      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n (I'm reading along and paying attention. But, just for the record, I'm leery of this interpretation. For starters, it was hashed and rehashed for years by all the Forge folks until it was discarded. It's a very old-school/traditional way of thinking about RPGs, and I'd be surprised if it can survive that kind of dissection again a second time. Anyway, don't mind me; just wanted to register my disclaimer - do go on!)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Paul_T said:

      But, just for the record, I'm leery of this interpretation. For starters, it was hashed and rehashed for years by all the Forge folks until it was discarded. It's a very old-school/traditional way of thinking about RPGs, and I'd be surprised if it can survive that kind of dissection again a second time.

      \nThere are games built on the model that entities are injected into the diegesis only as they are uttered. The Baker/Care-Boss principle does apply to those games.

      We want to have another model that enables other games.

      The principle "Magic cards have relevant text only on the front side of the cards" was true for 18 years... and then the Innistrad expansion came out with text and art printed on the back of cards too.

      Design space can grow when principles change.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I understand that. From where I'm sitting, this is more like saying, "Hey, what if we ignored those Innistrad cards, and make it a new rule that 'relevant text can only be on the front side of the cards', and see what we can make with that?"

      It's going backwards, in order of the development of those ideas. (This idea of the gamestate, although not in those words, of course, is how everyone I knew approached gaming back in the early 90's, and is strongly implied by the earliest D&D texts.)

      However, I'm ready to keep an open mind, because I'm *super excited* about any possibility of the design space growing, as you say. I'm just saying: be smart and careful and be aware that some very smart and knowledgeable people have torn down this approach before. You'll have to have bulletproof arguments or some really cool proof-of-concept designs! (Sometimes even incorrect ideas/theories can give birth to some great stuff, after all.)

      Anyway, back to the point - I don't want this to become a digression from the actual topic.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Paul_T said:

      I understand that. From where I\u2019m sitting, this is more like saying, \u201cHey, what if we ignored those Innistrad cards, and make it a new rule that \u2018relevant text can only be on the front side of the cards\u2019, and see what we can make with that?\u201d

      To me, that\u2019s what the \u201cno-myth\u201d model was when it was introduced. \u201cLet\u2019s ignore that there are unshared but canon diegetical entities and let\u2019s redefine the canon to only be entities that have been shared\u201d.

      That has also happened in Magic\u2019s history.

      Up until and including the Weatherlight expansion, the order of cards in the graveyard was a relevant part of the gamestate and that was used to design cards like the Nether Shadow.

      Then they said \u201cwhat if we ignored those cards, said that cards in the graveyard can be rearranged at will, and see what we can make with that?\u201d. A similar evolution happened with cards that interact with the set of cards that are being gambled for (the \u201cante\u201d zone), when Magic stopped gambling over cards.

      And both of those changes did lead to productive design; just as how \u201clet\u2019s see what games we can make with the No-myth model\u201d led and games such as Scattershot Lady Blackbird were invented. (And, for that matter, SLUG a decade earlier.)

      The \u201cno-myth\u201d model is a rule that says \u201centities can only be injected into the diegesis by being shared\u201d.

      [For example, the predicate entity \u201cThe party, except the rogue, are currently in room 12\u201d is injected into the diegesis by the playes saying \u201cWe go through the door. We are using Alice\u2019s torch, which is lit\u201d.]

      Full blorb games break that rule, by having some canonical entities being injected into the diegesis at prep time.

      [For example, the predicate entity \u201cThe coolest sword of all time, BLACKRAZOR, Stormbringer\u2019s punk li\u2019l brother, is in room 12\u201d can be a canon part of the gamestate even though only one participant is aware of that fact, or maybe no-one if the DM has injected the module whole-cloth.]

      The replacement for that rule is vague; I use the three tiers + the wallpaper saliency principle + the No Paper after seeing Rock principle. We have fruitful design space here for where we can script some \u201cmoves\u201d around this.

      My own desire for using this design space is ofc to keep the character/world gap large, to make the world seem \u201creal\u201d, etc. Injecting custom \u201cBelief-challenging\u201d entities as freely as BW lets the GM do it does not appeal to me. I want the entity injection to be more moderated by a gloracle\u2014i.e.\xa0decisions disclaimed to a greater degree.

      The goal, according to my own desire, is to keep a high degree of symmetry in the degree of canonicity in how the DM and the players treat the diegetic elements, respectively.

      The \u201cmagic mirror\u201d in such a setup is something that the DM treats with as much respect as the players do; it\u2019s an established game-state entity. [Sorry for the academese but obv the world \u201creal\u201d got misunderstood pretty badly.]

      If we can find a way to satisfy both of the following constraints:

      • entity canonicity has a high degree of cross-screen symmetry [i.o.w. keep it very blorby!]
      • many entities are relevant to character beliefs. Not so many so that the world starts to seem fake/overly-custom, but enough that the world is relevant [i.o.w. increase the degree of protagonization]

      we\u2019d be golden. (By the way can\u2019t they die in BW?)

      Now, what I\u2019m tryna do is to get player characters that that challenge each other\u2019s beliefs. A la hillfolk. But it\u2019s been an uphill battle. I should whip out the literal Hillfolk book again though. After the TPK last Tuesday my dorx started doing new characters and they Just Would Not want to hook them into each other. Each hobo an island.

      I\u2019m gonna try to whip those primitive screwheads in shape in that regard for today\u2019s session.

      \n
      \n

      \n

      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      2097 said:

      Each hobo an island.

      \nBecause we don't have enough experience with, vocab for, rules around, and a model for the type of activities we are doing in "character creation & dungeon prepping" mode as opposed to the "in play" mode which, through these last years of developing the various pillars & principles & glossaries, has become very refined.

      Hence thread
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJohann \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Paul_T said:

      You can make all kinds of stuff up on the spot, so long as it precedes the players' choice [...]. Maintaining that hygiene is much easier if you do it well in advance, but it's not impossible - for instance, not knowing what the players are thinking of doing is often sufficient for a "on the spot" invention to be entirely hygienic.

      \nExactly. Preparing content is just one way to help a GM maintain neutrality.\n
      Paul_T said:

      In Narrativist play, we generally/usually *want* to choose Paper after seeing Rock. Making those choices - what will I do with that rival from theatre school so as to make life interesting for the PC? - is at the heart of play.

      \nI fully agree.

      In a lot of gamist play, we want to make interesting choices (in a particular arena -- combat only in my last D&D 4e campaign, just about everything in most "sandbox" campaigns -- I think that's one way to interpret the term) and then have them judged fairly (typically in terms of success-failure), e.g. by a transparent process (e.g. the application of the combat rules without fudging).

      Other options than transparency exist, e.g. trust in the GM, though such trust may have to be earned, particularly with the looming spectre of illusionism. For instance, trust may be built by a campaign accruing TPKs, easy wins, anticlimaxes etc. A multi-pronged approach (transparency, accumulating trust, hygienic principles etc.) is probably best.

      In narrativist play, we want to make interesting choices and thereby judge the fiction ourselves (i.e., address premise). In many narrativist designs, it is largely irrelevant* how the situations offering these choices come about (similar to how in my above-mentioned 4e campaign the players did not care much how the PCs got involved in the GM's next set-piece combat -- the GM had to be a neutral referee only once we rolled for initiative).

      *Not irrelevant, really. I'm trying to express that the GM/player setting up a situation has a lot of leeway improvising it specifically to bring about those sought-after hard choices, tailoring them to the PCs and their recent decisions, current state etc..
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Johann said:

      trust in the GM

      \nTrust but verify. For example, trust falls is a good trust exercise because you know that your trust paid off because the other person catched you. (Same goes for the "knife sleep" trust exercise in one of my fave novels, Kallocain.)

      "Trust that I gave you the water glass I hadn't spat in" is a bad trust exercise because that's just gonna grow paranoia over time, not grow trust.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJohann \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n edited June 6
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      2097 said:

      The \u201cno-myth\u201d model is a rule that says \u201centities can only be injected into the diegesis by being shared\u201d.

      [For example, the predicate entity \u201cThe party, except the rogue, are currently in room 12\u201d is injected into the diegesis by the playes saying \u201cWe go through the door. We are using Alice\u2019s torch, which is lit\u201d.]

      Full blorb games break that rule, by having some canonical entities being injected into the diegesis at prep time.


      [For example, the predicate entity \u201cThe coolest sword of all time, BLACKRAZOR, Stormbringer\u2019s punk li\u2019l brother, is in room 12\u201d can be a canon part of the gamestate even though only one participant is aware of that fact, or maybe no-one if the DM has injected the module whole-cloth.]

      \nBut isn't this just an agreement at the social contract level ("I shall use all modules as written.")?

      As far as I can see, Blackrazor is only shared the moment it is described to the players present at the table. Before that, there is just a promise on the part of the GM, the breaking of which could be discovered).
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Johann said:

      But isn\u2019t this just an agreement at the social contract level (\u201cI shall use all modules as written.\u201d)?

      As far as I can see, Blackrazor is only shared the moment it is described to the players present at the table. Before that, there is just a promise on the part of the GM, the breaking of which could be discovered).

      We want to design games where entities (such as swords) can enter into the diegesis not only when they are being shared but also at other times. Such as during prep.

      We also want limits on when and how those entities can be altered once they\u2019ve ented the diegesis; the injection of entities and their predicates moderated by rules.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJohann \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n edited June 6
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      2097 said:

      entities (such as swords) can enter into the diegesis not only when they are being shared but also at other times. Such as during prep.

      \nTo me, this is a contradiction in terms. I'm not interested in arguing semantics,* though, so please carry on -- I'll be happy to just read along. It's an interesting discussion!

      *Which I did myself with "isn't this...?" and, even worse, "isn't this just...?". My apologies.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n edited June 6
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Right, "part of the canon offscreen gamestate" might be a phrase for it that you find less contradictory. SImilarly to how I can be dealt a Queen of Spades in Bridge and the gamestate now canonically has me holding a Queen of Spades, even before it has been played to a trick and been revealed to everyone.

      Roleplaying game diegetic entities are "made by words" but words can [in our model] be used in ways that extend beyond the immediate spoken word.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDeReel \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n In such a way that "My princess' maid is called Mavalda" is in the diegesis even if I only write it at the back of my character sheet ? Or is it the GM's authority on content that creates a specific glitch ?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      DeReel said:

      In such a way that "My princess' maid is called Mavalda" is in the diegesis even if I only write it at the back of my character sheet ?

      Yes.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDeReel \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n edited June 6
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n So you clearly use diegesis in this sense : "c'est l'univers d'une \u0153uvre, le monde qu'elle \xe9voque et dont elle repr\xe9sente une partie." (wikipedia ; tr : "It's the universe of a novel, the world it evokes and of which the novel represents only a part.") Diegesis can be more or less subjective but is always an interpretation.

      The term "game state" is a bit different, because it goes with the means to track it (preparation notes and drawings, character sheets and play notes, counters, etc.) The "game state" is objective. It does not describe all there is in a game though, far from it. It doesn't take into account body language at the table, for instance. It goes without saying but I'd rather say it, so you don't build a model of roleplaying where literacy has supremacy.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Oui, c'est vrai.
      The literate model.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Yeah, that\u2019s an important distinction to make.

      It seems to me that canon/setting information plays a big role in that, as well (like \u201cwe\u2019re playing in Middle Earth\u201d or \u201cmoral/spiritual alignments are a real thing in this world).
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Paul_T said:

      Jeph said:


      Are you also asking whether the presence of the encounter table in the prep implies that there's a green dragon in the gamestate, before we ever roll?

      Depends on the rules.

      In other words, depends on whether this group has agreed that every entity on an encounter table is in the gamestate but not yet in the imagined events...

      Or whether they've agreed that entities on an encounter table are mere potential, and they get added to the gamestate and imagined events simultaneously when they're rolled.

      \nI was hoping my italicized text at the bottom of my post would be enough to address this, but apparently it wasn't. I'll clarify again:

      Imagine, for the sake of the example, that we're dealing with a general-purpose, large-scale random table collection, like a "Blorbella's Tome of Random Encounter Charts for All Occasions, volume 17" - one of those thick tomes with 100 random encounters or monsters per page.

      Maybe the GM's procedure is to open the book to a random page and then roll a d100.
      \nOh, I don't think this actually changes my answer, really.

      Though I have a hard time imagining a group using Blorbella's Vol. 17 going with the "everything on the encounter table is in the diegesis" option over the "things on the encounter table get injected into the diegesis when rolled" option.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Yeah, that\u2019s exactly what I\u2019m trying to say! It would be a WILD stretch to say that those things are part of the \u201cgame state\u201d.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n With our current crude tools [hence thread: we want to get some more design done in this space!!!] then yes. I guess in my practice there's a mix. Sometimes an encounter table is very legitimate of the people running around in this region.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n (Yeah, I\u2019ve seen all kinds of variations on this.)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Sure. For that group, entries on encounter tables are clearly not yet diegetic.

      But a lot of the time, you'll see an encounter table like this (from a game I'm prepping):\n
      \n
        \n
      1. Mother Hen: A giant, talking, flying chicken with extremely soft, downy feathers. She is always willing to provide safety and fly someone home, if they are lost or in distress\u2014unless she is sitting an egg (25% chance). She lays giant eggs that hatch normal-sized chickens, albeit incredibly clever ones. Eating the golden yolks cures poisons and diseases, removes afflictions and curses, and can even revive the recently deceased. As a Roc with mental abilities of 16. She gives her reddish speckled feathers to her friends; they are Common one-use items that can be used to call her. She'll come along quick as she can, if not sitting an egg, arriving in (d4) minutes, tens of minutes, hours, or days. The feathers don't work for anyone but the one she gives them to.
        2. \n
      2. Les Trois Sourisquetaires: The mice, Athos, Porthos, and Aramis, who are considered by many (and certainly by themselves) to be the greatest adventurers of the age. They are just talking mice; no particular combat ability, but they always want to prove themselves the cleverest and bravest. They are quick to take insult, issue challenge, and strike up a rivalry, and profuse with stories of their own exploits. Each 1HD.
        3. \n
      3. Collector: A forty-foot-tall brass and ceramic stick-man who strides across the world on stilt-legs, plucking up things and placing them in the bird-cages that dangle from his body. He is intelligent, and many things interest him; he will often stop to listen or contemplate. But he never responds; merely swats things away and strides off if annoyed. Swarms of easily-angered wasps live in several of his cages. (As an Iron Golem with d4+1 insect swarms. Instead of poison breath, when he hits with a Slam, may forego dealing damage to snatch a Medium or smaller creature up and place it in a cage. Base speed is 60 feet. Disengage as bonus action. Int 14. Gargantuan size.)
        4. \n
      4. Red dragons, out hunting; lair located in the nearest mountains, possibly quite distant. Equal chance of Wyrmling, Young, Adult, or Ancient. Wyrmlings will be a clutch of 1d4; young adults and ancient are solitary; adults have a 50% chance of being in a mated pair. If followed back to its mountain lair, a wyrmling's hoard is worth 1d6 x 100 GP; each age category is x10. Plus 50% chance of a magic item: uncommon for wyrmling, rare for young adult, very rare for adult, and legendary for ancient.
        5. \n
      5. ...
        6. \n
      \n
      \nHere, it's clearly a mix.

      The existence of Mother Hen, the Mouseketeers, and Collector as individuals are part of the game state and diegetic, but not yet shared.

      The red dragons are more complicated. The potential for red dragons is in the rules (we've agreed on this procedure that can result in red dragons appearing in the game state and imagined events). I'd probably say it's also in the game state: the potential, that is, not the dragons themselves. Are rules-in-the-textual-sense (as opposed to Baker-Care-Boss Principle rules) that we've agreed to use per the B-C-B Principle part of the game state, idunno?

      I'm unclear about whether or not the potential for red dragons is in the diegesis. I think yes: per this particular game's convention, a generic entry on an encounter table means that at least one entity of that type exists.

      It's very much not yet shared, that's sure. The game hasn't even started. Only one of the future players knows it even exists. (And yet, it has some state and diegesis already!)

      The hoard of indeterminate size and possible magic items possessed by possible red dragons, I think, are firmly in the same category as the entries in the roll tables in Blorbella's Vol. 17.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Quite right. A random encounter table can be \u201cthis thing exists; when do we encounter it?\u201d and it can be \u201cwhat is in that room?\u201d, and gradations in between.

      The point of all this is that it\u2019s not as simple as \u201cimprovised = it wasn\u2019t there in the first place\u201d and \u201cgenerated by random table or procedure = it was always part of the game state\u201d. The way gaming works isn\u2019t that simple.

      And there\u2019s ALWAYS room for, \u201chey we rolled this encounter/this is what the module says now, but that makes no logical sense and breaks our sense of what\u2019s happening in the game, so we can\u2019t accept it\u201d, which is the Lumpley Principle in action.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Right, like, we've just established a few minutes ago that The Red-Dragon Snuffing Orb has eliminated all red dragons everywhere ever, but I haven't had a chance to alter the encounter table, but we roll encounter #4...
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Precisely.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nSilmenume \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 6 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hello,

      The problem with using the literate/textural mode of diegesis WRT to RPGs is that the totality of the text has yet to be written. For the diegesis to exist the text has to be read by a human being.

      What I'm picking up so far, but to my very poor memory, has not been made explicit is that what is being described as canon is being used in two different ways WRT to RPGs.

      1. You have the preparations made by the GM which are claimed to canon. The information contained within said canon is not available to the players at this state. I'm just avering that it is only the GM who has knowledge of the contents of the canon.

      2. You have the canon of the SIS. This is the record of what actually happened as a result of play. This canon is shared and known by all the players including the GM. This can only happen via a communication process amongst the players, which includes the GM whereby all the players agree via consensus that of all the events proposed only those agreed upon actually have credibility. The Lumpley (BCB) Principle in action.

      The sticking point of calling type 1 canon is that no one but the GM knows about it. I'm getting the sense that the end run around that issue is that via Social Contract Agreement the players can read the canon (the text) post hoc, e.g. after the act of Exploration (in theory terms) has come to a conclusion because it never ran through the Lumpley Principle.

      One way to address this, which is nothing new to theory, is consider that each player has their own imaginary space while the table has the Shared Imaginary Space. Even with this formulation one has problem that the when the Game State has yet to have any presence upon the Fact Space (the SIS).

      Let's go back to the chess game analogy. The chess board represents the SIS. The pieces the various PC's and monsters. The rules of play represent the System/resolution mechanics. They not only inform what each piece can do, what moves are illegal and how to resolve combat. So this chessboard with the pieces and where they currently are situation represent the current state of the SIS through time. The referee/judge would be the Lumpley (BCB) Principle. Victory or loss (this standing in for the abstracts that are so important in roleplay) is only informed by the pieces and how they are arranged on the board.

      But lo! There is much more going on in the head of the chess players than in represented on the chessboard. What the chessboard is utterly agnostic about is the significance of the positioning of the pieces. Nor does the chessboard concern itself with the intentions of the players i.e., what they are planning on doing next. The only thing the chessboard is about is where the pieces are right now. It's the players that glean meaning and significance from what on the board. Yet the players aren't solely concerned about what's on the board. One might be concerned that their position is untenable and fight to a quick draw to conserve mental stamina for the next match. Maybe the winning player knows that the losing player has a real problem with noise so chomps and snaps gum.

      But more the point about game-state the losing player may have studied every game the winning player has played and know his weaknesses. The losing player know this information well enough to bring it into play and defeat the winning player. But unless the losing player puts his knowledge and plan into action it does not matter to the game-state. That knowledge of how to win this match was not put into action and thus had no effect on the game-state.

      IOW what was privately know but not publicly shared via the chessboard (the SIS) had no effect on the game-state abstraction of win or lose in the players', referees' or spectators' minds.

      I understand that this but an analogy with all the shortcomings inherent therein.

      Best,

      Jay
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 7 \n edited June 7
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Paul_T said:

      And there\u2019s ALWAYS room for, \u201chey we rolled this encounter/this is what the module says now, but that makes no logical sense and breaks our sense of what\u2019s happening in the game, so we can\u2019t accept it\u201d, which is the Lumpley Principle in action.

      Jeph said:

      Right, like, we\u2019ve just established a few minutes ago that The Red-Dragon Snuffing Orb has eliminated all red dragons everywhere ever, but I haven\u2019t had a chance to alter the encounter table, but we roll encounter #4\u2026

      \u2026???

      You need to update the encounter table right away after using an Orb of Snuffing. That\u2019s the rule\u2026!

      Again, Baker/Care-Boss principle is kind of orthogonal to the issue of mistake handling, and in this case there\u2019s been a rules mistake.

      In a Baker/Care-Boss principle game [\u201ca game where entities become diegetically canon only when shared\u201d] there can be mistakes, and you can handle them in different ways.

      With the Hardholder cliff fortress example I had before, saying it was on the Western side of the cliff first but then forgetting that and then saying it was on the Eastern side, you could say either: \u201cOh, hold on, wasn\u2019t it on the Western side? I\u2019m sorry, it\u2019s on the Western side, let\u2019s stick to that, that\u2019s what we said first\u201d or you could say \u201cOh, I just realized we\u2019ve been saying Eastern side for a while, that makes more sense; seeing the sun rise over the barren lands, filling our vision with tiny rainbows in each of the thousand puddles of oil that dot the field.\u201d

      In a blorb game [\u201ca game where entities can become diegetically canon even before they are being shared\u201d] there can be mistakes, and you can handle them in different ways.

      \u201cOh, I\u2019m sorry, I forgot to update the encounter table, I\u2019ll do that later, for now please just reroll\u201d or you could say \u201cA red dragon? But we used an orb of snuffing? Let\u2019s just say it stands; the red dragon opens it\u2019s maw to unleash it\u2019s fiery kiss of hellfire, what do you do?\u201d

      This particular rules mistake I haven\u2019t seen done in my 5 years of running the game; using an Orb of Snuffing is such a momentous occasion. When Dr Strange used it [against vampires] in volume 2, #62 that was kind of a very memorable moment. Updating the encounter table is part of it\u2019s resolution.

      However, rules mistake can always happen. Don\u2019t feel bad. It happens often.

      I did one yesterday when I misunderstood which direction a one-way-door went.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    \n

    Narrativism vs traditional techniques

    \n
    \xab1\u2026891011121314\xbb

    Comments

      \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 7 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Silmenume said:

      For the diegesis to exist the text has to be read by a human being.

      No\u2026

      So there is this Thing; we\u2019ve been calling it a diegesis, a game-state, a canon, or a big old blorb. It can contain things that no-one at the table knows about. It doesn\u2019t even have to be written by a human being; I can go to a random dungeon generator site, have it generate a dungeon that no human has ever read, print it out with eyes closed, go to my hex map, say this new random dungeon is in THIS hex. It now exists and everything in it is part of the, uh, diegesis, game-state, canon, blorb\u2026 even though no human on Earth has read it, said it, or shared it.

      This \u201cThing\u201d is a set of entities.

      It\u2019s that set of entities that we operate on while playing and running blorb games.

      That is our relevant data structure.

      A subset of that set is the set of entities that have been shared.

      Keeping track of that \u201cshared\u201d subset is somewhat relevant.

      As DM, there is this scepter on a throne in a room in the dungeon I\u2019m running. The players saw it, walked up to it, but have not dared touch it. The exact amount of times they\u2019ve seen that thing, I don\u2019t really need to note or remember, or even the fact that they\u2019ve seen it once because all I need to remember/know to do my role is that in room so-and-so there is a scepter that looks so-and-so. The predicate shared-p is of a kinda low relevance in the case of that scepter.

      Conversely, in a Baker/Care-Boss-principle adhering game (if such a game even exists), the relevant data structure that the participants operate upon is the set of entities that have been shared. When they enter room so-and-so, instead of a scepter, I can say there is a devil there, or some ice cream, or a ghost. Sure, I\u2019d bound by the rules of the game when doing so, for example when making the \u201cAnnounce Future Badness\u201d move I can\u2019t say \u201cThere is nice & good tasting ice-cream here that restore 10 hp\u201d.

      Btw, I\u2019m not even sure that Apocalypse World itself adheres to the Baker/Care-Boss-principle. \u201cAlways say what your prep demands\u201d page 81. If I wrote down a scepter in room so-and-so, that becomes part of the relevant data structure even though it isn\u2019t shared-p.\n
      Silmenume said:

      What I\u2019m picking up so far, but to my very poor memory, has not been made explicit is that what is being described as canon is being used in two different ways WRT to RPGs.

      Good old \u201cFour mirror scenarios and two groups\u201d\u2026

      It\u2019s been said a bunch of times but recently and explicitly here. \u201cIn our new model, [\u2026the] gamestate has been extended beyond the spoken entities to also cover some unspoken entities.\u201d\n
      Silmenume said:

      The sticking point of calling type 1 canon is that no one but the GM knows about it.

      This is kind of an equivocation fallacy. You are used to reading theorists that discuss operating on a particular data-structure (the set of shared entities), the \u201cSIS\u201d. That makes you think that words like \u201ccanon\u201d, \u201cimagined space\u201d, etc primarily denote & connote qualities associated with that particular set. Leading to misconclusions like \u201cIf it\u2019s canon, it needs to have been shared?\u201d \u201cIf it\u2019s diegetically coherent, it needs to have been shared?\u201d \u201cIf it\u2019s part of the imagined space, it needs to have been shared?\u201d but for our new model, the relevant set that we operate on is a bigger set of entities where the shared-p predicate isn\u2019t inherently ontological but is instead of much lower relevance.\n
      Silmenume said:

      One way to address this, which is nothing new to theory, is consider that each player has their own imaginary space while the table has the Shared Imaginary Space.

      Sure, that\u2019s true but it\u2019s not particularly central to the way we operate when running and playing blorb games. If there is a red ball in a box, that ball doesn\u2019t only come into existence once you open the box and look in the ball.\n
      Silmenume said:

      Even with this formulation one has problem that the when the Game State has yet to have any presence upon the Fact Space (the SIS).

      See, conflating the SIS with the Fact Space is completely wrong in the new model.

      \u201cFact Space\u201d is actually kind of a good name for the blorb, for the diegesis, for the canon, for the game-state, for the data-structure, for the \u201cset of entities\u201d but it absolutely is not limited to only shared things.\n
      Silmenume said:

      There is much more going on in the head of the chess players than in represented on the chessboard. What the chessboard is utterly agnostic about is the significance of the positioning of the pieces.

      OK, so there are two kinda confusingly similar chess analogies going on here. In both analogies the \u201cchess board\u201d is a data structure that the participants are operating on.

      In your analogy, you\u2019re saying that the data structure relevant to you, the SIS\u2014the set of entities that have been shared\u2014is the chessboard, is the game-state, and that there are more things going around in the game than in that data structure and that those things might or mightn\u2019t have an effect on that gamestate, depending.

      But in our analogy, the \u201cchessboard\u201d signified a much larger set of entities. It included the prep, for example. The entire imagined space, not just the subset that is shared.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nThanuir \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 7 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Silmenume said:


      2. You have the canon of the SIS. This is the record of what actually happened as a result of play. This canon is shared and known by all the players including the GM. This can only happen via a communication process amongst the players, which includes the GM whereby all the players agree via consensus that of all the events proposed only those agreed upon actually have credibility. The Lumpley (BCB) Principle in action.

      \nSince I run games for different groups, and also in cons, set in the same game world, does it mean that nothing is ever in SIS? There are very few claims about the game world that every player has met in play.

      And these different games certainly have affected each other - an angel was summoned in a Burning wheel game quite some years ago, it has been central for a partially overlapping group of players, while a completely separate group of players has been interested but is yet to meet it.

      Or maybe you would like to say that all of these are different games. If so, how come that actions in one of them can affect the other in a highly meaningful way? One group fights against an army and at least stalls its progress, so others do not have to worry about it. Had the first group not done that, the war would have hit the others, forcing them to react. Right now they have been doing unrelated things.

      "Things are true when everyone knows about them." seems to be an inadequate model, here.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 7 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Thank you Thanuir\u2665
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 7 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      2097 said:

      In a Baker/Care-Boss principle game [\u201ca game where entities become diegetically canon only when shared\u201d] there can be mistakes, and you can handle them in different ways.

      \nNote that this misstates the Baker-Boss Principle, which is simply, "System is how we agree on what enters the fiction." We can agree that something "enters the fiction" only when it makes a difference in play (No Myth style) or we can agree that the GM's notes are "diegetic" in the sense of having a fictional existence before being communicated to any player.

      What it means when a GM or player makes a mistake in terms of (a) contradicting what has gone before in the fiction (that is, both imagined and shared), versus (b) contradicting what has been written in their own or someone else's notes (imagined but not shared) are thus slightly different cases. In what have been calling a No Myth game, only case (a) is a problem that requires repair. In any game in which the GM's prep or the PC's secret backstory have special "ontological" status (that is, diegetic consequence), case (b) also requires repair in play.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 7 \n edited June 7
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill\u2665\n
      Bill_White said:

      Note that this misstates the Baker-Boss Principle, which is simply, \u201cSystem is how we agree on what enters the fiction.\u201d We can agree that something \u201centers the fiction\u201d only when it makes a difference in play (No Myth style) or we can agree that the GM\u2019s notes are \u201cdiegetic\u201d in the sense of having a fictional existence before being communicated to any player.

      I really like that definition of system, \u201cSystem is how we agree on what enters the fiction\u201d, because it applies to both blorb games and no myth games.

      Others here have used this formulation of the Baker Care Boss principle, maybe it\u2019s older:

      \u201cSystem (including but not limited to \u2018the rules\u2019) is defined as the means by which the group agrees to imagined events during play.\u201d

      I get that \u201cplay\u201d can be defined very widely, but reading the rationale text on the old and dusty Big Model wiki makes it seems pretty much like a rallying cry for the \u201cno myth\u201d model.

      Which, of course no principle can ever override our own research findings here at S-G (when we find things that directely contradict the principle, or at least a particular interpretation of the principle), even if we want to be informed of ideas like that.

      So, when I\u2019ve been writing \u201cDoes not comply to Baker Care Boss principle\u201d, that doesn\u2019t apply to the principle as you (Bill) presented it just now. Just for the record\u2665\n
      Bill_White said:

      What it means when a GM or player makes a mistake in terms of (a) contradicting what has gone before in the fiction (that is, both imagined and shared), versus (b) contradicting what has been written in their own or someone else\u2019s notes (imagined but not shared) are thus slightly different cases. In what have been calling a No Myth game, only case (a) is a problem that requires repair. In any game in which the GM\u2019s prep or the PC\u2019s secret backstory have special \u201contological\u201d status (that is, diegetic consequence), case (b) also requires repair in play.

      That\u2019s right. Agreed.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 7 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Yeah, Bill\u2019s got it.

      The Principle just tells us that things other than HP and Armor Class are part of our System.

      In this case, treating the GM\u2019s prep as sacrosanct (and checking and correcting errors) is one of those Techniques.

      To say that something \u201cviolates\u201d the Lumpley/BCB Principle... I\u2019m not even sure what that means.

      \n
      \n
      \n\nVivificient \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 7 \n edited June 7
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n It looks like the disagreement comes from whether you see "the fiction" (in BCB Principle) as describing the "shared imaginary space" or "the game state."

      If we assume that "the fiction" refers to the "shared imaginary space" (i.e., the narration of the game world that you and all the players know and agree on), then it seems to me that the principle is still entirely consistent with good klockwerk play.

      Here is how that interpretation looks:

      The BCB Principle is "system is how we agree on what enters the fiction."

      In this game, the system is rules like "The fiction consists of the game state as described vividly from the perspective of the player characters" and "The DM must obey the Three Layers of Truth rule when editing the game state."

      And the game state is "this dungeon module I downloaded and printed without reading."

      Breakdown of the game at the level of the game state would look like the errors that have been discussed (e.g., the DM reads "Green Goblin" instead of "Green Dragon"). These are handled robustly by the part of the system that says something like, "If we discover an inconsistency between the fiction and the game state, we must correct it to bring them back into sync, usually by rewinding or amending the fiction."

      On the other hand, breakdown of the game at the level of the system would look like this:

      DM: You go into the room and see a race car.

      Players: What? That's ridiculous! There's no race cars in D&D!

      DM: It's what's in the room. We all agreed that the fiction would consist of exploring the game state, and we all agreed that the game state would include this module I downloaded and printed without reading."

      Players: Well, we didn't know it had a race car when we agreed to it! Come on! We won't play unless you take out the race car.

      The BCB principle is saying that this latter scenario is still possible, even with a system that implies the race car is part of the game.

      Edit: OK, I see a similar clarification was reached in the other thread. This is confusing how the discussion keeps jumping back and forth.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 7 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Gotchu Vivs\u2665
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 7 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Vivificient has the basic gist of my issues with this idea.

      You\u2019re so committed to the idea of prepped information being \u201creal\u201d that you want to twist around the theory to preserve that idea.

      You\u2019re taking the Principle far too literally, in other words.

      In Lumpley Principle terms, the social agreement in a \u201cfull blorb\u201d game is that the GM will make things up, yes, but commits to never contradicting prepped facts. This is entirely in line with the Principle, not a contradiction of it. (Just like Apocalypse World\u2019s \u201csay what your prep demands\u201d.)

      You posted an example earlier where you described there being tar on the wall, and you\u2019re worried that the players might take advantage of that fact.

      It sounds like, in your ideal RPG, either a) the GM is not allowed to describe tar (because it\u2019s not prepped beforehand), or b) the players are not allowed to use that to their advantage.

      That, in my opinion, would be a pretty terrible
      game, and possibly not even really a roleplaying game (something I\u2019m usually very hesitant to say about anything that happens in the wild variety of our hobby!).

      There are much better, easier, and more useful ways to understand the same constraints, in my opinion, or at least ways that won\u2019t confuse people to death with statements like \u201cmy game doesn\u2019t comply with the BCB Principle\u201d. Therein lies madness!

      However, it also feels like we\u2019re butting heads with no or little progress, so I\u2019ll just register my disagreement and then back away from this debate.

      I may disagree with how you\u2019re describing this theoretically, but I love what you\u2019re doing with games and will continue to read with great pleasure everything that you write on the subject.

      So don\u2019t ever stop!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      Paul_T said:

      However, it also feels like we\u2019re butting heads with no or little progress, so I\u2019ll just register my disagreement and then back away from this debate.

      Writing a diatribe on how wrong I am and then saying you\u2019re only registering your disagreement? \n
      Paul_T said:

      You\u2019re taking the Principle far too literally, in other words.

      I think I\u2019ve, in this and the other thread, demonstrared a willingness to work with a variety of interpretations of the LBCBP. Some interpretations, like Bill\u2019s, do work with my game.

      I\u2019ve seen two different interpretations of the LBCBP here.

      Bill\u2019s, which extended the definition \u201cthe fiction\u201d to include un-uttered / unknown aspects of the gamestate. (That\u2019s not a Forge-compatible definition of \u201cthe fiction\u201d, where \u201cthe fiction\u201d specifically means only the transcript.)

      The Big Model web page\u2019s definition, which, after a very \u201cno-myth\u201d ingress (which I\u2019ve replied to in detail, states\n
      Paul_T said:

      System (including but not limited to \u2018the rules\u2019) is defined as the means by which the group agrees to imagined events during play.

      And our new model has a system that also covers other things.\n
      Paul_T said:

      There are much better, easier, and more useful ways to understand the same constraints, in my opinion, or at least ways that won\u2019t confuse people to death with statements like \u201cmy game doesn\u2019t comply with the BCB Principle\u201d.

      Well, see you in heaven because there are many many games that don\u2019t comply with the LBCBP. Bridge and Poker for example both have rules that are not a strict subset of a system defined as a the means by which the group agrees to imagined events during play. Therefore, I can say with certainty that the LBCBP does not apply to them.\n
      Paul_T said:

      Therein lies madness!

      Again with the \u201cmad\u201d ablism. I just get these headaches\u2026\n
      Paul_T said:

      It sounds like, in your ideal RPG, either a) the GM is not allowed to describe tar (because it\u2019s not prepped beforehand), or b) the players are not allowed to use that to their advantage.

      My current game, 2097e, has a rule for how to deal with wallpaper when it becomes salient, which is what happened.

      I\u2019m not gonna go \u201cyay awesome\u201d when that rule is invoked, because I dream that one day an even better wallpaper-became-salient rule, or better way to do wallpaper, will be invented. This is fresh & new design ground and the rules are rough and ad-hoc.\n
      Paul_T said:

      That, in my opinion, would be a pretty terrible game, and possibly not even really a roleplaying game (something I\u2019m usually very hesitant to say about anything that happens in the wild variety of our hobby!).

      Some say love it is a river that drowns the tender reed. Others say that I\u2019m working on a terrible game that\u2019s not even really a roleplaying game. I say the game is like a flower and prep it\u2019s only seed.

      Listen up, the following is pretty cool. Maybe I should start a new thread about it:

      What data-structure does your game operate on?

      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 7 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      2097 said:


      I\u2019ve seen two different interpretations of the LBCBP here.

      Bill\u2019s, which extended the definition \u201cthe fiction\u201d to include un-uttered / unknown aspects of the gamestate. (That\u2019s not a Forge-compatible definition of \u201cthe fiction\u201d, where \u201cthe fiction\u201d specifically means only the transcript.)

      \nYou misread me, I think. If we agree that the GM's prep has a special diegetic status, then we've agreed that it takes priority over potentially contradictory material that someone may attempt to introduce "into the transcript" (which, somewhat confusingly), the Big Model takes to mean the account of (fictional) in-game events. What people say at the table as well as other game-mechanical and play-related texts, in contrast, is "Ephemera"). The important point is that we agree that the GM's prep takes priority.

      So "the means by which the group agrees to imagined events during play" includes in some cases "the GM refers to her notes and tells us what's here." It's still Baker-Boss "system." A game without shared imagined events is arguably by definition not a role-playing game.

      But if you want to create Chess: The RPG to prove me wrong, that's great. To quote Ron Edwards, via the manuscript of my hopefully forthcoming book about the Forge:\n
      Ron\u2019s comment at a panel at InterNosCon, an Italian gaming convention, in 2010 illustrates the extent to which he was motivated by an ideal of a broad understanding of the possibilities of RPGs as a form. \u2018We could be talking about designing and playing better role-playing games,\u2019 he told an audience of about 20 Italian indie gamers. Alternately, \u2018We could be talking about breaking that and making a different thing. . . . I\u2019d rather not do that.\u2019 Instead, he went on, \u2018I think that there is a productive dynamic between saying I am making a better role-playing game and saying, no, I am making something different. Rather than knowing which one you are doing, perhaps it is better to recognize that there may be a difference between the two but\u2014but it is a dynamic relationship over time . . . Someone could have been trying to make a better role-playing game, and what they did opens up the door to something completely different, or someone could have said, \u201cOh, no, I am completely different, I am not making a role-playing game,\u201d and what they do inspires someone to make a better role-playing game.\u2019 Ultimately, he said, \u2018We don\u2019t know. We don\u2019t know. Just let that be dynamic. Let that\u2014relax about that.\u2019
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 7 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n My co-authors and I talk about an issue that seems close to what you mean when you say salience in the Fate Space Toolkit:\n
      We\u2019ll use the term black box to refer to any potentially important science fiction setting element. These are technologies or scientific contrivances, and in some fiction their likely consequences are not fully thought out before their introduction. For example, script writers don\u2019t often consider things like how the nonscarcity economy implied by the existence of food replicators in the Star Trek universe affects the Federation (but see Manu Saadia\u2019s Trekonomics for an extended discussion of the replicator). Though a technology that can manipulate matter at a molecular level is both really powerful and really interesting, it\u2019s not the point of the show, so it gets moved into the background.

      So in effect, a black box is Just the Way Things Are, without further consequence
      or implication to the setting. It signals that certain problems\u2014like \u201cHow do we
      get our food while we\u2019re in space?\u201d\u2014are not interesting in the fiction. At least, not
      most of the time. But in a Fate Space game, it is often worthwhile to keep track
      of black boxes for the times when they can lead to challenges or opportunities
      that might prove very interesting, indeed!

      For example, any of these fictional details can be treated as a black box:

      o Antigravity in the deck plates
      o Hyperspace technology
      o Personal teleportation belts
      o Extended human lifespan

      However, once established, a black box can become a plot point in an adventure, even if most of the time it is ignored. Suddenly the grav plates are on the fritz; the power crystals are slowly depleting while the ship is trapped in hyperspace mid-jump; the calibration sensors on this TP-belt are out of alignment; or the captain\u2019s nanogerionic therapy regimen has caused a harmful mutation. Any of these can be an issue that requires time and attention during play. Thus, black boxes can imply, inspire, and collect aspects that make the setting feel more plausible and coherent.
      \nThe rules for when a black box or something like it opens up--becomes salient--probably fall into different categories based on Tweet's resolution categories: Drama, Fortune, Karma.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 7 \n edited June 7
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n@Bill_White&;lt;br />I want those GM notes to also be governed by rules. Rules for when and how to add, remove or change things in them. That\u2019s the thing that makes me think that the transcript, the shared imagined events, while important, is not the central \u201cgame board\u201d anymore.

      I think you, me and Ron are on the same page that whether this or that is different, better, \u201cnot a role-playing-game\u201d or whatever, that\u2019s not the productive part of this work.

      I want to have rules that operate on a whole new level is what I\u2019m saying.

      I broke that out to a new thread so that my dumb semantics argument can continue here:

      In the chess analogy I made [which is distinct from Jay\u2019s chess analogy but similar to Jeph's chess analogy], both the oldies and the kids were doing the same thing: saying letters & numbers to each other. That was the whole of the game, for both: talking. Neither had a physical board.

      The LBCBP obviously applies to the kids\u2019 take on memory chess.

      One can also construct a set of rules, with the LBCBP in mind, to construct a fully isomorphic version of the oldies\u2019 version of the game strictly as operands on the uttered statements.

      For example:\n
      PbtA chess said:

      To start the game, say a letter from a through h followed by a 3 or a 4, or say the letter N, followed by a, c, f, or h, and a 3.

      Then the second player replies by saying a letter from a through h followed by a 5 or a 6, or saying the letter N followed by a, c, f, or h, and a 6.

      etc etc. One could do that. And obviously a chess board [real or imagined] is a great tool when constructing that type of rule set, just like the threat map is a great tool in AW2e.

      But.

      for this game \u201coldies\u2019 memory chess\u201d, it\u2019s much more efficient, relevant, and valuable for rule designers to create rules that primarily operate on the board directly [again: real or imagined] and only secondarily creates utterances such as \u201cexd5\u201d.

      We want to do that.

      And when the No myth crew then say \u201cno no no the only things that matter is what are being said, stop pretending that anything else matters, stop trying to make rules about anything else\u201d that can get kinda frustrating.

      There\u2019s a looot of appeal to authority from Paul right now (not from you, Bill), \u201cBaker & Care-Boss once said\u201d, \u201cChris Lehrich once said\u201d, \u201cFang Langford once said\u201d. And, like, that\u2019s getting to be kinda patronizing. I get it. They were, 15 years ago, hyperfocused on a tiny subset of what I\u2019m interested in. They cared primarily about the subset of diegetical entities that have happened to have been uttered at the table within earshot of another participant. They were into trees that fell in the forest with someone to hear, I\u2019m more interested in all kinds of falling trees. God, Paul, you\u2019re making me feel like a complete schizophrenic, I\u2019m so gaslighted right now. I\u2019m \u201cdelusional\u201d for desiring some rules to cover the \u201cchasm width\u201d problem. Can someone who gets what I\u2019m talking about please come here and back me up? I\u2019d really appreciate it.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nSilmenume \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 7 \n edited June 7
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hello Sandra,

      There is absolutely nothing contradictory with "I want those GM notes to also be governed by rules. Rules for when and how to add, remove or change things in them." and the LBCBP. Its an interesting section of game theory and design development. Maybe even a disruptive area of thought - disruptive in the good sense of radically altering.

      Having a game system where the GM actions are tightly prescribed is still System. The idea of strictly formalizing how the GM can operate while not new has not been explored in depth. Let the good ideas flow!

      But both @Bill_White and @Vivicent have the right of the LBCBP. That the GM game prep gets automatic or highest credibility is still System. That the players could revolt at something the GM enters into play is a breakdown that the LBCBP covers. When the players are not in consensus about the SIS play breaks down until the problem is resolved. That's the LBCBP.

      That the GM can and does exercise control of "off-screen"/extra-SIS events is fairly well established. That you want to create a rigorous system for how that happens is interesting but ultimately a game design issue. No problem.

      The thesis that you're promoting about these "off-screen" actions that have been fully documented prior to play but not in any way (yet) been communicated, validated and integrated into the "fact space"/SIS/text has the same the same weight and validity is what is controversial. It is the "creating a language in a closet" is not the same as communicating issue.

      Of course there is a lot going on outside the SIS in the minds of every player especially the one bearing the burdens of the GM. To me, this Individual Imagined Space is the awesome sauce of the game. We plan our actions. We consider the implications of our or another players actions. We wonder at the significance of an event. We worry about our character dying. We surge with joy at getting the joooools! We plan short and long term goals. Perhaps we're thinking about an internal crisis point about our character. Maybe we are angry about an injustice perpetrated upon our character or are plotting revenge. This is all very player facing and where are hearts are most engaged. This IIS also covers such things as the players' character sheets and what not. This is all player facing.

      What I think you're getting at is very GM facing. Rules, regs and procedures for GMing in a certain mode of play that all the players agreed on at the Social Contract Level before playing. Very cool and have at it.

      The proposal that is causing the rukus is claiming that the GM facing part of the game is functionally self-same as the player facing part of the game. There is absolutely nothing controversial about the GM moving things in the backfield as long as such actions don't impinge directly on the established fact space/SIS. An army can march on the players hometown while they are adventuring and that is perfectly acceptable as long as it doesn't violate system or the established facts/SIS. In fact this makes for a living breathing world beyond the myopic view when we focus solely only the hobos.

      But to propose that this uncommunicated IIS has the same credibility as shared and validated communications/proposals does run afoul of both the shared and communal parts that are the fundamental process of role-play.

      The question that needs to be answered is how that information which is only known to a very specific one (uncommunicated/unshared) equated to the fact space which is a communal communication construct?

      Yes private imaginings are a vital part of the game but if they are not put into play in any way ("putting into play" includes having an IIS construct and using it to influence/inform our proposal offered into the fact space/SIS) then from the player facing side we've got nothing. If what the GM facing stuff does never enters the Proposal stage of play then as far as the players are concerned it never exists. By analogy the writer's notes may exist but if they never made it into the text the reader never has any knowledge of said writings. As far as reading goes the unincorporated notes don't exist and don't matter.

      Best,

      Jay
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 7 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Silmenume said:

      The thesis that you\u2019re promoting about these \u201coff-screen\u201d actions that have been fully documented prior to play but not in any way (yet) been communicated, validated and integrated into the \u201cfact space\u201d/SIS/text has the same the same weight and validity is what is controversial. It is the \u201ccreating a language in a closet\u201d is not the same as communicating issue.

      Obviously when the DM is in that closet and engaging with the ruleset she is creating referents. Chris Lehrich is just strictly wrong about that. I\u2019m gonna die on that hill, I\u2019ll never yield.

      Introducing those referents into the SIS is creating signs on another level compared to introducing them into the prep. No one is disputing that.

      In our model where the prep is in such high regard, that \u201clevel difference\u201d is very minor. In a \u201cno myth\u201d model, that \u201clevel difference\u201d is fundamental.

      Which is fine. This is all semantics.\n
      Silmenume said:

      But to propose the this uncommunicated IIS has the same credibility as shared and validated communications/proposals does run afoul of both the shared and communal parts that are the fundamental process of role-play.

      In which case I\u2019ll have none-of-it. If you would deny my game the label of \u201croleplaying game\u201d then that\u2019s fine. D&D the original roleplaying game is not a roleplaying game. Fine. That\u2019s all semantics.


      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 7 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Yes, Bill and Silmenume are approaching this in a way that makes sense to me.

      I love and support what you\u2019re doing, and I think it\u2019s good stuff. Even great stuff. You should keep pursuing it, and I\u2019ll be there with you all the way (because I also love playing this way, and always want to do it better).

      My only objection is that you\u2019re misinterpreting the BCB Principle, and that\u2019s muddying he waters. I don\u2019t even think it\u2019s relevant to what you\u2019re talking about.

      That\u2019s all!
      \n

      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nSilmenume \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 7 \n edited June 12
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hello Sandra,\n
      2097 said:

      If you would deny my game the label of \u201croleplaying game\u201d then that\u2019s fine. D&D the original roleplaying game is not a roleplaying game. Fine. That\u2019s all semantics.

      \nI'm talking about a model framework of understanding how role-play functions. I have never nor do I ever intend to make negative claims about the utility, joyousness or the nature of your game. It is a role-playing game and apparently a very good one at that.

      Please don't mistake the theory discussion of a proposed method for analyzing play as the same as a critique of the actual game itself. That is simply not the case. IOW I make NO claims at all on your game but I am trying to engage in an interlocutory about the powerful claims you make about the process.

      For a fairly long time role-play theory has been based on the transactional model of communication and your current theory claims suggest that you disagree with that. That's a huge claim to make. Like....wow! Huge.

      I doubt this will make things any easier but I will say them again for clarity's sake. I've read your threads on design with fascination and wonder. I like my style of play but I appreciate the effort, beauty and most importantly the reported successes of your design efforts. My arguments have been only and strictly for the theory side.

      I'm sorry that I haven't been a better communicator and I'm sorry that my shortcoming as such have caused you distress. I've tried to be civil and stay on topic and if I've failed I can only claim my humanity with all its attendant failings and offer you my apologies in the hope you accept them.

      All the best,

      Jay
      \n

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n

      \n\nJune 7 \n

      \n
      \n Well said, Jay. We are entirely on the same page here.

      (I hope some combination of Jay's words and mine will make sense to you, Sandra! There's no ill will here from either of us.)

      \n
