      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 8 \n edited June 8
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n In the other thread, Paul wrote:\n
      Paul_T said:

      AW is generally much more self-aware (about the nature of roleplaying) than old school D&D.

      \nPaul, that is an argumentative and unproved statement that I disagree with. I first wrote an opposing statement:

      I'd say the opposite is true. AW's approach feels incredibly cargo cult to me. C.f. the kids' version of memory chess.

      but I've deleted it (thanks, @Thanuir ) because at this point we'd both be falling into the old "nuh-uh!" fallacy.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nThanuir \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 8 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I have always understood Baker-Care-Boss principle to be a definition of "system" in Forge theory; that "system" in the Forge sense means precisely the way things are brought into the shared imagined space, which I have understood to mean the parts of the fiction that has been shared among at least some players around the table and have been accepted as true.

      I do think this definition of system can be used when discussing a sandbox/klockwerk/blorb games - as others have more-or-less written above, it simply states that the procedures for upholding the game state or the fiction are parts of the system that give credibility to claims concerning what gets to enter the shared imagined space. I think that this is a fruitful path.

      The same definition could be used to discuss highly immersive play, or character optimization play where showing off your creation is what happens in play, while the actual optimization happens between the sessions.

      However, in all of these cases, the Forge definition of system describes fewer of the salient features of play than it does for play with focus on narrative authority, or for essentially improvised play.

      * The point of character optimization (in a game where the group appreciates it) is not to be able to add certain utterances into the fiction, but rather to be able to achieve system mastery and find interesting combinations and loopholes. Showing off your creation in play is of course nice and all, but does not require the convoluted jungle of mechanics.
      * The point of highly immersive play is not the input you give into the shared fiction. Hopefully that will be more interesting and dramatic due to your immersion, but, as far as I understand, the immersion itself is the point. And, indeed, Forge theory has had serious problems with understanding people who hold immersion as a dear goal in play. Harsh words have been exchanged in the past, I think.
      * The point with sandbox/klokkverk/blorb is not the fact that one can refer to prep and random tables to add credibility to certain statements, but rather the solid fiction and whatever ways it is being used - as an arena for challenges, as making the narrative the game creates feel more real, etc.

      This suggests that one should pay more attention to other things when discussing these other types of games. And this is what some of the relevant communities have been doing:

      * Character optimizers do their theoretical optimization stuff. They do not pay attention to who adds to the fiction and when.
      * People who want specific emotional experiences have traditionally discussed props, candle light, how a story should be structured, etc., and more recently the structured freeform/Fastaval/jeep people seem to also be aiming for creating certain intense experiences, and the fiction in their games is often fairly nebulous and not that central (when compared to traditional games or many Forge games). I might utterly wrong here; feel free to correct, if so.
      * OSR people pay a lot of attention on how to abstract the game world, what kind of content should be in the game world, and, for a different take, on how the referee should act to keep the game state solid and communicate this to the players. This "different take" is influenced by the Forge system thinking and it seems to mostly have been done at Story games and by some people with background in PbtA play; this is the "fruitful path" I mentioned above. The concerns about abstracting and nature of content are more widely discussed and more distant from Forge system and credibility of narration.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nThanuir \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 8 \n edited June 8
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Paul_T said:

      AW is generally much more self-aware (about the nature of roleplaying) than old school D&D.

      \n
      2097 said:


      I'd say the opposite is true. AW's approach feels incredibly cargo cult to me. C.f. the kids' version of memory chess.

      \nOne would hope Apocalypse world (2010) to be more self-aware than old school D&D (1974-1986, leaving AD&D 2 out, or -1991, if the third edition is where we draw the line).

      Claiming that for example PbtA community is more or less self aware than OSR community would, on the other hand, be quite argumentative and difficult to settle without some serious research: conceptual work (how to measure self-awareness?) and empirical work.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 8 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Silmenume said:

      For a fairly long time role-play theory has been based on the transactional model of communication and your current theory claims suggest that you disagree with that. That\u2019s a huge claim to make. Like\u2026.wow! Huge.

      Yes. I claim that Chris Lehrich was strictly wrong back in 2004. [Which I can\u2019t judge him for because I was even more off the mark back then.]

      Their model: Talking is fundamental.
      Our model: Talking is incidental.

      In their model, talking is the fundamental layer, and all other ephemera (such as dice and prep) are engaged incidentally in order to produce direct operands for talking (the fundamental layer). (I.e. \u201cIf someone says so-and-so, roll 2d6, add this-and-that, and if it\u2019s lower than six, then say that-and-this.\u201d)

      In our model, the game state is the fundamental layer, and all other ephemera (such as talking) are engaged incidentally in order to produce direct operands for the game state (the fundamental layer). (I.e. \u201cIf 20 pounds of pressure is applied to this floor tile, the trap door opens\u201d)

      In our model, we talk when there is a lack of about the game state that needs to be resolved.

      Going through this finchian example with our model:\n
      Finch said:

      GM: \u201cA ten-foot wide corridor leads north into the darkness.\u201d

      GM talking because John has a lack of clarity about where he is.\n
      Finch said:

      John the Roguish: \u201cWe move forward, poking the floor ahead with our ten foot pole.\u201d

      John talking because John has a lack of clarity about what happens if he moves forward.\n
      Finch said:

      GM: Is about to say that the pole pushes open a pit trap, when he remembers something. \u201cWait, you don\u2019t have the ten foot pole any more. You fed it to the stone idol.\u201d [if the party still had the pole, John would have detected the trap automatically]
      John the Roguish: \u201cI didn\u2019t feed it to the idol, the idol ate it when I poked its head.\u201d
      GM: \u201cThat doesn\u2019t mean you have the pole back.\u201d

      Group correcting a mistake about the gamestate, which takes precedence over what\u2019s just been said.\n
      Finch said:

      GM: \u201cDo you go into the corridor?\u201d

      GM talking because GM has a lack of clarity about John\u2019s actions.\n
      Finch said:

      John the Roguish: \u201cNo. I\u2019m suspicious. Can I see any cracks in the floor, maybe shaped in a square?\u201d
      GM: Mulls this over, because there\u2019s a pit trap right where John is looking. But it\u2019s dark, so \u201cNo, there are about a million cracks in the floor. You wouldn\u2019t see a pit trap that easily, anyway.\u201d

      A question & the answer to resolve clarity about the visible details of the floor.\n
      Finch said:

      John the Roguish: \u201cOkay. I take out my waterskin from my backpack. And I\u2019m going to pour some water onto the floor. Does it trickle through the floor anywhere, or reveal some kind of pattern?\u201d

      Water is being poured in the game state order to find out if there is a trap in the floor. John incidentally lets the GM know this so that it\u2019s added to the game state but primarily so that John can find out what happens to the game state.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 8 \n edited June 8
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Going through the same example with the transactional model:\n
      Finch said:

      GM: \u201cA ten-foot wide corridor leads north into the darkness.\u201d

      GM wants to use talking to describe an adventurous location, he incidentally engages his notes [such as a dungeon map] in order to find what details he can add to the fiction (such as the width, cardinal direction, and light), and then talks. The GM then leaves a pause in order to allow John to add a statement to the fiction.\n
      Finch said:

      John the Roguish: \u201cWe move forward, poking the floor ahead with our ten foot pole.\u201d

      John wants to use talking in order to describe a story about a forward motion through a corridor, he incidentally engages his knowledge about the character\u2019s capabilities, such as having legs, a non-zero movement rate, and a particular pole.\n
      Finch said:

      GM: Is about to say that the pole pushes open a pit trap, when he remembers something. \u201cWait, you don\u2019t have the ten foot pole any more. You fed it to the stone idol.\u201d [if the party still had the pole, John would have detected the trap automatically]
      John the Roguish: \u201cI didn\u2019t feed it to the idol, the idol ate it when I poked its head.\u201d
      GM: \u201cThat doesn\u2019t mean you have the pole back.\u201d

      GM wants to add a pit trap to the fiction, and incidentally consults his notes to see that he is both allowed and obliged to add a pit trap to this particular location. He mentally refers back to his recollection of the transcript and recalls that it has previously been established in the fiction that John\u2019s incidental capabilities (the pole) have been dimished. He realizes that the fiction has been compromised by a mistake and issues a correction.\n
      Finch said:

      GM: \u201cDo you go into the corridor?\u201d

      The GM knows that it\u2019s John\u2019s turn to add a statement to the fiction and creates a prompt for him to do so.\n
      Finch said:

      John the Roguish: \u201cNo. I\u2019m suspicious. Can I see any cracks in the floor, maybe shaped in a square?\u201d

      John wants to use narration to portray a canny and cautious young man so he adds a statement to the fiction that implies that he is attempting to examine the floor.\n
      Finch said:

      GM: Mulls this over, because there\u2019s a pit trap right where John is looking. But it\u2019s dark, so

      That\u2019s not how a GM would reason if the transactional model were true. Instead:

      \u201cGM: Wants the fiction to portray this adventure location as very challenging and also hammer home his previous addition to the fiction about the light situation so he says\u201d\n
      Finch said:

      \u201cNo, there are about a million cracks in the floor. You wouldn\u2019t see a pit trap that easily, anyway.\u201d

      and then\n
      Finch said:

      John the Roguish: \u201cOkay. I take out my waterskin from my backpack. And I\u2019m going to pour some water onto the floor. Does it trickle through the floor anywhere, or reveal some kind of pattern?\u201d

      John wants to pile on to the portrayal of this canny and cautious adventurer and incidentally engages his list of gear in order to add to the fiction, including embelleshing the the previously establish part of this fiction, the floor.

      As you can see, I do understand the transactional model. I just think it\u2019s not the best fit for the type of design work I want to do.

      I want to see what designs we can create when not shackled to this model.

      For example, here is a part where the transactional model is stretched thin:\n
      2097 said:

      GM wants to add a pit trap to the fiction, and incidentally consults his notes to see that he is both allowed and obliged to add a pit trap to this particular location.

      In the transactional model, rules cannot govern whether or not a pit trap is present at a location.

      Instead, if you want to model a fully blorb game with the transactional model, you need to create a rule that says where you are allowed&obliged to add, and where you are disallowed to add, pit traps into the uttered-at-the-table fiction, and that rule incidentally engages the prep.

      But if you\u2019re not forcing the design through the transactional model, you can just straight forwardly make rules that govern how or when pit traps are added to the prep because the prep is no longer something that you have to engage with incidentally; instead you can engage with it primarily as part of the game state, since the game state is the fundamental layer.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 8 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I cross posted with @Thanuir (my double-length post above took some time to write).

      Agree with @Thaunir.\n
      Thanuir said:

      This suggests that one should pay more attention to other things when discussing these other types of games. And this is what some of the relevant communities have been doing

      \nYes.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nNeurotrash \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 8 \n edited June 8
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n So, for my own edification and clarification, at this point the debate is about whether:

      An RPG is a conversation about what happens in the SIS. The system (as understood by the B-C-B Principle) is what we use to decide how that conversation is allowed to determine what happens in the SIS.

      OR

      An RPG is (or can be) an exercise in manipulating an Objective Game State. The system exists to allow players (including the DM) to both ascertain what is true about the current game state and affect change upon the game state and then determine how the game state is affected.

      ---

      Furthermore, we are also arguing whether:

      Both of these statements can accurately describe what is happening in an individual game, and thus if one is true about one game and another is true about another, then those two games might not be of the same type? (The terminology used to label and differentiate between these different types being a whole can of worms any sane person would probably want to avoid given past atrocities)

      OR

      Only one of the above statements is true about the type of game we call an RPG, and anyone arguing for the false proposition is simply [using inaccurate language to describe/is deluded about] what is actually happening in the game?

      Or am I off-base?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 8 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n That seems like a pretty good summary to me!
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\n2097 \n\n\n

      \n

      \n Thanks for the summary\u2665
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 8 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I\u2019m gonna die on the \u201cChris Lehrich was wrong about closet language & semiotics\u201d hill but I\u2019m pretty flexible on the rest of this debate stuff.

      So for me it\u2019s more about:\n
      • let\u2019s pretend that one of these models is right, and design some games,
      • let\u2019s pretend that the other of these model is right, and design some games,
      This variety will lead us to new rules, new mechanics, new interesting design solutions.

      We already saw an amazing payoff in @Thanuir \u2019s ideas in the data structure thread. Whether that idea will pan out or not, we\u2019ll have to see, but I\u2019m optimistic.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nSilmenume \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 8 \n edited June 9
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Thanuir said:

      Since I run games for different groups, and also in cons, set in the same game world, does it mean that nothing is ever in SIS? There are very few claims about the game world that every player has met in play.

      And these different games certainly have affected each other - an angel was summoned in a Burning wheel game quite some years ago, it has been central for a partially overlapping group of players, while a completely separate group of players has been interested but is yet to meet it.

      \nHaving given this some thought I propose that what you are describing is nothing more than persistence of Setting. As role-play is a group communicative process for that Setting information to relevant to the play process it must be entered into the SIS. Here's where the hangup seems to be manifesting. What does communication mean? It can mean spoken words, written text, somatic actions by the players, dice, cards, silence when that act of silence communicates information - such as when a character refuses to answer a direct order under heavy penalty to divulge information, describing the effects of something unknown to the players is having on the Setting, etc.

      Even if this communication takes place out of game session the LBCB Principle still holds once play begins. Basically the LBCB Principle covers whether or not the out of game information is usable by the PC's in game. This happens all the time with players reading the rules and setting information about the game.

      That the GM has more Setting information or can create Setting information through random tables or direct creative efforts is nothing new or controversial. That the GM bears the responsibility for maintaining this continuity of Setting is nothing new.

      Since RPG play has always been played as a process of change and not a state or condition of being that process of change has always been communicated, regulated and agreed upon. It's not enough for the players to sit and stare at each other. While it is necessary, it is not sufficient that only the GM communicating to call that process roleplay. If that were the case someone reading out loud to an audience would be called roleplay.

      I don't deny and have never denied what I am now calling Setting persistence. I'm saying that Setting Persistence doesn't matter to player agency if that persistent information does not affect the SIS in some way.

      So my two questions to you are -

      1. How was the information about the Angel summoning communicated amongst your various groups? (Especially with regards to the completely isolated group)

      2. By what manner of system did you use to allow such information to be acted upon by the PC's? (Remembering that you as the GM just hand waving the problem away is still System)

      Your example didn't include who did the actual summoning of the Angel, but whoever did it the effect of that summoning was communicated, validated and integrated into the SIS. Setting was changed. Nothing you've described invalidates the notion of the SIS. For the player group that was completely isolated from the Summoning event game session someone communicated that information to them if, as you've said, the players are expressing interest in it.

      What I'm not saying is that the Fact Space/SIS is the everything of role-playing. We have the Social Contract. We have Creative Agenda's. We have our plans about what we want to accomplish during the game. Etc. All these are vital to us engaging in roleplay but until we've starting Exploring (the act of using the Elements of Exploration which includes System - the LBCB Principle) we haven't started play. They are all necessary but as activities they are not sufficient to be regarded as roleplaying. We can all agree to meet at Alice's and all agree to play (pick whatever RPG you want) at 8pm on Tuesday night. But that's not roleplaying. We can agree on the Technique that there is a separation of information between the players and the GM.

      I'm saying the SIS is the arena where roleplaying happens which results in changes to Setting. Pre-game Prep whether taken from a book, made up whole cloth, a mix of both, a map or taken from another game session is still Setting. It should be noted for completeness that there are games that distribute the duties/roles of the GM around the table but again those games have a System that regulates and empowers that activity.

      But to answer your question about table having its own SIS then short answer is yes. To what extent that information is shared amongst your various groups is a matter of the Social Contract. But whatever information that is shared/common to the groups is a matter of Social Contract. As far as the Agency allowed to players to employ such information that is a matter of the LBCB Principle describing what information is allowed to the PCs and what is restricted to the Players only.

      Finally it should be noted that whatever information that is allowed to be shared between groups the players still have to all agree on it as well. For one reason or another a player could contest some aspect of the Setting you've provided which is still under the LBCBP. This may be extremely rare to actually come about but tacit passive approval is still occuring.

      Best,

      Jay
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nThanuir \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 9 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hi Jay,

      I mostly agree with you, and I do not think that discussing that further is fruitful.

      Rather, (in hindsight I believe) I was grasping at the following simple observation: The Forge definition of system and characterization of the process of roleplaying is moment-to-moment, and highly local in time.

      As you correctly write, the definition does not care why we are introducing something into the fiction, it just asks if everyone involved accepts the input. The criterion for acceptance is defined as the system.

      This is also why all the games that have a game master (who has narrative authority over the world) and players (who are restricted to their characters perspective and taking actions through the character) look like pretty much the same game from a Forge lens: The *moment-to-moment* means of accepting input is mostly the same. Maybe people get credibility for their statements by reading dice and character sheets in different ways, but that is surface detail, not fundamental in any way.

      On the other hand, if the player has metagame currencies that influence the character's performance, or if different parts of character performance require rolling dice than "usual", than the Forge definition of system starts seeing differences.

      ----

      Let us take a look at two games, one a no myth game, the other a sandbox/blorb/klokkverk game, but with the traditional player-GM divide and nominally the same rule system in both.

      The big model definition of system sees very little difference; maybe it adds a side clause about the GM prep adding to credibility of the statements in one, or about the GM having to respect their prep.

      Similar phenomenon happens with two otherwise identical games, where one contains an intricate system of character creation and in the other the player or game master simply writes down a bunch of values that seem to fit the character. This has little effect on who can say what and when so that it is accepted into fiction; basically, when introducing a character, it has to have a certain number of points total in one game, but not the other.

      ----

      Suppose we want to, for whatever reason, discuss the intricacies of running a persistent game world, or of having a compelling character optimization in a game.

      As another issue, suppose we are considering a fate token rule for a game - what they are good for and when they are earned.

      In the latter case, the Baker-Care-Boss principle definition of system is quite useful. Does the player have the right to declare their character successful, or that a minor fact is true, or that a major fact is true, or that their relationship appears in the scene, etc.

      In the first case, thinking through the same definition gives far less - questions of realism or balance between options are more relevant.

      ----

      I would be tempted to say that the locality of time of the big model definition explains why almost all Forge games are short-form games, but this is likely a poor explanation.

      ----

      From a sandbox point of view, Apocalypse world and its descendants are the only (probably: "among the few rare"; exceptions likely exist) relevant games with their roots in the Forge, because they pay attention to creating and maintaining the game world via clocks and fronts and what not. Other games just assume you do it.

      Yeah, okay, Dogs in the vineyard mentions revisiting towns, Burning wheel has circles and relationship rules and resources as an attempt at abstracting essentially non-modern economics. Not entirely irrelevant in that way.

      I wonder if anything useful (from sandbox point of view) has come out of the Fate community. Star system generation in Diaspora, maybe.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 9 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n It just bugs me when someone says\n
      1. System is defined by the LBCBP to only cover what we imagine in play
      2. The rules are defined by the LBCBP to be a strict subset of system
      3. Therefore a game can not have rules that cover things outside of what we imagine in play
      That has actually happened in this thread.
      And on the Forge.

      Not that people are interested in the LBCBP or impressed by it, but that they then also conclude that it means that it therefore must be allowable for the DM in any \u201creal roleplaying game\u201d to do unblorby things.

      And I\u2019m like\u2026 this is a kinda tired old clich\xe9 but the whole bumblebee thing? For a brief moment in 1934 there was a calculation that showed that bumblebees couldn\u2019t actually fly because dynamic stall in the oscillation cycle wasn\u2019t wholly understood.

      You can use the six letter string \u201csystem\u201d to mean whatever you want in your game, and you can use the five letter string \u201crules\u201d to mean whatever you want in your game, and, like, that\u2019s fine, don\u2019t mind us, we\u2019re trying to fly over here? This is also why I called it blorb by the way. A new & fresh & wholly alien word untouched by Forge.

      We want to write\u2026 well, if you can\u2019t call them rules, you can call them them \u201cprinciples of prep\u201d or whatever. (We\u2019re gonna just go ahead and call them \u201crules\u201d though.)

      When you\u2019re too in love with the LBCBP, instead of just making an ambush team as a virtual ludeme and making Dremmer\u2019s territory as a virtual ludeme, instead, with their model, you need to script a rule that triggers when we talk about Dremmer\u2019s territory as if it were a ludeme. But it\u2019s not. They\u2019re only pretending to pretend that there\u2019s a territory, instead of doing the more straightforward thing which would be to pretend that there\u2019s a territory. Easier.

      And, like, it\u2019s completely assymmetrical.

      The player still needs to \u201ccreate\u201d their character, \u201ccreate\u201d their chopper gang, \u201ccreate\u201d their hardhold. They need to be \u201cdelusional\u201d and have these things of theirs expressed in ontological terms like \u201ccreated\u201d.

      I.o.w. the player-facing ludemes are still expressed as \u201cinstances\u201d, as \u201cobjects\u201d while the MC-facing ludemes are, in order to not be delusional, expressed as \u201cprocedures\u201d, as \u201cfunctions\u201d.

      Traditional techniques, man!

      That\u2019s why I have zero qualms with a super hippiefied game, because those games don\u2019t have this assymmetry.

      Also, I almost made some \u201cdeludeme\u201d portmanteus about delude and ludeme but it ended up as \u201cdelude me\u201d which wasn\u2019t great.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 9 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Silmenume said:

      I\u2019m saying the SIS is the arena where roleplaying happens which results in changes to Setting. Pre-game Prep whether taken from a book, made up whole cloth, a mix of both, a map or taken from another game session is still Setting.

      So what the new model does is that it has rules that govern how we create/alter the Setting, rules that operate wholly outside of the SIS arena.\n
      Thanuir said:

      I wonder if anything useful (from sandbox point of view) has come out of the Fate community.

      Aspects, as prose sentences that are first class ludemes that exist simultaneously in the dice layer and the cloud layer, has been pretty influential on my sandbox design.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nshimrod \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 9 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      2097 said:

      When you\u2019re too in love with the LBCBP, instead of just making an ambush team as a virtual ludeme and making Dremmer\u2019s territory as a virtual ludeme, instead, with their model, you need to script a rule that triggers when we talk about Dremmer\u2019s territory as if it were a ludeme. But it\u2019s not. They\u2019re only pretending to pretend that there\u2019s a territory, instead of doing the more straightforward thing which would be to pretend that there\u2019s a territory. Easier.

      \nIn practical terms, for some people at least, it's not easier. Making the ambush team and making the territory and making the mechanisms by which they interact with each other and the players' characters to determine if the ambush is successful creates many, many opportunities for mistakes which can end up skewing the situation you wanted to model in the first place: sometimes you get ambushed, sometimes you don't.

      For some people at least, it's easier to just say: sometimes you get ambushed, sometimes you don't.

      That approach does have other disadvantages: for most people it feels less "real" or "solid". But I don't think it's accurate to say it's more difficult.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 9 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n What I meant was more difficult writing a disciplined LBCBP game, such as the MC half of AW. Translating the experience of a traditional game into a "The SIS is the central operand" mode required a pretty deep understanding of the theory. I mean, I sure as heckfire didn't understand this stuff to that level back in 2010 before AW came out. (Still a couple of years before "mirror story".)

      And even then you can see spots here and there where there are cracks in the discipline.

      This is going to get nerdy but in programming terms,
      AW is the Haskell of games. No sideeffects allowed so we have to jump through some hoops (monads) to create some of the same feel.
      2097e is more of a Lisp. Meta-aware, sure, but a multidiscipline, inelegant, wonderful ball of mud.
      \n

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n

      \n\nJune 10 \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n It seems to me that the topic has now shifted somewhat to, "Hey, let's think of some interesting ways to improve klockwerk play", which I love and think could be very fruitful.

      I feel that the discussion of the Lumpley Principle is just distracting us from that good stuff; it seems entirely unrelated, from where I'm sitting.

      I'd recommend removing that from this discussion, if that's the goal (and I hope it is!).

      Otherwise, I'm not sure how to interact with this conversation at all. (For example, those "two analyses of Finchian trap-finding" were both severely misguided, in my view, either misrepresenting roleplaying as an activity or conflating motives with tools, respectively. That makes it hard for me to continue the conversation, other than to state my disagreement and attempt to change the subject. You seem to be conflating the idea of "No Myth", Narrativism, story-telling, Forge-style design, the differences between sandbox play and improvised collaborative gaming, and the Lumpley Principle all into one big soup. If you want to pursue this further, please tell me how you'd like to proceed!)

      I'm very curious how you would parse my example in the other thread from a mental model of roleplaying which includes a "game state" (or whatever we want to call it). How does one analyze that kind of sequence of events, from that perspective?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nSilmenume \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 10 \n edited June 10
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hi Sandra,\n
      2097 said:

      It just bugs me when someone says

      1. System is defined by the LBCBP to only cover what we imagine in play
      2. The rules are defined by the LBCBP to be a strict subset of system
      3. Therefore a game can not have rules that cover things outside of what we imagine in play
      That has actually happened in this thread.
      And on the Forge.
      \nThe logic here doesn't hold up as Rules and System were never defined to be the same. From the Provisional Glossary -\n
      Rules:

      Textual instruction about (a) anything and everything concerning role-playing this particular game, or (b) specifically Techniques and Ephemera. Used in this sense, Rules are distinct from the System actually employed during play, although it may be used as a reference or justification for it.
      \nSo, no, the Forge never said that, "A game can not have rules that cover things outside of what we imagine in play."

      The process of creating a character typically has Rules about the activity. Dogs in the Vineyard has Rules detailing how to create the town. Rules about under what circumstances to roll a random encounter fall into this camp. Typically there are Rules about how to go about leveling up a character. Polaris (by Ben Lehman) had Rules about who had control over the protagonist, the villain, the spurned lover, the angry authority figure and when those roles changed.

      The short of it is lots of games (all?) have Rules about how to play the game that don't directly deal with the SIS.

      Best,

      Jay

      Crossposted with Paul.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\n2097 \n\n\n

      \n\nJune 10 \n
      \n

      \n
      \n I\u2019ll get into that dragon post shortly.

      First of all, about me falling out of love with AW\u2026

      I also want to add something (that I already wrote in an email to Paul today but I think it\u2019s appropriate for here, too) that:

      AW is a masterpiece of IIEE. It seems to me that it came straight out of Vincent\u2019s groundbreaking work on IIEE with the dice & cloud series, which is a series that I absolutely love and has been thoroughly influenced by.

      If I want to solve an IIEE issue I have no qualms turning to AW.

      My issue with AW is only on the, uh, let\u2019s call it data structure layer instead of \u201contological\u201d layer.

      About this thread\u2026

      I\u2019m glad that the other thread has a very strict \u201cproductive-only\u201d focus. This thread though has been about all kinds of things, and one of those things is a couple of lingering questions about this theory stuff.\n
      Paul_T said:

      For example, those \u201ctwo analyses of Finchian trap-finding\u201d were both severely misguided, in my view, either misrepresenting roleplaying as an activity or conflating motives with tools, respectively.

      Paul, throughout this thread you\u2019ve been doing this. \u201cThis is severely misguided\u201d, \u201cthis is wrong\u201d, \u201chere I disagree\u201d, \u201cthis is deluded\u201d\u2026 Care to elaborate?

      I made the formatting of the posts easier to quote just for that purpose, so if there are several fundamental issues with my analyses (I\u2019m sure there are plenty nitpicks of minor errors, I can be pretty sloppy), I\u2019d love to know what they are, or given the opportunity to respond in detail.

      Otherwise, I always feel like everything I write on here just becomes discarded (whereas in email you\u2019re being very thorough which is very much appreciated).

      This seems like a very strong mental lock for you. \u201cOur model has been so thoroughly hashed out, it was so painful hashing that stuff out, it improved my gaming so much, it can\u2019t be wrong\u201d. I\u2019m not disagreeing with the second or third of those four thoughts. I\u2019m not about to make gaming worse or forbid all non-blorby play. For example, your own \xc9owyn game has hippiefied mechanics rather than traditional, so is already not a problem.\n
      Paul_T said:

      either misrepresenting roleplaying as an activity

      (I take it this one is for the blorby analysis.)

      In blorby play, interacting with our primary-level data-structure, the canon, the mutual (not necessarily \u201csense-four-shared\u201d) imagined space (The MIS! A superset of the SIS!) is the fundamental operation.

      Talking is incidental;
      sometimes as a result of operating on the MIS,
      more often as a way of communicating changes to the MIS (\u201cI go through the door\u201d) or information about the MIS (\u201cthere are three trolls there\u201d)

      If this is a radically different model than your model of what \u201croleplaying as an activity\u201d is, then, well, that is noteworthy, wouldn\u2019t you say? If it\u2019s not, and you guys should know better than me if it is or isn\u2019t, then what\u2019s the problem?

      Speaking of \u201croleplaying as an activity\u201d\u2026 when you\u2019re a kid and you play a game such as \u201cI\u2019m a ghost\u201d or \u201cthe floor is lava\u201d or \u201cthis doll is my baby, Susan\u201d,

      step one is that you pretend that it is so,
      step two is that you make actions and statements as if it were so,
      to the extent that they aren\u2019t overridden by very practical limitations (such as not actually trying to walk through a wall when you pretend you\u2019re a ghost, and not actually try to swim when you pretend the bed is a pirate ship and you are \u201cswimming\u201d (walking on the floor but making swimming motions with arms) to \u201crescue Susan\u201d (fetch doll).

      While there\u2019s a bit of an overlap, this is fundamentally different from \u201cyarn-spinning\u201d as an activity, where you add statements to a story, incorporating or embellishing or correcting previously added statements to said story.

      Either your model recognizes that, in which case fine, please clearly acknowledge that, or it doesn\u2019t, in which case: let\u2019s dig into it! I\u2019m convincable but I need to hear arguments!\n
      Paul_T said:

      or conflating motives with tools, respectively

      I did portray both motives and tools but I thought I was pretty clear about which was which [and sometimes a tool can be a motive and sometimes a motive can be a tool] so what\u2019s this in reference to?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 10 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Silmenume said:

      The logic here doesn\u2019t hold up as Rules and System were never defined to be the same. From the Provisional Glossary -

      Silmenume said:

      Rules:

      Textual instruction about (a) anything and everything concerning role-playing this particular game, or (b) specifically Techniques and Ephemera. Used in this sense, Rules are distinct from the System actually employed during play, although it may be used as a reference or justification for it.

      So, no, the Forge never said that, \u201cA game can not have rules that cover things outside of what we imagine in play.\u201d
      This is fine, this is good, this is well, this is sweet, this is on the same page as me; and that means that obviously that Lumpley principle web page on the Big model wiki is in need of correction. Here is an attempt at a fix to make it inline with what you\u2019re saying now, Jay:\n
      Big model web page said:

      You can point to the pages of your book all you want to. You can imagine stuff in your head all you want to.

      The fact is that nothing happens, in the fiction of role-playing, unless someone says it and it\u2019s heard by others. Even if the book says, \u201cOn a critical hit, you do double damage,\u201d your character won\u2019t actually do double damage on a critical hit unless someone recognizes it and says it.

      Role-playing is made of talking like apple pie is made of apples and crust and scary amounts of butter. Whatever mechanics you use, you are agreeing to use them among the group, usually as a creative inspiration or constraint, specifically as a way to affect what is going to be said.      [Instead: \u201cWe use the word \u2018fiction\u2019 refer to things about the setting that have been said out loud and heard by at least one person.\u201d]

      \u201cSystem (including but not limited to \u2018the rules\u2019) is defined as the means by which the group agrees to imagined events during play.\u201d [and add \u201cthere are rules that cover other aspects of the activity too.\u201d ]

      (Not actually proposing this, just that one way I can get it to square with that broader definition for rules that you posted. The other way to make their statement coherent is interpreting it as them still have the narrow definition of rules except that those rules govern ephemera that are, in turn, interacting with \u201cthe fiction\u201d/SIS and the rules, narrowly defined, can not ever ever ever govern something that is wholly off-screen. In which case (but only in that case), no, we do have rules beyond that, so principle falsified.)

      To me, that would make the words \u201cfiction\u201d and \u201csystem\u201d unusably narrow but that\u2019s fine, I don\u2019t mind. I usually don\u2019t use those terms anyway (except polysemically, as in \u201cI have a new system to create dungeons while prepping\u201d or \u201cI wrote this awesome fan fiction about your character.\u201d). You can have \u201cthe fiction\u201d/SIS and we\u2019ll grab \u201cthe canon\u201d/MIS.\n
      Silmenume said:

      The process of creating a character typically has Rules about the activity. Dogs in the Vineyard has Rules detailing how to create the town. Rules about under what circumstances to roll a random encounter fall into this camp. Typically there are Rules about how to go about leveling up a character. Polaris (by Ben Lehman) had Rules about who had control over the protagonist, the villain, the spurned lover, the angry authority figure and when those roles changed.

      The short of it is lots of games (all?) have Rules about how to play the game that don\u2019t directly deal with the SIS.

      Fantastic!

      Which is what I\u2019ve been trying to say!

      However you wrote this earlier:\n
      Silmenume said:

      Let us not forget that ALL of this is, at base, a very ritualized form of conversation between real human beings.
      [\u2026and much later\u2026]
      The thesis that you\u2019re promoting about these \u201coff-screen\u201d actions that have been fully documented prior to play but not in any way (yet) been communicated, validated and integrated into the \u201cfact space\u201d/SIS/text has the same the same weight and validity is what is controversial. It is the \u201ccreating a language in a closet\u201d is not the same as communicating issue.

      Well, since we now have created Rules that govern off-screen actions there should be no more need for controversy and the \u201ccloset language theorem\u201d can be retired, since referents can be constructed (via Rules) prior to talking about them.

      (Obviously, the talking about them is also Signs i.e. signifiers are being constructed during The Conversation, but that\u2019s not the only way those referents are being constructed, which is what Chris was wrong about. (Otherwise programmers wouldn\u2019t need to implement reference counters for memory management. (References to referents.)))

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 10 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Sandra,

      First of all, thank you for making your posts so much easier to quote! That's really lovely, and very helpful.

      Second, it looks like I should explain where I'm coming from a little more clearly. Let me try to do that!\n
      2097 said:

      I\u2019ll get into that dragon post shortly.

      \nI think the issue of the green dragon in my example is directly relevant to this topic, so I look forward to your description of that kind of play event. (Edit: looks like you've done so in the other thread. Should I address it in full there?)\n
      2097 said:

      First of all, about me falling out of love with AW\u2026

      [...]

      AW is a masterpiece of IIEE. It seems to me that it came straight out of Vincent\u2019s groundbreaking work on IIEE with the dice & cloud series, which is a series that I absolutely love and has been thoroughly influenced by.

      [...]

      My issue with AW is only on the, uh, let\u2019s call it data structure layer instead of \u201contological\u201d layer.

      \nSo, first of all, the clarity which AW has in regards to issues like IIEE (which is the type of thing that you can really ONLY consider from the standpoint of the Lumpley Principle; it was basically absent prior to that understanding) is exactly what I meant by the text being more "self-aware". It's not necessarily a net positive, but from a designer's standpoint it's really handy, and it arguably does a better job of teaching people how to play.

      Now, what is your issue with the "data structure layer"? It seems to me that AW is not a "full blorb" game, nor does it try to be. So, if that's your qualm with it, I don't think anyone will argue that you're wrong. (Well, actually, lots of people will. But I won't! I think you're right on.)

      Or do you think there's something fundamentally, philosophically wrong with the way the game is put together? That would be a much stronger, and more controversial/interesting claim.\n
      2097 said:

      Paul, throughout this thread you\u2019ve been doing this. \u201cThis is severely misguided\u201d, \u201cthis is wrong\u201d, \u201chere I disagree\u201d, \u201cthis is deluded\u201d\u2026 Care to elaborate?

      I made the formatting of the posts easier to quote just for that purpose, so if there are several fundamental issues with my analyses (I\u2019m sure there are plenty nitpicks of minor errors, I can be pretty sloppy), I\u2019d love to know what they are, or given the opportunity to respond in detail.

      \nYeah, so what is Paul's problem here?

      I've been trying to figure out how to engage with all these conversations, because I think you're often finding yourself in the position of feeling assaulted from all sides. And that's unfortunate - after all, I feel we're all friends here, and, as far as I can see, no one's deliberately trying to put anyone down. I don't want you to feel "set upon", as by a pack of hungry wolves.

      However, here's my problem:

      * I love what you're doing from a design perspective, and I love exploring and finding new "blorb/klockwerk" tools, because they can really improve a certain style of gaming. So I want to engage with that and support it and offer my own ideas. It's some great stuff, and it's what's got me coming back to Story Games every day lately. Wonderful!

      * However, I either don't follow or strongly disagree with your theoretical thoughts on the matter. Sometimes it feels like you're trying to redefine the way we look at RPG play in order to legitimize your favoured playstyle.

      This is tricky, because, on one hand, that doesn't mean I can't engage with the practical stuff (e.g. designing random encounter tables). On the other hand, there's a danger of getting mired into a whole semantic swamp and missing out on cool techniques. However, I also like theoretical thinking about RPGs, and I like challenging existing ideas and coming up with new models because they can give us new avenues for design and play.

      So, what to do?

      If I ignore the theory stuff, you feel like your points are being ignored and overlooked (fair!). If I engage with it and critique what I see as its weak points, then I sound obstinate and I make you feel like you're on the defensive.

      So, I choose to take a middle ground by pointing out that I don't agree with the theory, and to preferentially engage with the more practical topics.

      It sounds like you'd really like me to challenge the theory, though, and address that. I'm happy to do so; in exchange, I'll ask you to give me the benefit of the doubt and not to assume that I'm being close-minded or mean-spirited. I very much see this as a friendly and interesting dialogue!
      \n
      2097 said:


      In blorby play, interacting with our primary-level data-structure, the canon, the mutual (not necessarily \u201csense-four-shared\u201d) imagined space (The MIS! A superset of the SIS!) is the fundamental operation.

      Talking is incidental;
      sometimes as a result of operating on the MIS,
      more often as a way of communicating changes to the MIS (\u201cI go through the door\u201d) or information about the MIS (\u201cthere are three trolls there\u201d)

      \nOk. I really like this; I think it's the clearest restatement you've made so far of what you're reaching for with this whole "gamestate" idea.

      Perhaps the analogy is one of a board game, which has defined positions and moves, and we talk only to communicate our moves to each other.

      I'd initially thought that no change of the Situation (in Forge terms) can happen without talking, but perhaps you are right that sometimes such change happens with very little overt communication. (e.g. I can cross off a potion on my character sheet and increment my HP, and we all know that, in the SIS, my character drank a potion.)

      The question, then, becomes whether this somehow violates the idea of the Lumpley Principle. I'd always understood it as being entirely in line with it: the original text of the Principle doesn't say anything about talking, and it seems silly to pretend that things like illustrations, maps, miming a sword swing, taking on the body position/posture of a character I'm playing, and so forth don't affect what we're imagining.

      I can see, though, that the Wiki you're quoting says that "nothing happens, in the fiction of role-playing, unless someone says it and it's heard by others". I would have thought this was just sloppy writing (after all, 99% of the time we DO say these things out loud), but I can see how - if you took it literally - you'd think it was bogus.

      However, I think the original text of Principle - how we agree to imagined events during play - is fairly self-evident. Can you think of any counterexamples?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 10 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      2097 said:


      If this is a radically different model than your model of what \u201croleplaying as an activity\u201d is, then, well, that is noteworthy, wouldn\u2019t you say?

      \nIndeed! This is why some of us are reacting the way we are. It's an extremely noteworthy and bold claim!

      It might qualify as a really interesting claim, if not for the perception (and I'll keep my mind open about whether this is fair or not) that this is just the "old" way of looking at gaming.

      Before the Forge days, there was a pretty dominant perception that RPGs didn't really work like other games. Instead, we had an imaginary reality, a virtual world, and the "game rules were the physics of that world". I remember this being fairly doctrinal in the 90's, at least. Pretty much everyone I knew who played RPGs spoke of the process in this way.

      For instance, the rule for an attack roll was engaged when a fictional entity made a physical attack against another entity, and the outcome determined the fictional/diegetic outcome (the target was hit, let's say). This kind of rule is written with no concern for the actual, real-table activity in which it's taking place; it presumes the "reality" of the diegesis/game world as a given.

      What it led to was a real stagnation in RPG design and all kinds of evolutionary dead-ends. (Like I said earlier, it's pretty hard to design something with the clarity of AW's IIEE when looking at gaming from this lens.)

      So, the idea was that the Lumpley Principle was a broader understanding, breaking us free of that kind of limited thinking.

      Now you're trying to bring on board something that sounds suspiciously like that old-time kind of thinking about RPGs. Do you feel that your "game state" theory/concept is meaningfully distinct from that kind of pre-Forgean view of RPG play? If so, how so? \n
      2097 said:


      While there\u2019s a bit of an overlap, this is fundamentally different from \u201cyarn-spinning\u201d as an activity, where you add statements to a story, incorporating or embellishing or correcting previously added statements to said story.

      \nSo, this is the rather bold and interesting claim: that there is a fundamental difference between RPG play or "make believe" and collaborative storytelling.

      I can see some rationale for that! Certainly, a game where I am strictly limited to actor stance (e.g. many/most of the trad RPG tradition) and a game where we get to make stuff up together *feel* quite different.

      But, off the top of my head, I can think of a dozen examples of corner cases that defy categorization, hybrid forms, and so forth. So I'd have to hear WHY you feel these are fundamentally different, and then how you can think of any kind of hybrid game (which most RPGs are, at root) within a framework where those two things are fundamentally different activities. How do you explain something like AW or Sorcerer or The Pool from that point of view?\n
      2097 said:

      Paul_T said:

      or conflating motives with tools, respectively

      I did portray both motives and tools but I thought I was pretty clear about which was which [and sometimes a tool can be a motive and sometimes a motive can be a tool] so what\u2019s this in reference to?
      \nSure! I'll come back to this in another post.


      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 10 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Paul_T said:


      2097 said:

      Paul_T said:

      or conflating motives with tools, respectively

      I did portray both motives and tools but I thought I was pretty clear about which was which [and sometimes a tool can be a motive and sometimes a motive can be a tool] so what\u2019s this in reference to?
      \nSure! I'll come back to this in another post.
      \nI'm running out of time, so I'll make this short (feel free to ask questions).

      In short, your analysis part one (from a blorby perspective), I feel, omits some pretty important details, by pretending to ignore the real people playing and their interactions.

      It describes what's happening pretty well, but the references to a "game state", even though it often doesn't exist outside of the utterances of the players (e.g. those cracks in the floor simply did not exist in any sense until the player asked about them), have to be supported. I also think that, aside from the mentions of the 'game state', it's a perfectly accurate and 100% Lumpley Principle-compatible analysis of what's happening there.

      However, then you move to what you and Jay are calling the "transactional model" and suddenly you are conflating the means of play (we talk) with the motives (we're trying to tell a story).

      For example:

      "John wants to use narration to portray a canny and cautious young man so he adds a statement to the fiction that implies that he is attempting to examine the floor."

      This is complete straw doll, in my opinion. You've somehow decided (perhaps because of that line on the wiki page!) that accepting the Lumpley Principle means that all roleplay is a structured narrative that we consciously construct.

      I don't know why - either it's that one line in the wiki, or your idea that Forge theory means we can't have rules about things other than what we say (which is downright silly - obviously we can make rules like "at 30 minutes past the hours, change seats with your partner"), or your recent interest in separating "full blorb" from "freeform storytelling" games, even though thousands of hybrid games exist and are played every day.

      But, coming back to your "transactional model" analysis of finchian trap-finding, that is not true at all. The "John" in the example is doing no such thing. There's no "story being told" - we're exploring an imaginary space which it is the GM's responsibility to describe as accurately and consistently as she can. John's describing his character's actions to the GM, which is the way the group has agreed to "imagined events during play": his role is to describe his character's actions, and he's doing so because he wants to avoid his character getting stuck in a trap (a likely hint that this might be a Gamist kind of venture, or at least one where John's responsibility is to advocate for his character's survival and success).

      Sure, we could make a game where that's not the case - something like Donjon, perhaps - but that would be a different game.

      In short, you've created a (nearly) accurate analysis and said that it conforms to your model, and then a rather caricatured and strange analysis where for some reason two people playing D&D are trying to "tell a story" as their primary motive and don't seem to understand how Finchian trap-finding even works, and are trying to say that this analysis discredits the Lumpley Principle.

      One thing I would be very interested to see, which I keep coming back to, is how the "game state" model can explain uncorrected errors in play. Like my example where the GM reads "green dragon" instead of "green goblin", but *never realizes the mistake*. Let's say you and I play a D&D campaign, and such an error occurs. (And never mind that such errors, large or small, intentional or unintentional, happen all the time!) Is it really your position that it means something, years later, to say, "Sandra and Paul played D&D back in 2019, but we, scientists looking back at them, now in the year 2097* can say that their memory of the game is incorrect; in fact, the 'game state' they were interacting with had a green goblin, not a dragon, and they just repeatedly made error after error, including descriptions, character decisions, numbers of hit points, and so on. The REAL game they played had a green goblin, not a green dragon; they're just misremembering."

      How can the "game state" model account for the persistence of such errors? Or even non-errors like those cracks in the floor or the identity of the green dragon (as having been rescued by the PC's father, in my example)?

      I hope that helps rather than aggravates. I am happy to drop this entire debate, if you prefer!


      *: Just for fun! It will be a good year.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 10 \n edited June 10
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Paul_T said:

      Before the Forge days, there was a pretty dominant perception that RPGs didn't really work like other games. Instead, we had an imaginary reality, a virtual world, and the "game rules were the physics of that world".

      \nWait, wait, wait!

      Some imaginary reality, some virtual world, is NOT at all what I mean when I write "game state".

      The game state is a logical structure.

      It constrains imagined events. It is not identical to the imagined events. It is not a virtual world where those events take place.

      We're playing D&D 5e. My guy, Alice, has 0 hit points. (That's part of the game state.) This applies a constraint that, in imagined events, Alice is incapacitated.

      If I share this portion of the game state, saying "Crap I'm at 0", this makes manifest to all present that, in the diegesis, Alice is incapacitated.

      It restricts me, preventing me from saying, "Alice gets up and stabs the orc." Because contributions to imagined events that contradict the constraints of the game state are invalid.

      Do we agree that this is a totally, completely different thing from saying "There's an imaginary reality, a virtual world, and the game rules are the physics of that world"?

      I'll also note that Sandra and I are totally not on the same page re: game state and the LBCB Principle. I think the principle works as originally stated: "System (including but not limited to 'the rules') is defined as the means by which the group agrees to imagined events during play." So written, the LBCB Principle is 100% compatible with the idea of game state; the game stat's constraints on imagined events are just a means by which we agree to those imagined events.

      I also think that the entire Big Model Wiki entry on the LBCB Principle is crap. It is NOT the principle itself; it is rather bad commentary on the thing, and totally fails to state the thing itself.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 10 \n edited June 10
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nAgreed with you 100% on the "small print" stuff at the bottom of your post. I really hope the sloppy wording of that wiki page isn't the thing responsible for this whole debate.

      Also: wow, look at this tiny font thing Sandra started finally catching on! Just as S-G is shutting down, too...

      I don't think I understand the distinction you're trying to make. Are you just saying that the game state includes things outside of the imagined reality (so, being at 0 HP doesn't *just* mean that Alice is incapacitated, it also means that I, Paul, can't say that she attacks anyone)?

      I don't have an issue with that, and I don't really see how it changes anything. (And I'm obviously not about to defend the whole "game rules as the physics of the game world" thing; it's wrong on so many levels, and the way rules reach beyond the SIS is an important part of that.)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nSilmenume \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 10 \n edited June 12
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hello,

      WRT to the Wiki definition of the LBCB Principle Jeff has the right of it. It is garbage and the way it was discussed on site did not think of the principle in that way. It was discussed and treated in the way Jeff quoted from the Provisional Glossary.

      FREX - just recently in a game session I posted about a PC being bit by a vampire, trapped under rubble and dug about by another PC. Near the end of the digging out, where the bitten PC (played by Dax) was being pulled out the Player of the PC doing the rescuing (played by Blake) rolled three 1's in about 5 rolls. The Player of the rescued PC then rolled two 1's back to back. At this point the GM looked at Dax and all he did was raise his eyebrows in question. Dax in return just dipped his chin in the smallest of nods.

      It was perfectly clear what was being asked and answered to both the GM and Dax. Since you rolled two 1's and Blake rolled so many ones are you going to have your character (Silitare) bite Tomas (Blake's character)? The tiny head nod was a "Yes" and Tomas' current state and future were radically changed.

      The LBCB Principle in action using no words.

      Best,

      Jay
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    \n

    Narrativism vs traditional techniques

    \n
    \xab1\u2026891011121314\xbb

    Comments

      \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 10 \n edited June 10
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I'm saying something a bit stronger than "the game state includes things outside of the imagined reality."

      In fact, there's absolutely nothing that appears in both the imagined reality and in the game state! They operate on different types of symbols.

      Diegetically, we have a character named Alice. She's a tall warrior who carries a spear and loves candied lemon peel!

      In the game state, we have a an entity or token, let us call it `ALICE. The game state includes propositions about `ALICE, like:

      (HITPOINTS `ALICE 0)
      (EXHAUSTIONLEVELS `ALICE 1)
      (SPEED `ALICE 30)
      (AC `ALICE 16)
      (ATTACKBONUS `ALICE +6)

      And stuff like that.

      `ALICE is not the imagined character Alice.

      However, under our agreed-upon system, there is a causal relationship between the game state token `ALICE and the imagined character Alice. Game state propositions concerning `ALICE constrain imagined events with regards to the character Alice.

      ...

      If we wanted to, we could play a game with no gamestate at all, but the exact same imagined events.

      Or a game with the exact same imagined events, and a gamestate which includes no token `ALICE. (For instance, The Pool, which has one token for each player, one binary predicate, SIZE_OF_POOL, which takes as arguments a player token and a nonnegative integer; and nothing else. The Pool was a shitty example, since pool size doesn't directly constrain game state. Consider a hypothetical game with one element of game state, a predicate DANGER_LEVEL that can take a boolean argument of True or False; when True, the GM is allowed to harm player characters in the fiction; when False, not.)

      Things that are in the diegesis, imagined events, do not necessarily have any correspondence with anything in the game state. The game state is not "imagined events plus some other stuff." It's not even "A portion of imagined events, plus maybe other stuff."

      It's a set of propositions: predicates which operate on tokens, logical primitives like numbers and booleans, and other propositions.

      The system, in the LBCB Principle sense, includes ways in which this set of propositions constrain what counts as a valid contribution to imagined events. And the system contains ways that we are allowed to, or obligated to, observe and share and mutate the game state.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 10 \n edited June 10
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n In one game, you've written in your prep, "100 GP are in the vestibule." This causes the game state to include:

      (CONTAINS `VESTIBULE (GP 100))

      Which, combined with our system, creates obligations for the GM regarding information they must share when the players' characters observe the imagined location which corresponds to the game state token `VESTIBULE.

      ...

      In a another game, you've written in your prep, "100 GP are in the vestibule." No game state is created. No obligations are created. When the players' characters walk into the vestibule, maybe you'll say, "You see a hundred pieces of gold!" Or maybe you won't. No biggie! Both are valid. The notes in your prep, they were just ideas to get you going!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 10 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n It seems to me that seeing game rules as being a sort of "underlying code" of a video game is pretty much the same thing as seeing the rules as "the physics of the game world". (Allowing, of course, for the understanding that they are loose metaphors in the first place.)

      Or is there some important distinction being made here which wouldn't be covered by "in this game, we treat the GM's prep is inviolable, but in this other game, the GM is free to change stuff whenever"?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nSilmenume \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 10 \n edited June 11
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hi Jeph,\n
      Jeph said:

      In fact, there's absolutely nothing that appears in both the imagined reality and in the game state! They operate on different types of symbols.

      \nI'd have to give this a good hard think before I say I agree with you unequivocally, but I'm very inclined to agree with you. Point in fact a lot of early (I don't know the current state) Narrativist game design capitalized on this very idea. There is nothing particularly controversial about your formulation which was nicely stated.

      That these two layers, GameState and SIS, function using a completely different set of (ugh) symbols and operate at different levels of the abstract and the concrete is still not particularly controversial. You might want to consider such things as Creative Agenda priorities and what not in the GameState. It is an important part of play.

      However they do constantly communicate with one another and are constrained by each other. Nor does this GameState need to be physical.

      My question to you is would you consider the bidding system of Dogs in The Vineyard to be functioning at the level of GameState? Do you perhaps consider the following from Universalis to be functioning at the GameState level?\n
      Coins are the measure of story power in Universalis. By spending coins, players can create Facts in the game. These may be about characters, the setting, or the scene being played. Each player begins with a number of coins (typically 25), and gains more after each scene plays out (typically 5). Players may also gain coins by winning Complications
      \nIf you do then I'm not seeing anything new. If I'm wrong, if you're willing, could you offer an example from DitV of a GameState? I ask about Dogs because I'm loosely familiar with it having never played Universalis.

      Best,

      Jay
      \n
      \n

      \n I also wonder if Sandra agrees with your interpretation - my sense is that her "game state" was fairly analogous to (though not exactly the same as) the SIS. I'll be curious to hear what she has to say; as far as I remember, no one's really defined the term yet, anyway.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Paul_T said:

      "underlying code" of a video game

      \nHooo boy, we are not on the same page at all.

      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Uh oh!

      You'll have to clarify, then. That's what I got from this:\n
      Jeph said:


      It's a set of propositions: predicates which operate on tokens, logical primitives like numbers and booleans, and other propositions.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAsIf \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n That's beautiful.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n edited June 11
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nWhat's beautiful, @AsIf ?

      @Silmenume , each player's coin count is part of the game state. But not a part of the game state that has any kind of interesting relationship to imagined events, since it works at a purely meta level. The rule that you can spend coins to state facts isn't part of state; any more than the rule that rooks move orthogonally and bishops move diagonally is part of the state of a game of chess. I don't have DitV, so I can't really comment on its details!

      Ah, Paul, I understand the confusion!

      That's really not what computer programs are like at all.

      Programs are sequences of instructions, or actions. The game state is composed of propositions, or logical statements or descriptions.

      Programs are executed; when executed, they act, manipulating a memory tape. The game state cannot do anything, merely be observed, talked about, and acted upon.

      You might compare the game state to the memory tape that a program reads from and writes to. It's an extremely misleading analogy, the surface similarities will only confuse things. Primarily, there is nothing that relates to the game state in the way that a program relates to a memory tape.

      And, there is nothing that relates to a memory tape in the way that imagined events relate to the game state.

      Torturing the analogy to fix those misalignments is probably not a productive avenue.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Ah, yes, I see what you mean. The System is our means of acting upon and changing both the imagined reality and the "game state", either of which doesn't do anything on its own.

      Perhaps the board of a boardgame and its pieces might be a more suitable analogy, then. (Especially a boardgame that involves way to store information, like decks of cards, tokens used to track resources, and so forth.)

      In that case, I see what you mean, although I don't think it's that different from my earlier "physics of the game world" analogy. It's not the laws of physics, maybe, but relevant values, like the mass of each object in the physics-analogy, its position and momentum, its density, and so forth. (In that analogy, the game state is the recorded values for such quantities, and the System is the flow of time. But it gets weird, because I think things like "the guards step outside at midnight each night" are closer to being values in the game state than elements of System.)

      It's probably best to get away from twisted analogies, though, and talk about more practical matters: what does this mean for design, and how does it get us to new ideas or structures?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well yeah duh a boardgame and its pieces are the better analogy, that's why I've been talking about invisible chess for a week. To get people used to the idea that elfgames can have state in the same way that boardgames have state.

      Here's a reason I don't like the "physical qualities of an imaginary world" analogy: the game state IS NOT an imaginary world, and the analogy makes it reaaaaaalllly easy to mistake surface similarity for structural alignment in a murky, confusing way. Best avoid.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAsIf \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Jeph said:

      What's beautiful, @AsIf ?

      \nSorry, shoulda refreshed that page before posting. I was referring to @Silmenume 's wordless vampire story. Elegance in action.

      \n
