      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nThanuir \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Jeph, suppose I am playing game which does not have formal rules for someone having fallen down or being prone. My character falls down. Is the statement indicating that my character is prone a part of the gamestate, as you see it?

      (I am guessing yes, but I want to verify.)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n That\u2019s a good question.

      Or does the answer, maybe, depend on that fact\u2019s salience with regards to the game state? (For example, if falling prone affects what game actions your character can take or turns into attack penalties.)

      Depending on the answer to that, this concept may have some serious limitations when it comes to more loose-knit systems (like the GM translating fictional position into advantage/disadvantage in D&D).
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n edited June 11
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Very much no, actually.

      The game state is not a symbolic representation of imagined events + some other stuff.

      Say we're playing chess, and imagining it as a battle at the same time. My knight takes your queen. I say, "My knight knocks your queen off of her feet!"

      We've got shared imagined events, here, right? I'm imagining it right now. You are too! Your queen is lying on the ground in the muck!

      But the gamestate is exactly the positions of the chess pieces on the game board. It does not include (PRONE `THANUIRS_QUEEN).

      ...

      The gamestate can have any logical structure you want.

      It's exactly those propositions required to enact the rules.

      Portions of it can pretty much mirror imagined events. That doesn't mean imagined events are always mirrored in game state.

      In D&D5e, we have rules about opportunity attacks that require us to track whether characters are next to each other. That means that (ADJACENT `ALICE `BOB) is part of the game state. In The Pool, we don't, so it's not part of the game state.

      The fact that (ADJACENT `ALICE `BOB) is part of the game state probably requires the GM to communicate that fact, per our system. But note that it's not the same thing as the GM having said "Bob is engaged in melee with Alice" and you and me each imagining Alice and Bob next to each other, fighting. It's not the same thing as the characters Alice and Bob being next to each other in imagined events, in the shared imagined space.

      Any more than my Queen being at E6 and your Rook being at E5 is the same thing as us looking at the chess board and imagining my Queen and your Rook next to each other, fighting. Those are the positions, whether we look at the board or not, whether we imagine them fighting or not.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nThanuir \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Earlier you wrote that "CONTAINS `VESTIBULE (GP 100)" is in the game state. How is it different from a character being prone?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nThanuir \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Paul_T said:


      * However, I either don't follow or strongly disagree with your theoretical thoughts on the matter. Sometimes it feels like you're trying to redefine the way we look at RPG play in order to legitimize your favoured playstyle.

      \nNote that this is what was done at the Forge.

      See also Dogma 99 and Turku school manifestos.

      Nothing wrong with finding a new way of looking at roleplaying to legitimize a style of play. It is of course somewhat impolite to claim that the new way is superior to older ones (if one does that), rather than simply different, but this is a matter of presentation, not content, and the responses seem to be similar regardless.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n Hey, at least she isn't trying to deconstruct the word "railroading."
      I tried once. Shoulda seen that shitstorm. :-)

      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n edited June 12
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Wow, there are twenty new posts in my favorite thread!

      I\u2019m gonna address Jeph first using our special nerd lingo and then I\u2019ll get into your points, Paul and Jay, OK?

      I\u2019m gonna start off by clarifying my own take on the \u201cis the game state wholly symbolic vs a virtual world\u201d thing. Now, I really don\u2019t want to create a rift between myself and Jeph because wherever he is going \u201c[Next]\u201d I\u2019m gonna go too, I think! I need someone who groks lisp on the other side\u2026 \n
      Jeph said:

      It constrains imagined events. It is not identical to the imagined events. It is not a virtual world where those events take place.

      Right; it\u2019s the data-structure that in turn constructs the virtual world.

      Like how in the Deleuze sense, the window on the computer screen is virtual, there\u2019s a middle layer of coordinate arrays and graphics routines, and down on the metal it\u2019s all magnets and electricity.\n
      Jeph said:

      Well yeah duh a boardgame and its pieces are the better analogy, that\u2019s why I\u2019ve been talking about invisible chess for a week. To get people used to the idea that elfgames can have state in the same way that boardgames have state.

      Here\u2019s a reason I don\u2019t like the \u201cphysical qualities of an imaginary world\u201d analogy: the game state IS NOT an imaginary world, and the analogy makes it reaaaaaalllly easy to mistake surface similarity for structural alignment in a murky, confusing way. Best avoid.

      I disagree; the benefits of the analogy are much too great to give up. Here\u2019s why:

      I think the view of our diegesis as a \u201cworld\u201d, having it expressed \u201cin natural language\u201d (or even imagined, fully realized 3d places and people) rather than sexps (symbolic expressions) is sometimes a great tool for us humans to use when remembering parts the game state because of how any aspect of established wallpaper (whether improvised wallpaper, or gloracularly produced wallpaper) can become salient. (Obviously salient elements have an unambigous sexp representation.)

      As ambitious as some sexp representations are:\n
      Norvig PAIP p 131 said:

      (gps '(son-at-home car-needs-battery have-money have-phone-book) ' (son-at-school))

      You run into the \u201clack of descriptive power\u201d problem, p 144 on the same book.

      Like, what we can do in D&D, and why it\u2019s my favorite game of all time, are these transitions between wallpaper and saliency, and taking advantage of the human brain\u2019s amazing pattern recognition power.



      If there\u2019s a tree in its art\u2026

      This was an paradigm-shattering card.

      Suddenly everyone had to go through their collections of basic land cards and add a completely new salient predicate to their estimation of each card, has-tree-in-art-p.

      Ultimately, my view is that the most efficient way to store the game state, because we have the advantage of a human brain to interpret it, is as as a big old mish-mash, a big gloppy ball of mud of a mix of languages. It\u2019s like those old Infocom boxes\u2026 this is a picture, this is a map, this is a tape recording, this is a keychain, this is z-code binary data derived from sexps, this is a little folder with the history of the town\u2026

      This is my vivid, \u201cnatlang\u201d or spatial memory of the time Alice almost got sucked into the death propeller, this is my prep with a couple of sexps for each room, etc.

      FATE was groundbreaking in storing free strings as data, but ultimately faltered, by not being able to parse/eval those strings, instead treating them as just all equal, just meaningless binary blorbs of text; i.e.\xa0they got treated mostly as symbols (interned strings) even though they looked as if they had parsable, usable semantic content.

      We don\u2019t have to make that same mistake.

      I sure as heckfire use sexps (using quasiquotation to store both symbols and procedures in the same cons tree) to prep, they\u2019re great both for prepping very widely and when prepping deeply. But it\u2019s just a tool. I\u2019m just as likely to use a photograph or a detailed Mike Schley map or some prose text.

      Uh, I get that you were using sexps as a metaphor just like you were using the air chess earlier.

      And I\u2019m in agreement.

      I\u2019m just adding to that by saying that a vividly imagined \u201cworld\u201d is still useful as a very practical way to store some of the \u201coff-screen canon game-state\u201d / diegesis / MIS. And in the Deleuze-sense, then, the entire game-state (both the parts of it actively imagined / formed-in-the-mind as world, and the parts of it stored symbolically) does form a \u201cvirtual world\u201d.

      So to give my answer Thanuir\u2019s question to Jeph:\n
      Thanuir said:

      Jeph, suppose I am playing game which does not have formal rules for someone having fallen down or being prone. My character falls down. Is the statement indicating that my character is prone a part of the gamestate, as you see it?

      (I am guessing yes, but I want to verify.)

      In 2097e, yes. While we do happen to have formal rules for prone, let\u2019s say instead \u201cturned 20 degrees slightly to the right, looking up at the stirge flying down at your face\u201d, and that is a part of our gamestate.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n edited June 11
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Paul_T said:

      2097 said:

      AW is a masterpiece of IIEE.[\u2026]My issue with AW is only on the, uh, let\u2019s call it data structure layer instead of \u201contological\u201d layer.

      So, first of all, the clarity which AW has in regards to issues like IIEE (which is the type of thing that you can really ONLY consider from the standpoint of the Lumpley Principle; it was basically absent prior to that understanding) is exactly what I meant by the text being more \u201cself-aware\u201d. It\u2019s not necessarily a net positive, but from a designer\u2019s standpoint it\u2019s really handy, and it arguably does a better job of teaching people how to play.
      Strong agree!\n
      Paul_T said:

      Now, what is your issue with the \u201cdata structure layer\u201d? It seems to me that AW is not a \u201cfull blorb\u201d game, nor does it try to be. So, if that\u2019s your qualm with it, I don\u2019t think anyone will argue that you\u2019re wrong. (Well, actually, lots of people will. But I won\u2019t! I think you\u2019re right on.)

      Well, the players are expected to create & inject their entities (their characters, their clothes, their strongholds, their weapons etc) into a blorb while the MC operates on the SIS directly. That\u2019s incoherent to me.\n
      Paul_T said:

      However, I either don\u2019t follow or strongly disagree with your theoretical thoughts on the matter. Sometimes it feels like you\u2019re trying to redefine the way we look at RPG play in order to legitimize your favoured playstyle.

      I have some gaps in my understanding of the \u201cold\u201d model (the Forge model).\n
      • some of those gaps have been patched in this thread (much thanks)
      • some of those gaps remain (much thanks in advance for your patience)
      • some of those things aren\u2019t gaps in understanding, it\u2019s me understanding perfectly but disagreeing (I believe \u201ccloset language theorem\u201d to be one of those things)
      I have proposed a new model. To the extent that that model is compatible, there\u2019s no problem, there\u2019s no redefining the way we look at RPGs etc, it\u2019s all fine. If the new model is incompatible then sure that\u2019s pretty groundbreaking right? But that\u2019s all on you\u2665

      I just rely on the new model to do some great work\u2665\n
      Paul_T said:

      This is tricky, because, on one hand, that doesn\u2019t mean I can\u2019t engage with the practical stuff (e.g. designing random encounter tables). On the other hand, there\u2019s a danger of getting mired into a whole semantic swamp and missing out on cool techniques.

      Right, I\u2019m gonna try police the \u201cWhat data-structure\u201d thread pretty strictly to be about the practical stuff so we can do the semantic swamp over here.\n
      Paul_T said:

      So, I choose to take a middle ground by pointing out that I don\u2019t agree with the theory, and to preferentially engage with the more practical topics.

      It sounds like you\u2019d really like me to challenge the theory

      You don\u2019t necessarily have to challenge the theory, it\u2019s 1000% fine if you tune out from that part!
      It\u2019s also perfectly fine that you want to wash your hands free of any responsibility of my model, to declare your loyalty to Ye Pantheon of The Forge.
      The problem is that the specific way you\u2019ve been repeatedly phrasing that hand-washing, I\u2019ve interpreted as dismissive, patronizing, sometimes ablist.

      Having the theory challenged in detail would be a lesser evil than that, is what I\u2019m thinking (unless this is a grass-is-greener, be-careful-what-I-wish-for thing). So with that in mind:\n
      Paul_T said:

      I\u2019m happy to do so; in exchange, I\u2019ll ask you to give me the benefit of the doubt and not to assume that I\u2019m being close-minded or mean-spirited. I very much see this as a friendly and interesting dialogue!

      That sounds like a good deal.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n edited June 11
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Paul_T said:

      I\u2019d initially thought that no change of the Situation (in Forge terms) can happen without talking, but perhaps you are right that sometimes such change happens with very little overt communication. (e.g. I can cross off a potion on my character sheet and increment my HP, and we all know that, in the SIS, my character drank a potion.)

      Right, and that happens for the DM all the time. I roll out the fight of Esmeralda vs Dracula between sessions and have the hobos next session meet a vampiric version of Esmeralda since she succumbed to the forces of night.\n
      Paul_T said:

      The question, then, becomes whether this somehow violates the idea of the Lumpley Principle. I\u2019d always understood it as being entirely in line with it: the original text of the Principle doesn\u2019t say anything about talking, and it seems silly to pretend that things like illustrations, maps, miming a sword swing, taking on the body position/posture of a character I\u2019m playing, and so forth don\u2019t affect what we\u2019re imagining.

      The the sloppily written Wiki text is where I\u2019m getting my understanding and in that view, those illustrations, sword swings, maps etc are ephemera that are still ultimately leading to what\u2019s going to enter the SIS and only then become relevant. Which to me is like \u201cA car isn\u2019t a car until it hits the road\u201d, kinda, uh, well, a useful mental model for some type of work and an indirect and clumsy model for other types of work.\n
      Paul_T said:

      It might qualify as a really interesting claim, if not for the perception [\u2026] that this is just the \u201cold\u201d way of looking at gaming.[\u2026]Now you\u2019re trying to bring on board something that sounds [\u2026] like that old-time kind of thinking about RPGs.

      I see reconnecting with these precedents as a good thing. I\u2019m gonna get around to reading Playing at the World one of these days.\n
      Paul_T said:

      So, the idea was that the Lumpley Principle was a broader understanding, breaking us free of that kind of limited thinking.

      I get that.

      Your revolution was going from the 90s game of \u201ccompromised blorb\u201d, which is incoherent, to \u201cunshackled by blorb\u201d, which isn\u2019t.

      But we\u2019re running into the limits of the new model, pretty hard, and find ourselves crying out for some blorb.\n
      Paul_T said:

      2097 said:

      While there\u2019s a bit of an overlap, this is fundamentally different from \u201cyarn-spinning\u201d as an activity, where you add statements to a story, incorporating or embellishing or correcting previously added statements to said story.

      So, this is the rather bold and interesting claim: that there is a fundamental difference between RPG play or \u201cmake believe\u201d and collaborative storytelling.

      I can see some rationale for that! Certainly, a game where I am strictly limited to actor stance (e.g. many/most of the trad RPG tradition) and a game where we get to make stuff up together feel quite different.

      But, off the top of my head, I can think of a dozen examples of corner cases that defy categorization, hybrid forms, and so forth. So I\u2019d have to hear WHY you feel these are fundamentally different,
      I\u2019m not disputing that there is significant overlap. What I am saying is that when there\u2019s a set of theorems and principles, like Lehrich\u2019s \u201ccloset language theorem\u201d (and some interpretations of the LBCBP that I\u2019ve seen some of you use earlier in this thread), that are set up to only do yarn-spinning and to discourage make-believe, we who want to do make-believe (\u201clet\u2019s pretend\u201d) need to find a different set of principles & theorems that help our design work.
      Paul_T said:

      and then how you can think of any kind of hybrid game (which most RPGs are, at root) within a framework where those two things are fundamentally different activities. How do you explain something like AW or Sorcerer or The Pool from that point of view?

      They\u2019re incoherent \n
      • AW asks the players to \u201cmake believe\u201d and the MC to \u201cyarn spin\u201d
      • Sorcerer is mostly in \u201cmake believe\u201d land if you are being careful to use the bangs blorbily (which we\u2019re gonna try to create a framework for, to be able to do more consistently
      • The Pool (and SLUG) are just\u2026 kinda bad games unfocused designs
      Paul_T said:

      It describes what\u2019s happening pretty well, but the references to a \u201cgame state\u201d, even though it often doesn\u2019t exist outside of the utterances of the players (e.g. those cracks in the floor simply did not exist in any sense until the player asked about them), have to be supported. I also think that, aside from the mentions of the \u2018game state\u2019

      The cracks in the floor exist in the game state, that\u2019s kinda central to what I\u2019m saying here, they\u2019re no mere \u201caside\u201d.

      I believe in that particular example the floor cracks were injected into the game state at prep time, but it might just as well have been in play, as a tier three truth. (A kinda crappy tier three truth since it\u2019s obv salient in that it obscures a pit trap.)\n
      Paul_T said:

      \u201cJohn wants to use narration to portray a canny and cautious young man so he adds a statement to the fiction that implies that he is attempting to examine the floor.\u201d > This is complete straw doll, in my opinion. You\u2019ve somehow decided (perhaps because of that line on the wiki page!) that accepting the Lumpley Principle means that all roleplay is a structured narrative that we consciously construct.

      If you remove the word \u201cconsciously\u201d, those kinds of roleplay experiences are the type of games whose design work most benefit from accepting the LBCBP.

      If the LBCBP is to have any meaning, it\u2019s to say that there is a first-class ludeme called the SIS (things said (with words or eyebrows or gestures) at the game table) and operating on that SIS is the core activity in roleplaying, and ephemera exist only to support those operations. And if so, that\u2019s where our model disagrees.

      The straw doll I made overly ascribes motivation to John, and that part of the straw doll seems to have been unhelpful in getting my point across, but:\n
      • in my model, the focus is on John pretending that he has a character in the dungeon that is taking actions, and then John is describing these actions with statements
      • while in the LBCBP model, the focus is on John making statements about his character performing actions.
      There is a lot of game play that can be perfectly accurately described by either of those two models.\n
      Paul_T said:

      which is downright silly - obviously we can make rules like \u201cat 30 minutes past the hours, change seats with your partner\u201d

      Ephemera to support the SIS.\n
      Paul_T said:

      even though thousands of hybrid games exist and are played every day.

      You even calling them \u201chybrid\u201d only serves to validate that there are two different models lest there\u2019d be nothing to \u201chybridize\u201d.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n edited June 11
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Paul_T said:

      The \u201cJohn\u201d in the example is doing no such thing. There\u2019s no \u201cstory being told\u201d - we\u2019re exploring an imaginary space which it is the GM\u2019s responsibility to describe as accurately and consistently as she can.

      In the \u201cblorb\u201d model, yes, exploring it.

      In the \u201cno myth\u201d model, you are instead constructing an imaginary space. This is even, audaciously enough, called \u201cexploration\u201d in the big model

      Fang, when he described the no myth model, made allowance for some genres to include extremely detailed prep to support the GM, and even having rules to enforce the GM to stick to that prep, when (by uttering it at the table) constructing it.\n
      Paul_T said:

      Sure, we could make a game where that\u2019s not the case - something like Donjon, perhaps - but that would be a different game.

      In the \u201cno myth\u201d proponents view [at the time, again, those threads are 15 years old, so I don\u2019t know what they think now]\u2026 all games are like Donjon, only with extremely detailed rules & prep to construct the dungeon as we go.\n
      • In Donjon, you construct the secret door by invoking the rule \u201csucceed on a search roll\u201d which lets you add it to the SIS.
      • In a no-myth model\u2019s view of an OSR game in progress, the secret door is constructed by the DM looking at their map, seeing the secret door there, and adding it to the SIS.
      • In a blorb view of an OSR game in progress, the secret door is in that wall and the DM just reports that accurately.
      Paul_T said:

      In short, you\u2019ve created a (nearly) accurate analysis and said that it conforms to your model, and then a rather caricatured and strange analysis where for some reason two people playing D&D are trying to \u201ctell a story\u201d as their primary motive and don\u2019t seem to understand how Finchian trap-finding even works, and are trying to say that this analysis discredits the Lumpley Principle.

      If not the LBCBP, then certainly the \u201cno myth\u201d prinicple / \u201cclose language theorem\u201d.

      It might look caricatured and strange because that\u2019s how I thought it worked, how you were supposed to run games, before I found blorb.\n
      Paul_T said:

      One thing I would be very interested to see, which I keep coming back to, is how the \u201cgame state\u201d model can explain uncorrected errors in play.

      The game state in our model can have errors, just like how the SIS/transcripts in the \u201cno myth\u201d model can contain inadvertent contradictions.

      Our game state is just a big old ball of mud. If someone in chess accidentally makes two moves in a row and neither player notices it, the board doesn\u2019t suddenly disappear in a cloud of smoke. I have a more detailed response here, including a 2d6 SWN example.
      Jeph said:

      I\u2019ll also note that Sandra and I are totally not on the same page re: game state and the LBCB Principle. I think the principle works as originally stated: \u201cSystem (including but not limited to \u2018the rules\u2019) is defined as the means by which the group agrees to imagined events during play.\u201d So written, the LBCB Principle is 100% compatible with the idea of game state; the game stat\u2019s constraints on imagined events are just a means by which we agree to those imagined events.

      Our disagreement here, @Jeph, is that I think it\u2019s just so much more productive to base our \u201csoftware architecture\u201d (our game design work) around the game state as primary data structure, than base it around the subset of that data structure that has been revealed in play. To the exent of the LBCBP being almost pointless or meaningless for our work.
      Silmenume said:

      [\u2026] your character (Silitare) bite Tomas (Blake\u2019s character)? The tiny head nod was a \u201cYes\u201d and Tomas\u2019 current state and future were radically changed.

      The LBCB Principle in action using no words.

      Frankly, the question of whether the utterances are verbal or somatic are beside the point here. The point of contention is when the referents are constructed.\n
      AsIf said:

      Hey, at least she isn\u2019t trying to deconstruct the word \u201crailroading.\u201d
      I tried once. Shoulda seen that shitstorm. :-)

      Huh, my remembrance of events are that you did succeed and that I incorporated \u201crailroading\u201d into the RISS model because of your efforts.

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n

      \n\nJune 11 \n edited June 11
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Ah, so our old railroading debacle is immortalized in the RISS Model? excellent!

      For what it\u2019s worth, my *position* on the term railroading is entirely unchanged since what I said in those threads, but having the discussion led me to consider and explore a variety of game styles and designs, which was good. I\u2019ve even tried to convince my most stable group to try some heavily GM-railroaded (Participationist) play, although I haven\u2019t succeeded just yet.

      My hunch is that this discussion will go the same way. So far, I find the ideas don\u2019t hold together from a theoretical standpoint, but I do like thinking in this different way and trying to explore what it can give us in terms of design space.

      Ultimately, the proof is in the pudding: I don\u2019t hold to *any* theoretical model as sacrosanct (although hardcore science comes close), so as soon as I find a way to generate useful tools or good design from any idea or model, I\u2019m a 100% on board!

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Thanuir said:

      Earlier you wrote that "CONTAINS `VESTIBULE (GP 100)" is in the game state. How is it different from a character being prone?

      \nNo! Fake news! Go back and re-read that post more carefully please:

      Earlier I wrote that whether or not the game state includes (CONTAINS `VESTIBULE (GP 100)) depends on the game. That proposition is in the game state if and only if we have system related to that proposition.

      For instance, if we've agreed that the GM must say what their prep demands.

      In exactly the same way, being prone is in the game state if and only if we have system related to being prone.\n
      2097 said:

      I disagree; the benefits of the analogy are much too great to give up. Here\u2019s why:

      I think the view of our diegesis as a \u201cworld\u201d, having it expressed \u201cin natural language\u201d (or even imagined, fully realized 3d places and people) rather than sexps (symbombolic expressions) is sometimes a great tool for us humans to use when remembering parts the game state because of how any aspect of established wallpaper (whether improvised wallpaper, or gloracularly produced wallpaper) can become salient. (Obviously salient elements have an unambigous sexp representation.)

      [...]

      Like, what we can do in D&D, and why it\u2019s my favorite game of all time, are these transitions between wallpaper and saliency, and taking advantage of the human brain\u2019s amazing pattern recognition power.



      If there\u2019s a tree in its art\u2026

      This was an paradigm-shattering card.

      Suddenly everyone had to go through their collections of basic land cards and add a completely new salient predicate to their estimation of each card, has-tree-in-art-p.

      Ultimately, my view is that the most efficient way to store the game state, because we have the advantage of a human brain to interpret it, is as as a big old mish-mash, a big gloppy ball of mud of a mix of languages. It\u2019s like those old Infocom boxes\u2026 this is a picture, this is a map, this is a tape recording, this is a keychain, this is z-code binary data derived from sexps, this is a little folder with the history of the town\u2026

      This is my vivid, \u201cnatlang\u201d or spatial memory of the time Alice almost got sucked into the death propeller, this is my prep with a couple of sexps for each room, etc.

      \nOoh. Yeah. You have convinced me!

      Like, I draw a LOT of maps, which my games hold as gamestate-ful. The gamestate is probably exactly that image of the map. Not the physical map itself, not graphite and wood pulp; and not a bunch of s-expressions extracted from looking at the map; but the image that I've drawn.

      (Supporting evidence: I'll switch between the physical image and a digital copy with no qualms!)

      Same for when you write "The vestibule contains 100 GP"; it's probably is more productive to think of the state as those very words: not the graphite and wood pulp or bytes and bits, and not the s-expression (CONTAINS `VESTIBULE (GP 100)), but the word-symbols.\n
      In 2097e, yes. While we do happen to have formal rules for prone, let\u2019s say instead \u201cturned 20 degrees slightly to the right, looking up at the stirge flying down at your face\u201d, and that is a part of our gamestate.
      \nHmm, I'm not sure I really understand this.

      I'm pretty sure you'd agree that in The Pool or Universalis, "turned 20 degrees slightly to the right, looking up..." is NOT part of the game state.

      What about 2097e makes it so that it IS part of the game state?

      Is it part of the game state in your average Apoc Wolrd game? In Eero's princess play 4E game?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nNeurotrash \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n \u2022\t
      In a no-myth model\u2019s view of an OSR game in progress, the secret door is constructed by the DM looking at their map, seeing the secret door there, and adding it to the SIS.
      \u2022\tIn a blorb view of an OSR game in progress, the secret door is in that wall and the DM just reports that accurately.
      \nI can\u2019t for the life of me see how these are contradictory or different. These are both just descriptions of how the existence of the secret door was added to the SIS. In both cases the B-C-B Principle definition of \u201csystem\u201d seems to apply. The DM is referencing their prep and using that information to add a fact into the Shared Imaginary Space.

      In both cases, \u201cthe secret door is in that wall\u201d, because at some point the DM decided to either put it there earlier during prep or decide that they would use this part of the module that says the door\u2019s there without modification.

      As far as I can see, consulting the Game State is just a tool used in a particular type of System (defined in the B-C-B-Principal as \u201chow we decide what happens in the SIS\u201d), no different than dice, negotiation, consulting a chart, submitting to a particular player\u2019s narrative authority, etc.

      The fact that we\u2019re considering the \u201cGame State\u201d as an extra-SIS \u201cvirtual world\u201d that all the players to have agreed to abide by (the same as they\u2019ve all agreed to abide by the results of dice rolls) doesn\u2019t make it not part of the System or invalidate the (I\u2019m just calling it this from now on because it\u2019s easier to type) Lumpley Principle.

      Or not? How is this wrong?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n edited June 11
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n@Neurotrash, I think that\u2019s precisely the same question a bunch of us keep asking. Right there with you!

      The first entry from the bit you quoted sounds like an accurate description of how RPG play works.

      The second is either a metaphor (in which case it\u2019s the same thing, expressed in less clear language), or it\u2019s... something else I can\u2019t parse, since that sentence appears to be conflating fantasy and reality.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n edited June 11
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n It... sounds like mostly everyone is on the same page here?

      In some games, there exists a Game State, some sort of objective logical structure; and the system creates obligations related to that Game State, and uses the Game State to constrain what counts as a valid contribution to the SIS.

      Right? We all agree on that?

      I don't think that the no-myth view or blorb view are contradictory in the facts, they're contradictory in terms of what's important, worth paying attention to and spending energy on.

      No Myth holds the game state as essentially ephemeral and unimportant. It ONLY matters insofar as it affects contributions to the SIS.

      Blorb holds that this is overly dismissive, the game state is a first-class structure just as important as the SIS.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nNeurotrash \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n edited June 11
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Okay, I think I agree then.

      It's more of a matter of agenda/priority than a description about what is happening in the game.

      If anything, this thread has convinced me that such a thing as the Game State exists. I might have argued against that fact before...

      So that still brings up the question of what one can do with this realization when it comes to a design standpoint. Other than including ways prep and use blorb (and declare that a facet of the system will be a strict adherence to that blorb and its effect on the Game State), how can this help us create procedures that will better allow players and groups who prioritize manipulation and tracking of the Game State as their primary goal in achieving that goal in play?

      More over, I think it might end up turning us back to the original debate on this thread, which is whether it is a bad idea to design a game wherein both interacting with the Game State and creating an SIS together are simultaneous and equally important goals, and whether its possible/desirable/coherent to attempt a design where players who prioritize one over the other can both be equally accommodated...

      ...and whether system tools that enable one type of play (Game State Manipulation) intrinsically inhibits the other type of play (SIS Construction), which I believe was 2097's original claim.





      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nThanuir \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Jeph said:

      Thanuir said:

      Earlier you wrote that "CONTAINS `VESTIBULE (GP 100)" is in the game state. How is it different from a character being prone?

      \nNo! Fake news! Go back and re-read that post more carefully please:

      Earlier I wrote that whether or not the game state includes (CONTAINS `VESTIBULE (GP 100)) depends on the game. That proposition is in the game state if and only if we have system related to that proposition.

      For instance, if we've agreed that the GM must say what their prep demands.

      In exactly the same way, being prone is in the game state if and only if we have system related to being prone.
      \nThanks. How does this work with OSR-style play with rulings over rules, where the precise mechanical interpretation of someone being prone is uncertain before the situation happens, and then the referee or the group as a whole makes a ruling about if and how the condition matters in this particular circumstance?

      I think this is essentially the same question as you got to in the quote of Sandra, in the last paragraphs of your post.

      I think a related phenomenon is that anything in the fiction (allow the sloppy language) might become relevant; there is a Lamentations adventure where the eye colour of characters might matter and a Trilemma adventure where blue clothes are relevant, to take examples where actual colour becomes a substantial part of play. Likewise Sandra's tar example.

      I would be very tempted to say that the entire fiction is part of the game state in these kinds of games, but you clearly have something more limited in mind.

      I think a relevant difference between this kind of game and Universalis or D&D 4 might be that OSR play* (and, I guess, Sandra's play) is one of creative problem solving, in the sense that one has limited tools that one tries to use in clever ways to solve problems, and the culture of play respects interesting and exotic problems and solutions.

      If one has narrative authority, then problem solving is of entirely different nature; I think Rickhard has some game like Dungeons and Bananas for this. But I might misremember a name or two.

      D&D 4, by default, has a component of tactical miniature problem solving (an important or an incidental one), while the focus might be elsewhere, but could also be in the tactical mini-game. I understand that Eero's game also has a light strategic dimension, but is focused more on following the stories of the characters and on enjoying the game world.

      ---

      * By OSR play, I mean the style of play that is fairly typical in OSR circles and rare elsewhere. For a good exploration of problem solving, see Goblin punch: https://goblinpunch.blogspot.com/2016/02/osr-style-challenges-rulings-not-rules.html
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Thanuir said:

      How does this work with OSR-style play with rulings over rules, where the precise mechanical interpretation of someone being prone is uncertain before the situation happens, and then the referee or the group as a whole makes a ruling about if and how the condition matters in this particular circumstance?

      I think this is essentially the same question as you got to in the quote of Sandra, in the last paragraphs of your post.

      \nYeah, I think it's the same question.

      My current thinking is that this sort of thing is operating directly on the imagined events, and not the game state. I'm not sure whether I'm being sloppy or ill-posed in this regard.

      But to clarify something: I am not saying that anything that serves as the operand for a rule is part of the game state. More like, if the rules cannot be enacted based on the SIS alone, then the game state is that minimal additional logical structure that you need.

      So when Dungeon World's Hack and Slash move writes "When you attack an enemy in melee..." that doesn't mean we need to include the relation IN_MELEE in our game state. Because we can resolve that purely at the SIS level.

      But now consider D&D5e, even a completely Theater of the Mind 5e with no grid. There's a rule that when you leave an enemy's reach, they get an opportunity attack. Consider a situation where the DM knows that an invisible assassin is standing next to Alice. Nothing about this assassin has been shared. But (WITHIN_REACH `ASSASSIN `ALICE) has to be in the game state, because we can't enact the opportunity attack rule without it.

      I'm kinda musing out loud and clarifying my own thinking at the moment, rather than trying to Teach Something.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I'd be very curious to see how you distinguish between the DW case and D&D.

      Would it change if I simply reworded the D&D rule like this?

      * When an enemy moves out of your reach, you can attack them, right now, before they can get away.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n edited June 11
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Nope, no difference at all, because we still need to know that Alice was within reach of the invisible assassin, and we can't know that from the SIS!

      EDIT: Unless we're explicitly allowing the GM to inject invisible assassins wherever and whenever they wish, I guess? "Uh, and there's an, uh, invisible assassin right behind you, and they get an opportunity attack as you enter the grocery store to buy arugula and baby kale!" Probably not a game I want to play. Or unless this is a Player Move, in which case it doesn't apply the invisible assassin, and probably really does only trigger off of the SIS, unless this is a really funky cool game that involves players having hidden game state that they know about and the GM doesn't.

      Oh, hey, we just opened up some design space: Game state that the player knows about and the GM doesn't.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nSilmenume \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hi @Jeph,\n
      Jeph said:

      @Silmenume , each player's coin count is part of the game state. But not a part of the game state that has any kind of interesting relationship to imagined events, since it works at a purely meta level. The rule that you can spend coins to state facts isn't part of state; any more than the rule that rooks move orthogonally and bishops move diagonally is part of the state of a game of chess. I don't have DitV, so I can't really comment on its details!

      \nThank you for clarifying that for me. Appreciate it!

      I'm trying to work this though so indulge me, if you will, with the Chess Board analogy.\n
      Things that are in the diegesis, imagined events, do not necessarily have any correspondence with anything in the game state. The game state is not "imagined events plus some other stuff." It's not even "A portion of imagined events, plus maybe other stuff."

      It's a set of propositions: predicates which operate on tokens, logical primitives like numbers and booleans, and other propositions.
      \nI propose that the chess board with the chess pieces on it, in the various positions are analogous to the SIS or what I sometimes refer to as the "fact space." It is the arena where the act of playing takes place. Going a bit further let say we end with a White Queen moved to the same file as the Black King and there are no other pieces between the two.

      The SIS has nothing to say about the relationship of the pieces, they just are where they are.

      The GameSpace does focus on the relationship of pieces, uses the rules of the game and draws a conclusion (makes a judgement) - one element of the GameState is that the "King is in Check." The rules say that you must inform your opponent about this (typically this spoken but for the sake of this example perhaps a token is put on the side board or placard is flipped over with the word "Check" exposed under it) but they also say that your opponent must address this GameState of Check above all other GameStates concerns. I would also offer that the Chess Clock is also part of the GameState in competition chess. If a player runs out of time is equivalent to running out of HP's. In both cases a new GameState condition is created. In the first that state is "You lose" it an RPG depending on CA and rules it could be "You lose" (als Kobolds Ate My Baby) or "Your character is dead" or "Your character loses consciousness" or "You lose the Conflict take fall out."

      So the SIS/"fact space" is completely agnostic WRT such matters a proposed/considered/planned moves, strategy, board state, winning, losing, offense, defense or any other matter requiring human judgment. The "game" of chess begins and ends with the chessboard and the disposition of the pieces (one is not playing if they are not moving chess pieces - this is more solidly clarified in tournament chess with the Chess Clock). For all that cogitation that happens in the GameState play isn't happening until the pieces are moved.

      The SIS is the official IS.
      That GameState covers everything about what the SIS signifies.

      The chessboard can exist without the GameState but play can't happen as there is no Agency. The GameState can only exist because of its relationship to the specific chessboard. The GameState state can be both informed by the SIS and inform what can be done in the SIS.

      Its interesting to examine this GameState as that what really matters to us as players happens in this part of the game. Such things as nebulous as CA make their influence felt here but this space has never been described or given a name before.

      Best,

      Jay
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Silmenume said:

      I propose that the chess board with the chess pieces on it, in the various positions are analogous to the SIS or what I sometimes refer to as the "fact space." It is the arena where the act of playing takes place. Going a bit further let say we end with a White Queen moved to the same file as the Black King and there are no other pieces between the two.

      \nOof. I want to nip this in the bud!

      Chess is a game that really, truly, actually has a game state.

      The game state is the positions of the pieces on the board. (The physical board and pieces are not the game state. They're signifiers, signs, which help us remember and track the game state. You don't need the physical board and pieces to play chess; you can track the game state in your head, if you want.)

      That's not a metaphor. The positions of the pieces on the board is literally the game state of a game of chess.

      Please, pleas, please, please do not construct some analogy where the positions of the pieces on the board in chess maps to something other than game state. That will become ridiculously confusing.

      Chess has no SIS.

      But we can play a version of chess that does have a SIS. Call in Vivid Imagination Chess. We imagine a battle where sixteen warriors dressed in red face off against sixteen warriors dressed in white, each corresponding to one of the pieces in the game state. After making a move, you describe it in the battle.

      "Pawn to C3. Gallant Sir Pawnington martches forth, his cloak billowing, shield raised, the tip of his spear tied with a fluttering banner of red cloth!"
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nSilmenume \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hi @Jeph\n
      Jeph said:

      (The physical board and pieces are not the game state. They're signifiers, signs, which help us remember and track the game state. You don't need the physical board and pieces to play chess; you can track the game state in your head, if you want.)

      \nThat was exactly the point of my analogy! And your phrasing maps exactly to my ideas of the differences between the SIS and the GameState.

      To me what you described in the quote above is crystal clear but if I'm the only one who benefits from the analogy then it is, ofcourse, not useful. I liked it specifically because the actual pieces are signifiers (the SIS/the fact space/the concrete) which help us remember and track the game state (with all its functioning at the abstract level). I will, with much sadness cease using it. It's all good!

      I would suggest, if you find it ameniable, that in using the virtual/air chess analogy that in order to keep the conversation as "simple" as possible that we stick to "Pawn to C3" type of statement just for the duration of this analogy. Statements like, "The Gallant Sir Pawnington marches forth, his cloak billowing, shield raised, the tip of his spear tied with a fluttering banner of red cloth!" are mostly Color but can add elements that can confuse the analogy. Maybe I'm not that bright but I want to distill this GameState idea down to its very base essentials before working back up to implications and design considerations.

      Aside from my poor use of the idea of a physical chessboard do you have any comments on the ideas offered in my previous post? Understanding that the like you said the SIS is the arena of referents and referents modified by which we keep by which keep track of GameState. The GameState being that arena where we interpret the referents, make choices, do book keeping, etc. and which under the proper circumstances we then go back and make modifications to the arena of referents/SIS.

      Best,

      Jay
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n edited June 11
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Yeah, I think we're pretty much on the same page then!

      Though I'm not sure what I think about SIS as the arena of referents. Sandra would say that the referent is the symbol in the Game State, I think; the symbol in the game state is the causal antecedent of the imagined entity in the SIS, just like the planet Venus is the causal antecedent of the entity I think of when I say "The Evening Star."

      And note, the Vivid Imagination Chess thing isn't an analogy. It's an actual game we can play right now, where the Game State is the logical structure signified by the board and pieces, and the SIS is what's evoked in our minds when I talk about Gallant Sir Pawnington, and when we look at the board and imagine the ranks of our soldiers on the field.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nThanuir \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Jeph said:


      My current thinking is that this sort of thing is operating directly on the imagined events, and not the game state. I'm not sure whether I'm being sloppy or ill-posed in this regard.

      But to clarify something: I am not saying that anything that serves as the operand for a rule is part of the game state. More like, if the rules cannot be enacted based on the SIS alone, then the game state is that minimal additional logical structure that you need.

      \nCertainly going to very different direction than Sandra is, given her suggestion that "who knows what" is of relatively little importance.

      If the game state is the minimal additional logical structure needed in addition to SIS, then it behaves strangely: As a greater deal of the fiction is revealed, it shrinks in size. In particular, if we take chess and start imagining the fiction and sharing it, the game state diminishes, and if we manage to add the entire game state (the locations of pieces, has castling been invalidated by moving the pieces, how many repeated moves there have been; let us ignore clocks for simplicity) to the shared imagined space, than the game state vanishes.

      The suggested concept would be more useful in a game of hidden information, for sure.

      What would be the price to pay for saying that anything that serves as an operand to the game rules is a part of the game state?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nSilmenume \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n edited June 12
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hi @Thanuir or @Jeph,

      Being the village idiot that I am would either of you please define or make clearer for dummies like me what "operand to the game rules" means.

      My take is that the concepts you employed in your example - \n
      ...the locations of pieces, has castling been invalidated by moving the pieces, how many repeated moves there have been...
      \n- are all GameState items. The tricky one is the "location of the pieces". In this particular circumstance this is where the SIS and the GameState come into contact. The facts of the SIS informing the GameState. Which in due course the GameState will then generate a proposition about the "location of the pieces" that travels through the LBCB Principle and possibly updates the SIS. To me the SIS is nothing but facts. Like your castling example that concept only resides in the GameState. It is informed by what the players communicate into the SIS but the SIS itself is utterly agnotic WRT concepts.

      The idea of the GameState vanishing is an idea that I'm having a terrible time wrapping my head around. My conceptions about my character, my conceptions about Situation, the various courses of action that I'm conceptualizing definitionally belong in the GameState and can never go away while one is playing. For the GameState to "vanish" would be akin the the player utterly losing all knowledge of the game itself. I am willing to admit that perhaps that my understanding is incorrect and any enlightenment would be gladly accepted.\n
      ...very different direction than Sandra is, given her suggestion that "who knows what" is of relatively little importance.
      \nI'm completely at sea by this statement. What information does "who knows what" refer to? The SIS? The GameSpace? The separation of GM and player knowledge? Help?!

      Best,

      Jay
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n The SIS is a strict subset of the MIS / the game-state / the blorb.\n
      Jeph said:

      What about 2097e makes it so that it [\u201cturned 20 degrees slightly to the right, looking up\u2026\u201d] IS part of the game state?

      In 2097e actions can be wholly diegetic (finchian) and they can sometimes lead into engaging a dice-level mechanic (from tonight\u2019s session: \u201cI drink the tea\u201d \u201cMake a DC 12 con save\u201d); I call this the \u201cbraid\u201d; diegetic\u2192dice\u2192diegetic\u2192dice.

      Diegetic actions depend on previous description. \u201cThen I look at the other side\u201d is different if it follows \u201cI look at the left side first\u201d vs \u201cI look at the right side first\u201d.\n
      Paul_T said:

      So far, I find the ideas don\u2019t hold together from a theoretical standpoint

      Paul, you\u2019ve promised to not do this; don\u2019t phrase your hand-washing in a way that makes it be just a drive-by attack. Engaging is fine but be specific.

      Also I just saw that I\u2019ve been using the word Ephemera wrong. Guh, #english\n
      Neurotrash said:

      The fact that we\u2019re considering the \u201cGame State\u201d as an extra-SIS \u201cvirtual world\u201d that all the players to have agreed to abide by (the same as they\u2019ve all agreed to abide by the results of dice rolls) doesn\u2019t make it not part of the System or invalidate the (I\u2019m just calling it this from now on because it\u2019s easier to type) Lumpley Principle.

      In Swedish we have an expression.

      Don\u2019t go cross the river to fetch water.

      Instead of going all the way out to this extra-SIS (the MIS) to validate all your SIS operations,
      you can operate directly on the MIS since it is a strict superset of the SIS, just with a shared-p flippable bit.

      If the LBCBP view would hold strictly, yes, the MIS could still be implemented, but only monadically as part of operations that are primarily SIS operations (each operation would have it\u2019s own \u201crelationship\u201d to the MIS). Which is crossing an entire ocean just to fetch some water. Also, such a game doesn\u2019t exist.\n
      Jeph said:

      Blorb holds that this is overly dismissive, the game state is a first-class structure just as important as the SIS.

      It\u2019s strictly more important than the SIS. Being a (very much larger) superset.\n
      Neurotrash said:

      So that still brings up the question of what one can do with this realization when it comes to a design standpoint. Other than including ways prep and use blorb (and declare that a facet of the system will be a strict adherence to that blorb and its effect on the Game State), how can this help us create procedures that will better allow players and groups who prioritize manipulation and tracking of the Game State as their primary goal in achieving that goal in play?

      Right; making rules about when and how to add things into the Game State is something that is very uncodified and ad-hoc right now. I\u2019ve tried to get the ball rolling with stuff like \u201cNo Paper after seeing Rock\u201d or whatever but we can have much finer granularity.

      Also creating things that give gloracular answers about off-screen actions in the Game State. An example of such a design being the faction turn in SWN.\n
      Neurotrash said:

      More over, I think it might end up turning us back to the original debate on this thread, which is whether it is a bad idea to design a game wherein both interacting with the Game State and creating an SIS together are simultaneous and equally important goals, and whether its possible/desirable/coherent to attempt a design where players who prioritize one over the other can both be equally accommodated\u2026

      \u2026and whether system tools that enable one type of play (Game State Manipulation) intrinsically inhibits the other type of play (SIS Construction), which I believe was 2097\u2019s original claim.

      Right\u2026

      in our model shared-p is a flippable bit, a predicate applied to entities, in their model it\u2019s the fundamental building block of the universe. \u201cUttering is making.\u201d\n
      Thanuir said:

      If one has narrative authority, then problem solving is of entirely different nature; I think Rickhard has some game like Dungeons and Bananas for this. But I might misremember a name or two.

      Drakar och Bananer is primarily a radically different IIEE exercise. You solved the problem using these and these and these tools. Now say how. I really dislike it.\n
      Jeph said:

      My current thinking is that this sort of thing is operating directly on the imagined events, and not the game state. I\u2019m not sure whether I\u2019m being sloppy or ill-posed in this regard.

      I hope one of us can come around to the other\u2019s view lest we fraction the nascent blorb model on day one \n
      Jeph said:

      But to clarify something: I am not saying that anything that serves as the operand for a rule is part of the game state.

      Whereas I am saying that.
      The game state contains all operands.
      Since the game is nomic, it also contains all operators.\n
      Jeph said:

      Oh, hey, we just opened up some design space: Game state that the player knows about and the GM doesn\u2019t.

      Yes, I hope we get some more design in this area.

      We use it often in our group. Maybe because I have a larp background, when there are dozens of players and you can\u2019t keep track of everything anyway. Here is perhaps the clearest example:

      When playing in a D&D game in 2014, I wasn\u2019t the DM, I was player. I wrote something on a note and sealed it in an envelope without showing it to the DM.

      It said I cast \u201cPurify Food and Drink\u201d spell on the food that was served to the duchess.

      That\u2019s just one of many examples.

      Often it\u2019s drama level stuff like building relationships etc.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Jeph said:

      Sandra would say that the referent is the symbol in the Game State, I think

      \nRight; referents can have multiple signifiers though.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Jay, an "operand" is a vampire or a sword or a d20 or a character sheet or a castle or a horse.
      An "operator" is an action or a rule or procedure or policy or principle or guideline or technique.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n edited June 11
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n (I need sleep)\n
      Silmenume said:

      I'm completely at sea by this statement. What information does "who knows what" refer to? The SIS? The GameSpace? The separation of GM and player knowledge? Help?

      \nWe meant
      Some parts of the game state (the game state includes things like swords and green dragons and cakes) are also part of the SIS. When two or more people know about something, that means it's part of the SIS.

      In my model, making something that's in the game state known isn't a radical change to that thing. You had the cake. You still have the cake, only now it's a cake that people know about.

      In the "no myth" worldview, you didn't have the cake before. You only had the recipe.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nkomradebob \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n At nearly 600 posts, this thread is longer than several RPGs I play.

      What has been learned? Can we get a summary at 600 posts or so before going on?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      komradebob said:

      What has been learned?

      \n@2097 bigger genius than all of RPG theorists
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n edited June 11
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n It seems to me that the permanent game state is in fact an extension of the rules. It is a rule that in this room of the dungeon, there are three caskets behind a pit; you can't break that rule anymore than when I play, oh, Apocalypse World that you can roll with Hard when you make the Act Under Fire move. Of course, maybe you have a move that lets you do just that: rules modifying rules, and we have rules for that. Just so that if I have the cantrip mage hand and need to do something inside a closed casket, and there are no rules saying I can't, then I can do it and we check the rules (the prep/module) for what happens next.

      The argument on the 2097e side at first seems to be that only things that have rules are real: die Regeln sind allen was der Fall ist.* This follows the, uh, lemme use "Laws" here to avoid confusion, the Laws of Salience and Tiers of Truth.

      Basically: Facts are rules. Certainly the inverse is true: it is a fact that your character can't fly in D&D without spell/magic/wings, it is a fact in Masks that the Outsider can. Those are both rules. New facts about the world are new rules, constraining it or expanding it.

      And actually...that's true for Apocalypse World too, it's just that in Apocalypse World we basically have a rule that's like "whatever a player asserts about their character/the world in their reach, that is not contradicted by prior events (where facts are rules or existing rules (rules are facts) is true." (Note that the rule is constrained, of course, because Apocalypse World says that players can't just assert that "there's a robot empire to the east" unless prompted by the MC, who will remain the ultimate arbiter of that truth through their function as, in truth, the prompter of questions about the game state which allows more assertion of new facts/rules.)

      Other games allow players to assert that there's a robot empire in the east because that's in the rules for them.

      Now at least part of the assertion here is that by prioritizing prewritten rules (the module/prep) and creating clear and essentially immutable rules for the generation of new rules/facts, you get a different experience than games that allow you to make up rules on the spot, or at least more freely. That in AW it is a rule that whatever someone makes up in response to a game question is as true as prep or rules. But it's a case of AWs procedures being different, ultimately; AW has rules about how to generate new rules, just like 2097e. But as to whether the experience is different, well, duh, of course it is because the point is that the different rules systems generate different experiences. That is the point of different rule systems.

      Note that the rules propositions of 2097e do in fact require the procedures Sandra has created, because in such a system the GM is limited just as the players are: the rules are all that the world is, and the GM is given no leeway to alter the world-state (the rules) beyond what has been allowed or what the system instructs us in how to create. But you know, so does Apocalypse World. It's just the tolerances are different and they aim at different experiences: but you can maybe see that the main differences is "how much of the world/rulestate is encoded at the beginning" and also the procedures for generating new rules.

      As to the central question of the thread, I'll leave it to people who know theory rather than this simple big-city girl who mostly just likes to run games. It does seem to me that analyzing rules and procedures in terms of how they alter the rulestate may help us see which principles work better for which type of experience. Furthermore, deciding just what the heck "experience" means and the typology of what they look like I leave to smarter people like Sandra who you know created a whole canonical theory of it including friendship bonds. I mean, you could make AW style playbooks out of it; it states things well. Looking at places where experiences and expectations blend may show where blended rulestate systems might be acceptable; examining the furthest ends of the spectrums will help determine maybe what those principles look like. And you know, Sandra did that in this thread, I think?** Except for maybe hating on Lady Blackbird, but that's like Glenn Gould hating on Mozart, which never kept Gould from being a freaking genius


      *The Laws of Saliency further follow the principle "wovon man nicht regieren kann, dar\xfcber m\xfcssen die Regeln schweigen" in the Wallpaper principle.

      **I got my MA in Literary Theory and walked away without a look back, save my post-two-beers rants about how Bakhtin can be used to expose the fundamental generic flaw in The Lord of the Rings.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 11 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n(I think ya'll are successfully convincing me that "game state is all the operands of the rules" is a more useful concept than "the minimal additional logical structure beyond the SIS".)

      My own personal takeaways from these 600 posts, plus a few hundred others in various related threads:\n
        \n
      1. Games have Game State beyond the Shared Imagined Space: all the concepts and relations needed to enact the game's rules.
        2. \n
      2. The Philosophy of Blorb holds the Game State outside of the Shared Imagined Space is of first-class importance. That it is useful, desirable, and productive to engage the un-shared State in both play and design.
        3. \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nNeurotrash \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n


      @2097 said:

      In Swedish we have an expression.

      Don\u2019t go cross the river to fetch water.

      Instead of going all the way out to this extra-SIS (the MIS) to validate all your SIS operations, you can operate directly on the MIS since it is a strict superset of the SIS, just with a shared-p flippable bit.
      \nI've read this several times and still have trouble understanding what you're saying.

      Can you give an example of "going to the MIS to validate your SIS operations"?

      Can you give an example of "operating directly on the MIS"? And how it's different than the above?

      Can you explain the "shared-p flippable" bit?

      What I think you're trying to say is instead of consulting the GameState to see what does or does not get added to the SIS, you should just think of it as interacting with the GameState directly. But that's never what is happening when you are actually engaged in playing an rpg.

      As I understand it, interacting directly with the GameState would be something like marking off hitpoints. If there's a rule that says, "When a character is at zero HP, the character dies," and the DM sees your HP count, makes that translation to fiction, and announces, "You're at zero HP. You're character is dead." Your character is now dead in the SIS.

      But the character didn't die in the SIS until the DM consulted the GameState (the character sheet says "zero HP") and translated it into fiction, then communicated that fiction (via speech or holding up the sheet for everyone to see, it doesn't matter what form the communication takes) to the players.\n
      In my model, making something that's in the game state known isn't a radical change to that thing. You had the cake. You still have the cake, only now it's a cake that people know about.
      \nBut you're still consulting the GameState in order to decide what's allowed in the SIS in that case.

      I see no difference between:

      "The cake was part of the gamestate and wasn't known about, but then I told you about it so it's part of the SIS"

      and

      "We wanted to add [what was in the fridge] to the SIS, so the DM consulted the GameState and told us [what was in the fridge], and thus it was added.

      How are they different, other than one is from the point of view of the DM and the other is from the POV of the players?
