    \n

    Narrativism vs traditional techniques

    \n
    \xab1\u2026891011121314\xbb

    Comments

      \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nThanuir \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Neurotrash said:


      I see no difference between:

      "The cake was part of the gamestate and wasn't known about, but then I told you about it so it's part of the SIS"

      and

      "We wanted to add [what was in the fridge] to the SIS, so the DM consulted the GameState and told us [what was in the fridge], and thus it was added.

      How are they different, other than one is from the point of view of the DM and the other is from the POV of the players?

      \nThere is a motive in the second one, but not the first one. The first one should have a motive like "We wanted to know what was in the fridge...".

      ...

      There are two approaches to game design here.

      If you take the approach that mostly the shared imagined space matters, then you are more likely to design games with shared narration, or with Apocalypse world -style triggered moves.
      You can still have a game with unknown established facts; in Apocalypse world, you still draw maps (even if they have blanks) and respect the preparation and so on.

      If you take the approach that the game state is what matters the most, including the non-shared parts, then it is inconvenient to design games with widely shared narration because everyone with narrational authority has to respect the fiction, and this is more challenging to accomplish. (Go ahead and prove me wrong by design.)
      You are more likely to design fictional content, rather than only procedures: consider how useful an adventure is in D&D when compared to Primetime adventures, to take an extreme example.

      A definite game state is more useful if you want to design a game where the players solve a mystery or a puzzle, or reveal a secret. The focus on shared imagined space is more fruitful if you want a game where the players create a mystery. The shared imagined space approach is more fruitful, in the short run, if you want the play to create a particular kind of story, or even a particular story, though in the long run you might notice that you have painted yourself into a corner.

      This is not to say that you could not achieve any of the stated goals with either design approach; I am only saying that some are more natural for a particular approach.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n edited June 12
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n@Jeph, thank you for that very satisfying summary!\n
      Neurotrash said:

      What I think you\u2019re trying to say is instead of consulting the GameState to see what does or does not get added to the SIS, you should just think of it as interacting with the GameState directly.

      Yes, that\u2019s how you should think of it, that\u2019s the takeaway. Here\u2019s an example of that happening:\n
      Neurotrash said:

      \u201cWe wanted to add [what was in the fridge] to the SIS, so the DM consulted the GameState and told us [what was in the fridge], and thus it was added.

      That\u2019s right. There was something in the fridge that was unknown to us. By us finding out what that thing was, one thing changed about it: it is now known to us. It has been shared-p.

      That\u2019s our model.\n
      Neurotrash said:

      But that\u2019s never what is happening when you are actually engaged in playing an rpg.

      Did you see the post about the difference between make-believe \u201clet\u2019s pretend that the floor is lava\u201d and yarn-spinning \u201cthis is a story about a family of birds who live in a forest. who is their friend?\u201d.

      Some games (never \u201ctraditional techniques\u201d games of any complexity, not even AW, but some shorter very hippiefied li\u2019l story-games) have an apparent rule set that truly are implemented solely on the yarn-spinning level. They\u2019re phrased as partipipants make statement according to a set of criteria on those statements. But even these games, the way they work, what makes them fly, is that the participants start constructing this big old world in their heads which helps them to remember things, to reincorporate things, and most of all: helps them to care about things.

      For the \u201cno myth\u201d stuff to be true, they\u2019d instead see it as \u201cThere was nothing in the fridge until we opened it. Then the DM looked at her prep, saw that it had '(fridge (container shelves cake electricity)), consulted the rule about examining container-p items, and created a cake by adding it to the the SIS.\u201d

      That model, because of Turing completeness, can also create the same outcomes as our model but it\u2019s utterly cumbersome.

      The \u201ccloset language theorem\u201d variant of the model made a bolder & wronger claim and with that model, the only type of fridge/gameplay that would be allowed is \u201cThere was nothing in the fridge until we opened it. The GM had a 100% blank mind. Heard that we opened a fridge and tried to make up something that would be good to be stored in a fridge. She came up with a cake.\u201d Because as soon as you have any inkling of what type of imagined cakes or whatever are in there, you are creating referents. So the \u201ccloset language theorem\u201d applies to pretty much no game ever.\n
      Neurotrash said:

      As I understand it, interacting directly with the GameState would be something like marking off hitpoints.

      That\u2019s right.

      Here are some ways to interact directly with the game state:\n
      • moving from room to room in the dungeon
      • opening chests
      • chopping each other with swords
      • marking off hitpoints
      • dying
      Neurotrash said:

      If there\u2019s a rule that says, \u201cWhen a character is at zero HP, the character dies,\u201d and the DM sees your HP count, makes that translation to fiction, and announces, \u201cYou\u2019re at zero HP. You\u2019re character is dead.\u201d Your character is now dead in the SIS.

      More likely it\u2019d be the player saying that to the DM rather than the other way around but that\u2019s a minor nitpic

      That\u2019s right. The character was dead as soon as that HP reached 0. And by announcing it, the shared-p bit on that death is flipped. Which is of some relevance, but not as momentously fundamental as it would\u2019ve been with the no-myth model.

      Here\u2019s another story. The character dies in the gamestate but only one person at the table, that character\u2019s player, knows about it yet, so according to the whole LBCBP stuff it hasn\u2019t been added to the SIS. The player sits in shock, dumbfounded. The rest of the party goes into the next room. \u201cAlice\u201d, Bob says, \u201caren\u2019t you coming with?\u201d \u201cI\u2019m dead, you blockhead!\u201d Alice says. Now it\u2019s added to the SIS. The whole \u201cadding to the SIS\u201d part wasn\u2019t unimportant but the death itself was the thing.\n
      Neurotrash said:

      But you\u2019re still consulting the GameState in order to decide what\u2019s allowed in the SIS in that case.

      Which is utterly cumbersome.\n
      Operating on the SIS but consulting the game state
      \u201cI need to create what\u2019s in the fridge. I\u2019ll look at the game state to see what I have to create.\u201d
      Operating on the game state directly
      \u201cThere\u2019s a cake in this fridge. I\u2019ll tell them about it.\u201d
      The SIS is like the computer screen. A game designed strictly according to LBCBP principles would like designing a game where all the code resides in, or is called by, the screen drawing routines. That\u2019s just bad design. Also no such game exists if it has the slightest bit of traditional techniques. I called AW a disciplined design in the other thread but then I remembered that you also need \u201cplayers\u201d who have \u201ccharacters\u201d and those characters\u2019 gear sure as heckfire isn\u2019t defined solely in the \u201cscreen drawing routines\u201d; they are stand alone objects. Although Dungeon World comes close with its \u201cadventuring gear\u201d rule on 328. Which\u2026 isn\u2019t that rule kind of unsatsifying and pointless? It wholly de-tangibilitifies the sensation of having gear.\n
      Aviatrix said:

      Note that the rules propositions of 2097e do in fact require the procedures Sandra has created, because in such a system the GM is limited just as the players are: the rules are all that the world is, and the GM is given no leeway to alter the world-state (the rules) beyond what has been allowed or what the system instructs us in how to create.

      That\u2019s right. @Aviatrix played with our group for the first time yesterday and got to see our game: a pale, flickering, kinda crappy cave-wall shadow cast by the blazing blorb ideal.

      Including a mistake correction! I had forgotten that the players had destroyed a trapped statue when they visited a room previously.

      And, a \u201cmirror story\u201d! I got salty af when one of the deadliest traps of all time was utterly defanged by a cantrip \n
      Aviatrix said:

      But you know, so does Apocalypse World. It\u2019s just the tolerances are different and they aim at different experiences: but you can maybe see that the main differences is \u201chow much of the world/rulestate is encoded at the beginning\u201d and also the procedures for generating new rules.

      Yes.
      It too has a game state in our model.
      Almost all games do; our model doesn\u2019t just apply to full-blorb games.
      (Some games have very unblorby rules about creating&injecting entities into that gamestate. I.o.w. \u201cmaking things up as you go along\u201d vs \u201cadhering to prep\u201d.)\n
      Aviatrix said:

      The Laws of Saliency further follow the principle \u201cwovon man nicht regieren kann, dar\xfcber m\xfcssen die Regeln schweigen\u201d in the Wallpaper principle.

      They\u2019re not that schweigen since wallpaper can become salient.

      PS @Aviatrix: when I suggested that you toss the bag I had utterly forgotten abut the flasks in it. It was only the vivid image of a bag landing on stone that made me think \u201cWait, weren\u2019t there some flasks in that bag?\u201d So I myself made the same mistake that Birdsong did. (The vivid imagination\u2014shared or not\u2014is an amazingly important part of game state!)

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Thanuir said:

      If you take the approach that the game state is what matters the most, including the non-shared parts, then it is inconvenient to design games with widely shared narration because everyone with narrational authority has to respect the fiction, and this is more challenging to accomplish. (Go ahead and prove me wrong by design.)

      I will.

      You only need to put in very different, very unblorby rules about when & how you are allowed to create&inject things into the game state.\n
      • More \u201cgenerous\u201d than blorb about when&how in some ways (for example there\u2019s no \u201cNo Paper after seeing Rock\u201d principle)
      • Less \u201cgenerous\u201d than blorb about when&how in some ways (for example the offscreen gamestate has to be lightly held)
      Thanuir said:

      The focus on shared imagined space is more fruitful if you want a game where the players create a mystery.

      Lovecraftesque and Nerver av st\xe5l being good examples of games being created because their designers were influenced by the lumplian \u201cSIS-is-primary\u201d model. So it\u2019s clear that their model has been fruitful in terms of design.

      But their designs can be made with our model as well:

      In a 2097 while writing a module: \u201cHmm maybe I\u2019ll add a troll to this room on the map? Naw\u2026\u201d The troll wasn\u2019t injected into the game state and thus was never canon. [@Jeph: An example of a referent being created without having its symbolic representation be part of the game state!]

      Similarly, in Nerver av st\xe5l: \u201cHmm, maybe I\u2019ll reveal that silver tongue is a runaway nun, escaped from a convent\u201d and then later play leads to a state where she never is or was a runaway nun, because just as 2097e has you inject (or not inject, in this case) trolls in the game state at prep time, Nerver av st\xe5l has you inject (or not inject, in this case) runaway nuns into the game state at utterance time.

      Both games have rules about creating&injecting entities into the game state; just very different rules.

      (Not all of our model\u2019s rules are applied at prep time; the characters moving from room to room is an example of in-play game-state changing.)

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAlexanderWhite \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n@2097 I know we agree on a lot but I\u2019m still trying to hammer out exactly where we diverge because I think any disagreement could be fruitful.

      So has anyone seen game sessions like this.

      The goal of everyone is to make a story but people are kind of, well, not that engaged. They\u2019re all making fiction but there is no actual sense of tension, urgency or consequence. It\u2019s almost like an intellectual exercise. Occasionally things come together and produce an alright story but the process of getting there isn\u2019t that great. You\u2019ll get players trying to be interesting by engaging in hi-jinx, because otherwise play is just kind of dull. If there\u2019s a GM they often compensate by introducing something crazy or trying to ramp up the tension, but it never really works. At best you get these kind of good improvisational bits in a sea of tedium.

      We\u2019ll call this the Thespian problem.

      Does Blorb solve the Thespian problem? In some cases it does.

      Does Apocalypse World solve the Thespian problem? No it absolutely does not. In fact Narrativist design can\u2019t solve it because Narrativist games are for people that don\u2019t have the Thespian problem.

      I think we both agree so far?

      Where we might diverge.

      If you don\u2019t have the Thespian problem then adding blorb might in fact be slightly detrimental.

      The Thespian problem is in fact a problem and not normal Narrativist play. (This is hard because we don\u2019t want to judge fun but.. I\u2019ve been in groups of Narrativists that, well let\u2019s say they like a very laid back game rather than an intense one.)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n@AlexanderWhite
      You "add blorb" by changing the rules on how and when entities can be created&injected into the game state. If you have traditional techniques you are already using rules about how and when entities can be created&injected into the game state. I propose to either make those rules more blorb-compliant in order to make the rules about how and when entities can be created&injected into the game state carry their weight; or to ditch those rules, kick off your shoes and go hippie.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAlexanderWhite \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n@2097 We do disagree then.

      My claims are:

      If your gaming is broken then going blorb might fix it.

      If your gaming is working great, I see no reason why blorb would add much.*

      *well not no reason, but I think that\u2019s a minor technical debate to be determined on a case by case basis.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n To make it awesomer
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAlexanderWhite \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      2097 said:

      To make it awesomer

      \nDo you have any evidence that that\u2019s the case?

      If you thought your play was awesome before the mirror story but even more awesome after, you can use yourself as an example.

      If you thought your play was kind of crappy before the mirror story, then you can\u2019t.

      (not trying to be judgy or anything, I\u2019ve been in situations where I\u2019ve had years of crappy play, blorb was in fact a partial solution for me)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      AlexanderWhite said:

      If you thought your play was awesome before the mirror story but even more awesome after, you can use yourself as an example.

      If you thought your play was kind of crappy before the mirror story, then you can\u2019t.

      I can both!

      I ain\u2019t the sharpest tool in the shed so for many years I had no idea that anything even remotely like blorb could exist.

      For many many years I thought \u201cthis is as good as it\u2019s gonna get, and I love it! Ergo ain\u2019t nothing crappy about it!\u201d about my play.

      And then I heard a few stories about somethings that had happened in someone\u2019s play and I was like \u201cYou did what?\u201d Emergent dice stories like crashing a helicopter or sacrificing yourself & your squadron of X-wings to save a rebel cruiser. Now, we had some awesome narrative twists in our game but they were cooked up by us. They didn\u2019t feel \u201creal\u201d emergent.

      And I started seeing the cracks, that there was some kind of mismatch or incoherence between the traditional techniques (i.e.\xa0player / DM separation) and the lacuna-where-the-gloracle-should-have-been. The chasm-width problem reared its ugly head!

      And I was unhappy for years until I found blorb.

      So. Happy for years (not crappy),
      unhappy for years (kindof crappy),
      first one, then the other,
      ergo: both!

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDeReel \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Thanks for the summaries.

      "the actual pieces are signifiers (the SIS/the fact space/the concrete) which help us remember and track the game state (with all its functioning at the abstract level)"
      To me, the best part with this model is not the game state (we already knew how to manage hidden information etc.) It's that it provides a standing point to have a look at the SIS from a distance. And see a Shared Imagination is an unicorn.

      \n\nNeurotrash \n\n\n

      \n
      DeReel said:


      To me, the best part with this model is not the game state (we already knew how to manage hidden information etc.) It's that it provides a standing point to have a look at the SIS from a distance. And see a Shared Imagination is an unicorn.

      \nCan you explain that more fully?

      \n
      \n\nDeReel \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I thought SIS meant "shared imagined space" literally. It appears that it's a term that means "the public part of the game state". Not to derail this thread, I made another one here.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I am not convinced that the way people are talking about a "game-state" clarifies more than it muddles, particularly because it is being used to mean variously and possibly simultaneously (1) hidden fictional ("in-game") information about the game-world that someone during play is imagined to to wish to privilege; (2) information that is supposed to be purely game-mechanical (seemingly without, that is to say, a corresponding representation in the fiction; this may have implications for the idea of "dissociated mechanics"); and (3) fictional attributes of a character that nonetheless affect the options available to the corresponding player (e.g., "You're dead"). Some people seem to use it to differentiate fictional events from game-mechanical epiphenomena, while others include fictional events in the game-state so long as they have some game-mechanical import. I suppose that there is some value in calling attention to the toy features of play, but the reification of "game-state" that's happening in at least this thread deserves some more conceptual interrogation.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n edited June 12
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n It's the idea that we're playing a game of let's pretend together and through the life-changing magic of rules, we can do that without just limiting ourselves to things that have been stated & "added to the fiction in conversation".

      We can have a cake in a fridge without the fridge having been opened.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nThanuir \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      2097 said:

      Thanuir said:

      If you take the approach that the game state is what matters the most, including the non-shared parts, then it is inconvenient to design games with widely shared narration because everyone with narrational authority has to respect the fiction, and this is more challenging to accomplish. (Go ahead and prove me wrong by design.)

      I will.

      You only need to put in very different, very unblorby rules about when & how you are allowed to create&inject things into the game state.\n
      • More \u201cgenerous\u201d than blorb about when&how in some ways (for example there\u2019s no \u201cNo Paper after seeing Rock\u201d principle)
      • Less \u201cgenerous\u201d than blorb about when&how in some ways (for example the offscreen gamestate has to be lightly held)
      \n
      \nIf there is secret information and wide narration rights, then the narrators have to somehow dodge that secret information. Sure, it can be done, and would be fruitful design ground, but it is not the natural way to go.

      (Example rule: When you finally test whether they are a witch or not, flip the five cards. If more than half of them are red, he was a witch. Players have some means that let them see a single card from the heap of five and then shuffle it.
      Another example rule: Only I get to say things about dwarfs.)\n
      Bill_White said:

      I am not convinced that the way people are talking about a "game-state" clarifies more than it muddles, particularly because it is being used to mean variously and possibly simultaneously (1) hidden fictional ("in-game") information about the game-world that someone during play is imagined to to wish to privilege; (2) information that is supposed to be purely game-mechanical (seemingly without, that is to say, a corresponding representation in the fiction; this may have implications for the idea of "dissociated mechanics"); and (3) fictional attributes of a character that nonetheless affect the options available to the corresponding player (e.g., "You're dead"). Some people seem to use it to differentiate fictional events from game-mechanical epiphenomena, while others include fictional events in the game-state so long as they have some game-mechanical import. I suppose that there is some value in calling attention to the toy features of play, but the reification of "game-state" that's happening in at least this thread deserves some more conceptual interrogation.

      \nI agree that clarity with respect to

      1. The game mechanical state, i.e. which game mechanical claims are true. (My character has 16 strength. You have four tokens.)
      2. The state of the fiction, i.e. which claims about the fiction are true. (The dragon is angry at Kalervo. The city is 17 kilometres from the dungeon.)
      3. Other claims that are true, but not part of the previous categories, supposing they exist. (???)

      would be useful.

      Another classification is

      a. Things shared among and known by all the participants.
      b. Things known by only a single participant.
      c. Things not known to any participant.
      d. Other subsets of "who knows what".

      I think at this point is has been settled that the gamestate includes 1. I am not sure if it has been settled that it includes 2; I think it holds that in traditional roleplaying games it will turn out to include 2 if it includes 1, because the border is fuzzy, whereas in some formal games 1 and 2 might be disjoint. I do not know if 3 is meaningful or non-empty. My suggestion is to define the game state as 1 and see what follows.

      The shared imagined space seems to be the intersection of 2 and a (or 2 and d, perhaps); I'll just abbreviate it as 2a (and ignore the complications of d, which are unlikely to be conceptually interesting).

      All combinations of 1-2 and a-c are meaningful.

      1a: The game master has declared that the giant is wearing a maille and has armour class 16. We can all see that you have a deeds artha, since the red token in front of you means that.
      1b: The giant has 54 hit points. We just started playing and everyone has made their character separately. Only you know that your character has lockpicking skill 65.
      1c: We use an online random character generation. Your character is there, you have copied it, but nobody has read it yet. The game master has placed a module in their sandbox but has not read through (all of) it, yet, and so does not know the stats of various creatures therein. (I have done the latter. There is one such module in my sandbox right now.)
      2a: My character is hiding under the bed. I have said so.
      2b: I have decided that my character has a tattoo on their back, but this has not come up in play yet.
      2c: The adventure module the GM has not entirely read through contains many examples.

      No myth play is saying that 1a and 2a (and possibly 1b or 1c, but certainly not 2b or 2c) are relevant for play. Blorb/klokkverk is saying that all the combinations of 1-2, a-c, are relevant.

      I am, on purpose, glossing over the detail about classifying things that were known but have been forgotten by someone or everyone.

      ...

      If this is useful, maybe someone wants to give good names for some of the categories above.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill\u2019s post, above, describes my concerns/objections pretty well. I\u2019m not sure I have much to add. I\u2019m not at all convinced that any two people are even talking about the same thing yet. That makes it harder to engage!

      I do have some questions, though. Hopefully these will help people refine their thinking:

      1. What, in practical terms, does this model or way of thinking give us that the following doesn\u2019t?

      * This game gives certain players the authority to prep certain information, and that prep must be honoured when we play.

      (If the answer is, \u201cnothing yet; we\u2019re still exploring!\u201d, that\u2019s totally fine, by the way. Do carry on - I\u2019m all for exploring other ways of thinking. )

      2. How, in this model, can we explain what\u2019s happening when a mistake is made and isn\u2019t noticed?

      For instance, the GM misreads \u201cgreen goblin\u201d as \u201cgreen dragon\u201d, and we play out the session. A green dragon is fought and lots of stuff happens.

      a. We discover this much later, and have decide whether to retcon a good deal of gameplay (after all, lots hit points and other effects could have affected all kinds of long term developments since then). What if we decide it\u2019s too difficult and complicated to do so? What if the players argue that they legitimately fought a green dragon, risked their lives, and won - that it wouldn\u2019t fair to rescind the XP awards they received as a result?

      b. Perhaps even more telling, when it comes to the nature of the \u201cmodel\u201d, what if the group never notices the error, at all? How do we describe/explain the resulting play, in this model or this way of thinking?

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      2097 said:

      It's the idea that we're playing a game of let's pretend together and through the life-changing magic of rules, we can do that without just limiting ourselves to things that have been stated & "added to the fiction in conversation".

      \nSee, here's the thing. From my perspective, playing a game of let's pretend together is functionally equivalent to saying fictional things in conversation. Without that step, we're not doing it together. The idea that you can make it so that the rules of the game obviate the centrality of that step seems likely to be wrong to me.

      I am reminded of the story of the three umpires--these are the referees in the American sport of baseball who are charged with determining if the ball thrown by the pitcher has entered the batter's "strike zone," in which case the batter's failure to hit it counts against their three strikes, or whether it has not entered the strike zone, in which case the batter's refusal to swing is good judgment, since after a certain number of such "balls," the batter is allowed to advance to first base. Anyway, the three umpires are discussing their craft, and the first one says, "They're either balls or they're strikes, and I call 'em as they are." The second umpire shakes his head and says, "Well, some are balls and some are strikes, and I call 'em as I see 'em." The third umpire takes a minute to finish his beer, and then he says, "They ain't nothing until I call 'em."

      The point of the story in this case is of course that rules require interpretation, and so where interpretive authority lies and how it's legitimated are important issues in making sense of how games that are like RPGs work.\n
      We can have a cake in a fridge without the fridge having been opened.
      \nBut isn't it more complicated than that? There's no actual fridge, only propositions about fridges and their contents that one or more people at the table are authorized to make. If you make a note to yourself, "There's cake in the fridge here," it's in the expectation that others will ask you, "What's in the fridge?" rather than assume that the contents are somehow "typical" fridge contents or tell you what's in the fridge. To the extent that what's in the fridge is different from what they expect--"Hey, there's cake in here!"--it might matter to them because of what it tells them about what's going on ("Ah, someone's planning a birthday party!") or because it's potentially helpful ("I'm starving! I eat the cake!") or harmful ("Yuck! I'm allergic to chocolate!"). If none of those things are true, and it's just an extraneous detail of no particular significance, then why does anyone care whether there's cake or not in the fridge?

      [1] "What's in the fridge?"

      [2] "What do you think is going to be in the fridge?"

      [3] "Some moldy cheese, expired milk, and brown lettuce, probably."

      [4] "No! There's cake!"

      [5] "Really? Why?"

      [6] "Because that's what I decided before you opened the door! The cake was in there the whole time! Doesn't the world feel more real?"

      Maybe no one would ever ask [5], but [6] doesn't seem to me to be a satisfying answer in any case. To be fair, I suppose an alternative response could be:

      [6a] "Because that's consistent with what has previously been established in the game-world, but there's no other value, meaning, or importance that should be ascribed to that proposition."

      This is where the issue of salience pops up, which seems to me to be asking something like what if I say there's cake in the fridge and somehow it matters when I didn't expect it to? My own answer would be, great, wow, what clever players! what fun and interesting play!

      So, I love the description of three tiers of prep to ensure internal consistency and diegetic coherence; that's a really valuable procedural insight. But seeking to assign GM-prepped information some sort of ontological priority in and of itself in the absence of attention to how authority is distributed around the table strikes me as conceptually unsound. It's very similar to my mind to how some OSR-adjacent gamers use the idea of a "world in motion" to avoid the idea that their game is "fictional."

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul I have answered that exact green dragon green goblin question a few times now, and I\u2019ve discussed this whole error handling red herring at length in a few posts. Maybe it got lost in the flood. That\u2019s fine, I\u2019ll sort it out for ya:

      You asked it two days ago and here is my answer then, it also links to this, which is the longest and most detailed answer.

      Even that wasn\u2019t the first time I answered it, here is the first answer; a short & concise answer that\u2019s still good. (Uses the \u201cforget to do double damage\u201d example instead of \u201cmisreads green goblin as green dragon\u201d example.)\n
      Paul_T said:

      1. What, in practical terms, does this model or way of thinking give us that the following doesn\u2019t?

      * This game gives certain players the authority to prep certain information, and that prep must be honoured when we play.

      The new model allows us to make a lot of rules about how and when to add/change information in the game state, including but not limited at campaign start, between sessions, in play etc.

      Like, OK so someone once wrote this Yahtzee principle:\n
      The Yahtzee Principle said:

      You can point to the pages of your book all you want to. You can imagine stuff in your head all you want to.

      The fact is that nothing happens, in the dice tray of role-playing, unless someone rolls it and the number on the die face is seen. Even if the book says, \u201cOn a critical hit, you do double damage,\u201d your character won\u2019t actually do double damage on a critical hit unless someone recognizes it and rolls it.

      Role-playing is made of rolling dice like apple pie is made of apples and crust and scary amounts of butter. Whatever fiction you use, you are agreeing to use it among the group, usually as a creative inspiration or constraint, specifically as a way to affect what dice are going to be rolled.

      \u201cSystem (including but not limited to \u2018the rules\u2019) is defined as the means by which the group agrees to roll dice during play.\u201d

      And like that\u2019s cool, that\u2019s cool. That\u2019s one way of looking at things\u2026.

      And that design school created a bunch of various dice system. The Whispering Vault, that weird Godlike system, Otherkind dice, Burning Wheel with all of those traitor dice, Gumshoe\u2019s minimalist 1d6, or Prince Valiant and Ubiquity with their d2 pools, and Fudge/Fate with their custom dice, not to mention Genesys\u2026 and then someone is like ok, ok, we get it, the dice part of the resolution is interesting and fun to design things around, but we want to design the actual, you know, talking part? Can that also be part of the system? And we can actually resolve things without rolling dice?

      And let\u2019s say that the response then is\n
      1. What, in practical terms, does this model or way of thinking give us that the following doesn\u2019t?
      • This game gives certain players the authority to create certain fiction, and that fiction must be honoured when we roll dice.
      And we (modern audience that know that not all RPG design is about coming up with the coolest dice system \u201cno, I like BELL CURVES\u201d) go slackjawed in disbelief\u2026 Like\u2026 a lot? and not all RPG design is about coming up with the best way t o talk either. The game state is something that we want to create a variety of interesting operations on.

      Our model is fundamental in order to create a rich variety in how we work with the other parts of the experience that aren\u2019t just rolling dice (Yahtzee principle) or talking (LBCBP).

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\n2097 \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Bill_White said:

      See, here\u2019s the thing. From my perspective, playing a game of let\u2019s pretend together is functionally equivalent to saying fictional things in conversation. Without that step, we\u2019re not doing it together. The idea that you can make it so that the rules of the game obviate the centrality of that step seems likely to be wrong to me.

      So we used to do these big larps. In old ruins, mansions or whatever. We did one in a decomissioned nuclear power plant once.

      And no one person knows EVERYTHING that\u2019s being said at the larp. But we\u2019re all on the same \u201cstage\u201d. That\u2019s why I mean with the MIS or game-state.

      And maybe Alice and Bob are talking in one room and then later Bob and Carol are talking in another room. It\u2019s not multiple games going on. It\u2019s the same MIS.\n
      Bill_White said:

      The point of the story in this case is of course that rules require interpretation, and so where interpretive authority lies and how it\u2019s legitimated are important issues in making sense of how games that are like RPGs work.

      OK. And now we want to look at some other important issues that have been overlooked by theory at this level. A lot of OSR design work is sorta in the same vein.\n
      Bill_White said:

      Bill_White said:

      We can have a cake in a fridge without the fridge having been opened.

      But isn\u2019t it more complicated than that? There\u2019s no actual fridge, only propositions about fridges and their contents that one or more people at the table are authorized to make. If you make a note to yourself, \u201cThere\u2019s cake in the fridge here,\u201d
      Then there is cake in the fridge in the game state.\n
      Bill_White said:

      it\u2019s in the expectation that others will ask you, \u201cWhat\u2019s in the fridge?\u201d rather than assume that the contents are somehow \u201ctypical\u201d fridge contents or tell you what\u2019s in the fridge. To the extent that what\u2019s in the fridge is different from what they expect\u2013\u201cHey, there\u2019s cake in here!\u201d\u2013it might matter to them because of what it tells them about what\u2019s going on (\u201cAh, someone\u2019s planning a birthday party!\u201d) or because it\u2019s potentially helpful (\u201cI\u2019m starving! I eat the cake!\u201d) or harmful (\u201cYuck! I\u2019m allergic to chocolate!\u201d). If none of those things are true, and it\u2019s just an extraneous detail of no particular significance, then why does anyone care whether there\u2019s cake or not in the fridge?

      Hence wallpaper saliency principle. We care about salient things and we can improvise non-salient things.\n
      Bill_White said:

      [6] \u201cBecause that\u2019s what I decided before you opened the door! The cake was in there the whole time! Doesn\u2019t the world feel more real?\u201d

      Having an offscreen gamestate not only makes the world feel significantly more real. It also enables a completely new form of diceless resolution that just can\u2019t be done without it. (\u201c20 questions with a door knob\u201d a.k.a. finchian trap finding.)\n
      Bill_White said:

      This is where the issue of salience pops up, which seems to me to be asking something like what if I say there\u2019s cake in the fridge and somehow it matters when I didn\u2019t expect it to? My own answer would be, great, wow, what clever players! what fun and interesting play!

      Yeah, I do love it. Maybe you\u2019re thinking of the tar example here. I felt that the resolution protocol broke down a bit. SMH at how modules sometimes go into deep detail about something that I would\u2019ve easily & gladly improvised without colliding with any saliency principles but they skip details on secret doors & traps. But that\u2019s just another example of how the design work we are doing here will hopefully end up being useful to module writers and game designers and why this model is important & good. Because they\u2019ll learn to write traps & secret doors up properly.

      The tar in that example became salient in a way that hindered the players, not helped them, for the record.\n
      Bill_White said:

      But seeking to assign GM-prepped information some sort of ontological priority in and of itself in the absence of attention to how authority is distributed around the table strikes me as conceptually unsound.

      It\u2019s not unsound, it\u2019s awesome. It\u2019s a different paradigm. The GM must bow to the \u269eGLORACLE\u269f\n
      Bill_White said:

      It\u2019s very similar to my mind to how some OSR-adjacent gamers use the idea of a \u201cworld in motion\u201d to avoid the idea that their game is \u201cfictional.\u201d

      Yes, it\u2019s a similar idea. Remember that the Forge nerds redefined the word \u201cfiction\u201d to something very specific. Which obv the \u201cworld in motion\u201d / the offscreen canon game state / the MIS is a much larger superset to.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      2097 said:

      That\u2019s right. @Aviatrix played with our group for the first time yesterday and got to see our game: a pale, flickering, kinda crappy cave-wall shadow cast by the blazing blorb ideal.

      \nCrap, now they'll think I'm cool enough to play with you! Fortunately we both know better!

      (I had a good time. Also an interesting time. But it's better I not say anything without clearing what I can say with @2097 &c.)

      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDeReel \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n edited June 12
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n@Bill_White I agree that social questions (authority, communication, etc.) should be priorities in design. But the fact that "There's no actual fridge, only propositions about fridges and their contents that one or more people at the table are authorized to make." doesn't prevent me from making a side step. Let's pretend there's a fridge, and a cake in it. What can we see and infer from this view point is what matters. Maybe nothing will come out of it. I don't know, let's find out.
      Aviatrix's model conflates the existence and properties of fictional things, and other rules. It looks a lot like the SIS model, but with a clear "algorithmic" perspective.
      @Thanuir To me, the fictional state is part of the game state, but it's hard to communicate and handle, so it gets abstracted and sometimes deformed in the process. I don't know what 3 would be.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      Aviatrix said:

      Crap, now they'll think I'm cool enough to play with you!

      \nMaybe next time I bring in guest players we should do some more workshopping before

      \n\nSilmenume \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n edited June 12
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hello,

      If the GameState can be changed without reference to the SIS then what's to prevent the following from happening?

      Alice - Because she's a sneaky thief and doesn't care for Bob's moralizing writes on her character sheet, "I switch Bob's healing potion with a lethal poison".

      The GameState has been altered but not the SIS.

      Bob - After a nasty and brutal battle crosses out on his sheet "One flask of healing" and returns his dangerously low HP's back to full.

      Again the GameState has been altered but not the SIS.

      Both notes were made before either player had any knowledge of an upcoming ambush.

      According to some of what has been proposed both neither statement needs to be communicated to the SIS as we have authority to operate strictly on the GameState level without need to communicate these writings and thus such notations have automatic credibility. They simply "are."

      Shortly after the notations were made on both sheets and not communicated the GM runs a battle and Bob takes a loss of HPs that put him below zero. The GM says, "You're dead." Bob replies, "No I'm not, I drank my potion of wondrous healing and I was at full HPs. See, I wrote it on my sheet." Alice jumps in and says, "Sorry Bob, I swapped out your potion of Wondrous Healing for a Poison of Instan and Irreversible Lethality. There is no saving throw and no possibility of any form of resurrection."

      Given that we can function at the GameState level without reference to the SIS (as proposed) how is this situation resolved? And what does resolving mean? Is it sufficient that this be handled only at the GameState level with the GM making a notation his pad of paper but never communicating it or does this need to be resolved at the SIS level for the resolution to have credibility?

      Because as the description stands, as I understand it, the actions I described are permissible.

      Best,

      Jay
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAsIf \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n edited June 12
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I'll raise you one, Jay. Many years ago I had a Troublesome Player - a real shit-stirrer - who decided that his character hated hated hated one of my NPCs, so bad that he wanted to kill him. This NPC was a staple character in my D&D world, a character I liked to imagine had plot insurance, though only in a de facto way (Players recognized him as a significant part of the setting, found him useful, returned to him for missions and advice, etc).

      So TP challenges me to a fight, and everyone is excited. We broke from regular session and actually took a day to prepare ourselves for the big duel.

      Next day we assemble at TP's house, and the battle is played out. Wishing to be as impartial as possible, and also to focus on the fight from an "immersed" perspective, I hand over the GM role to one of the other Players. After a few rounds of swapping damage and narrative positioning, TP succeeds in scratching my character's face. He begins smiling deviously. The room goes quiet. Everybody else knows something I do not.

      I ask what's going on. TP reaches into his pocket and pulls out a piece of paper he had written the previous night and had already shared with the other Players. He hands it to me. It reads: "POISON UNDER NAILS."

      I'm required to make a saving throw. I fail. My favorite NPC is dead.

      Ok y'all -- what happened here? Analyze away!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n Yeah, great examples from Jay and AsIf.

      This is where the \u201cgame state\u201d model (or whatever we\u2019re calling it) loses me. Like Jay, above, I can\u2019t even begin to make heads or tails of what\u2019s going on. What\u2019s part of the game state? What\u2019s not? When was it introduced? At what point did it become \u201creal\u201d? (Whereas from a Forgite, Lunpley Principle point of view, it\u2019s crystal clear in every instance.)

      \n
      \n
      \n@Silmenume some things you want to communicate about. The potion has become poison, that's all well & good, and because we have frequent potion poisonings players tend to announce when they drink potions so as to not make this confusing thing happen. But the announcing isn't what makes the potion drinking real. It's just a way to clue everyone else in on the new game state.

      \n
      \n Paul, I believe they're referinging a similar example I had on page eleven about secretly casting Purify Food and Drink.

      Things can enter the game state at prep time and during play. I write "cake in fridge" and now the cake is in game state.\n
      Paul_T said:

      Whereas from a Forgite, Lunpley Principle point of view, it\u2019s crystal clear in every instance.

      \nI've given plenty of examples of things being unclear. Such as the hardholder's hold. It becomes "real" at character creation time.

      Edit: also, Paul, acknowledge the green dragon answer.

      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Is it crystal under the LBCB Principle, Paul?

      'Cause LBCB-wise, we get this:

      Up until AsIf reads the note, his favorite NPC is fine, and TP's character never had poison under his nails.

      When AsIf reads the note, his favorite NPC is poisoned, and TP's character retroactively had poison under his nails the whole time.

      The fuck?

      ...

      Whereas, with Game State:

      When TP writes his note, his character has poison under his nails.

      When TP's character scratches AsIf's favorite NPC, that NPC has been poisoned, but Asif doesn't know it yet.

      When AsIf reads the note, he learns that his favorite NPC has already been poisoned, and that TP's character had poison under his nails the whole time.

      ...

      Before anyone says "But wait, other players read the note," consider a hypothetical version of the scenario where that wasn't the case: nobody but TP had ever seen the note.
      \n

      \n Ok! First of all, @Bill_White is writing some good stuff - so far, I feel like he and I are exactly on the same page regarding all of this. I haven't had enough time to post about any of this really thoughtfully, so I'm glad Bill is doing so with more care and diligence.

      Second, if you feel it's clear under the "gamestate" model, I'd love to hear how you would analyze the other examples (mine and Jay's). It's when breakdowns and errors occur that, in my opinion, the "truth" comes out and the real mechanisms of play are laid bare. Sure, when everything goes well and smoothly, it all seems like it makes sense. What about when it breaks down? Let's look at the problem cases. So far, I can't see how they can even be understood from the gamestate point of view.

      For instance, when did that player write the note, and when did the nails "get poisoned"? What happens if I write, "I poisoned my nails yesterday, before the events of our last session" on a piece of paper? In that instance, "when" did the poison actually get applied to the nails?

      AsIf's story is absolutely clear to me from a BCB Principle perspective (as is Jay's). I can explain how, if you like, though I'm a bit surprised that would be news to anyone. Do ask away if you think there's some kind of sticking point there and we can go through it!

      I don't think any of the LARP examples are an issue, either, except maybe in the case of a LARP a person plays alone and doesn't tell anyone about - the theory does, admittedly, break down if there's only one participant. Not sure if that's a problem, though.

      Third, that brings me to the "green dragon" and poor Sandra being frustrated at me. (Sorry, Sandra! I can't quite keep up with the pace of these discussions at the moment.) I'll try to summarize quickly in the next post...

      (And I have no idea what that note about the hardholder is, Sandra! If it's important, or referring to some previous conversation, let me know, but so far that reference is not ringing any bells for me.)

      Fourth, Cat playing D&D with Sandra is one of the most wonderful bits of news I've received in a while. It makes me all smiles and excitement! (Wish I could have been there!) I'm really looking forward to that dialogue.

      \n\nJune 12 \n edited June 12
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n This adherence to the LBCBP is\u2026 just so Schr\xf6dinger's it's giving me a headache. Gonna pass the ball to the other members of team Game State Model to field a couple of goals here (uh I don't know sports did I do it right?)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nSilmenume \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Jeph said:

      Is it crystal under the LBCB Principle, Paul?

      'Cause LBCB-wise, we get this:

      Up until AsIf reads the note, his favorite NPC is fine, and TP's character never had poison under his nails.

      When AsIf reads the note, his favorite NPC is poisoned, and TP's character retroactively had poison under his nails the whole time.

      The fuck?

      \nHere's the problem with @Aslf that makes for an imperfect example. The player with the poison apparently communicated his possession of the poison and how it was prepared with other players. It entered into the SIS. The NPC died that too was entered the SIS. The other players had already been given knowledge of the note before game and that the PC had both the poison and applied it at the appropriate time was given credibility by the other players. The LBCB Principle was still employed. Aslf could accept the ruling of the DM pro-tem - LBCBP in action. As a person Aslf could contest this and a big argument could break out and after hours of fighting decide that yes, he agrees that the statement "Your character is dead" is credible and thus it enters the SIS - LBCB Principle. Aslf could refuse the outcome there is no consensus and the game grinds to a halt until a consensus is reached (the NPC is alive, dead, the provenance of the poison is shown to never have been run through the SIS [IOW the player of the poisoner cheated by putting poison on his sheet without seeking credibility], etc.) - LBCBP. Whatever happened in this particular example does stem from actions occurring in SIS and the result was entered into the SIS.

      The real problem is as Jeff indicated - the provenance of the poison. If the poisoner never passed the method through which he gained possession of a poison through the SIS then said player cheated WRT to standard gameplay theory. Unless there was a Rule that allowed him to propose and allow himself full credibility without communication the Proposition that he possessed a poison ex-nihilo. If the provenance of the poison was handled properly then Aslf is out of a beloved NPC.

      Best,

      Jay
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n edited June 12
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n No, it has nothing to do with the knowledge of the poison entering the SIS. It has nothing to do with whether the other players knew about the note.

      (EDIT: Or, wait, I thought we were disagreeing, but maybe we're not? Are we saying exactly the same thing?)

      Suppose AsIf's group has the rule, "reasonable actions that players write down on paper are true, even if nobody's read them yet."

      Suppose AsIf's story was exactly as he'd written it, EXCEPT that TP had written his note, but not shared it with anyone.

      It still works exactly the same way.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n edited June 12
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      2097 said:

      Paul I have answered that exact green dragon green goblin question a few times now, and I\u2019ve discussed this whole error handling red herring at length in a few posts. Maybe it got lost in the flood. That\u2019s fine, I\u2019ll sort it out for ya:

      \nI think I've read and reread those posts four or five times now, but, no, I don't feel they address my basic question or the examples at all.

      In those posts:

      I hear you reiterating your model, explaining in different ways. Helpful, sure.

      I hear you explaining that mistakes can and do happen in any manner of play. Cool!

      I hear you showing and explaining how you might go about correcting such mistakes. Great!

      But none of that is what I was trying to get at. I want to know:

      * Let's look at a failure case (a "mistake"), such as the ones I've suggested.
      * Let's assume that, in our example, it never gets corrected at all. Whether because the players don't notice, or because they decide it's not worth the trouble - it doesn't matter, as far as I can see.
      * How do we analyze/describe/understand what happened in such a failure case from the standpoint of this new theoretical framework?

      That's what I want to see. I think it will be quite instructive.

      I actually think that the "2d6 SWN example" could be our best bet - a really simple and easy one. I could talk about what's happening there from my perspective, if it would help. I do NOT understand how we can really think about that from a "gamestate" mindset without twisting ourselves into pretzels.

      For instance, the "gamestate model" suggests that the vorpal sword is "real", whereas the "green dragon" is not. Do you feel that's an accurate representation of the hypothetical game I've described, where a bunch of adventurers go into a dungeon, never encounter any kind of vorpal sword, but do meet a green dragon that turns out to have been raised by the adventurer's father? Because that's not how I would look at this.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Less relevantly, I can respond to Sandra's thought on the "utility" of what we're doing, because that's pretty cool. I don't expect a response to this - I'd much rather hear about the 2d6 and the green dragon! - but it might help someone reading along understand where I'm coming from:\n
      2097 said:

      Paul_T said:

      1. What, in practical terms, does this model or way of thinking give us that the following doesn\u2019t?

      * This game gives certain players the authority to prep certain information, and that prep must be honoured when we play.

      \nThe new model allows us to make a lot of rules about how and when to add/change information in the game state, including but not limited at campaign start, between sessions, in play etc.

      Our model is fundamental in order to create a rich variety in how we work with the other parts of the experience that aren\u2019t just rolling dice (Yahtzee principle) or talking (LBCBP).
      \nIf that's the case, that's great! I'm skeptical that we need this model to do that, though, and I have yet to see an example of an idea or rule or rules change which requires us to discard the BCB Principle in order to come into being.

      Why do I need a "new model" to make rules about prepping material for my game? Even the very earliest versions of D&D had rules for that.

      If you replace "talking" with "interpersonal communication", in the last sentence I quoted above (which you really should), then we can start talking about what that might be. Are there things we do when play an RPG together that aren't about communicating with each other in order to construct an imaginary setting, sequence of events, and so forth? If we can identify some, that would be pretty cool. I think. (I don't claim to have thought this particular part through in any detail. :P )

      What do I see as practical ideas, relevant to this discussion?

      Here are some ideas to explore that I'm seeing here, which I like and want to explore more, but that don't (in my opinion) have anything to do with the BCB Principle or that whole theoretical understanding of games:

      1. Let's talk about ways to do principled prep, and to handle information involved in our games that's not shared. Let's find new and cool and better techniques for the use of secret information at the table.

      Awesome. 100% down.

      2. Let's look at ways to communicate and to create, transform, or inject new information into our games that's not based on talking.

      Also awesome!

      (Although it seems to me this is only an issue because of the sloppy "Bog Model Wiki" text, which Sandra - understandably - took quite literally. I don't anyone who's given it more than two minutes of thought *actually* thinks that the only way we can communicate is by talking. So my disagreement here is with that Wiki entry - Sandra and I agree here, as far as I can see.)

      3. Let's discuss the idea of a "game state", as an analogue or metaphor which has all kinds considerations in it aside from we're narrating in the moment: physical information tracking (notes, tokens, dice, electronic devices), details of fictional positioning, and the implications of the rules we've agreed upon (and how they limit our ability to imagine events together). (Maybe other things, too.)

      Cool. Perhaps this will spark some ideas for new design, too. That would be awesome!

      (Although I'm skeptical, because, as far as I can see, that's just the "old" way of looking at RPG play which existed and was explored pretty fully, in my opinion, in the 80s, 90s, and still is today, especially by many trad gamers and the OSR crowd.)

      4. Let's find ways to make the fiction seem more real, concrete, and tangible.

      Super!

      I don't feel that any of these in any way invalidate the BCBP or whatever other theoretical ideas in any way. I feel 100% comfortable working with them from that point of view - there are no contradictions.

      It's when we start talking about some kind of strange "real" thing which "exists" somewhere, when it - very clearly, to me - does not in any way, shape, or form, except perhaps in wishful imagination, that I start to worry. Aren't we conflating fantasy and reality if we do that?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Here's another thing to consider:

      If we imagine that "content" gets "injected" into the gamestate in some fashion other than us communicating it to each other, how do we determine *when* that happens?

      Let's take AsIf's story. What if that player had written, on his note, "I put poison under my nails two days ago, just previous to the events of our last session"?

      Let's say the last session was a week ago (in the real world), and the events of that session a day ago (in diegetic time). The player wrote the note today, at 8am. We met to play at 4pm, and the poisoning finally happened at 7pm.

      In that case, since we're trying to argue that the gamestate has some "real" tangible existence, *when* did the poison get applied to the character's nails?

      This is the kind of thing that I find crystal clear under the BCBP, and I would like to hear how you would visualize that under a persistent "gamestate" model.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nSilmenume \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hi Jeph,\n
      Jeph said:

      No, it has nothing to do with the knowledge of the poison entering the SIS. It has nothing to do with whether the other players knew about the note.

      Suppose AsIf's group has the rule, "reasonable actions that players write down on paper are true, even if nobody's read them yet."

      Suppose AsIf's story was exactly as he'd written it, EXCEPT that TP had written his note, but not shared it with anyone.

      It still works exactly the same way.

      \nWhat you're not accounting for is that the human beings communicating at the table still gave the proposition credibility. You still get around that. If a player disagrees strongly enough the game comes to a halt and could end the campaign altogether. Role-play is what people communicate and agree upon. That part can never go away.

      WRT to the proposed rule - "reasonable actions that players write down on paper are true, even if nobody's read them yet" which did not exist in the recounting actually would read as -

      "reasonable actions proposals that players write down on paper are true given default credibility, even if nobody's read them yet"

      ...could stand if all the players agree to abide by it - LBCBP. But then we run into the adjudication of whether the written proposal was itself reasonable. This would then require players to agree as to whether the proposal met the reasonable threshold. This agreement process is still LBCBP.

      By the way, the pulling out of the note and showing it to the players is a communication process itself.

      Best,

      Jay
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Yes. Saying "I poisoned my nails" carries a certain level of credibility.

      Showing that you had written it earlier (by, e.g., putting it into a sealed envelope) increases the level of credibility dramatically. That's the whole point of doing so: to prove that you had the idea *before* the events which took place, making it much less likely that the other players will refuse to acknowledge that you did so.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nSilmenume \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 12 \n edited June 13
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hi Jeff,\n
      Jeph said:

      Suppose AsIf's story was exactly as he'd written it, EXCEPT that TP had written his note, but not shared it with anyone.

      \nIf the note is never shown ever then the poisoning never happened. No one knows about it.

      If you mean he never showed the note during the game then the credibility of his proposal ("I have a lethal poison applied under my fingernails") would have to be established. However I can guarantee you with certitude that nearly all tables would cry "cheater".

      Best,

      Jay

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nJeph \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 13 \n edited June 13
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n The credibility thing is pure distraction.

      Stop getting hung up on the note and the player's authority to write the note, ya'll.

      Pretend TP's character has a special ability straight from the core book that says, "Once in your character's lifetime, your character may secrete a contact poison (Con save DC 15, effect: immediate death) under their fingernails. You don't have to tell anyone else at the table when you do so. However, you do have to hold a purple cat's eye marble in the closed fist of your left hand."

      And instead of revealing his note, TP had just opened his left hand to reveal a purple cat's eye marble.

      No issue of authority or credibility.

      Completely isomorphic situation, as far as Lumpley Principle and Game State are concerned.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 13 \n edited June 13
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I actually think your example is a perfect illustration of precisely why authority and credibility are the core issue!

      The special ability from the core book and the marble in the hand give the player authority and credibility (almost unimpeachable credibility!). The act of opening his hand and showing the marble communicates his action to the other players.

      Consider how different that same moment in play would be if there was no such rule... ha! The player simply can't do so without the authority granted by the rules.

      That special ability in the book established credibility in the same way that the GM's notes in the module text did for the cake in the fridge.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAsIf \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 13 \n edited June 13
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Orthogonal to the larger discussion but submissible as evidence in regard to the poison: TP's character was an assassin and did indeed have poison. That point is unquestioned.

      Less tangential was the fact that as set forth by me myself, we were both tactically noodling with our character sheets the night before the fight. The implication here being that whatever arrangements and tactical plans we made "off screen" were indeed real, as long as our characters didn't suddenly acquire something they hadn't already possessed. In other words, if any transactions were said to have occurred (ie: "I went to the poison store and bought poison for 300GP"), some other Player might have rightfully called foul. I would have also called foul since I was still the acting GM at that moment, and interaction with an NPC would have required my participation.

      Of course, another interesting question is raised here: Is the GM still the GM even when the session has ended and nobody is at any table? But it's easy to answer Yes in this case, since this was my gameworld, and the day of the fight was the first and only time I ever handed over GM responsibilities for that world.

      In my model at the time - I'm still not sure what to call it - there was no rule broken. I was unhappy and felt betrayed by the other Players (one of them might have warned me, for instance, though that would have opened yet another epistemological can of worms)... But I did not refute the acting GM's ruling, nor that the application of the poison had indeed occurred.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 13 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n What an awesome story. I love it! (And I really hope Sandra gives it a name, like the "mirror story" and the "Ice Moon story". )

      I hope your sense of betrayal was more one of surprise than of legitimate disappointment in your friends, because that sounds like a lot of fun.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAsIf \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 13 \n edited June 13
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I felt a degree of legitimate disappointment, but it was admittedly illogical. One of the other Players spoke to me afterwards about it, saying that he wished there had been some way in-game to warn me, but there hadn't been. And I had to agree. In order for him to have warned me, he would have had to inject OOC information into his character (actual game-state data, not merely an idea), and we all knew that even with my fave NPC on the line, I wouldn't have agreed to the "reality" of that.

      So we have the following things to ponder about:
      1. What is considered injectable from Player to PC? (answer in this case: No to "game-state data" but Yes to "mere ideas" - because how could you not?)
      and
      2. Who needs to know about changes in game-state? (answer in this case: at least one other Player, whether or not their PCs are aware of it.)

      What I find interesting today is the fact that we all accepted the logic of the answers given above without even blinking. It's interesting because that's how well-formed our shared understanding of the rules of the space was. The reason he needed to have shared the note with at least one other person prior to the beginning of the fight was to prevent me from being able to accuse him of having written it during the fight. And we all knew that without even discussing it.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 13 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I really like the awareness on all sides of how to set up the order of events properly: you ceding GM responsibilities, the other player sharing his note, and so forth. It speaks to a high degree of self-awareness as well as familiarity with the group. Lovely!
      \n
      \n
